PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV

PARA.TAB: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—the petition of the residents of Tasmania respectfully sheweth:
that your petitioners, concerning parents and consumers respectfully request that the Broadcasting Services Bill which will control Television and Pay Television, will:
prohibit all considerably violent programs,
prohibit indecent and obscene programs, (to protect the young and impressionable),
prohibit blasphemous programs which denigrate religious faith or belief,
establish strict legally enforceable standards for programs and hours,
ensure that "nothing is included that will offend against good taste and decency
ensure that films are judged not as a whole, but each in its several parts,
that the Bill underpins and supports pro-social media in spirit and intent,
reject industry codes that will sell out Australia's defenceless children,
exempt all classification criteria and hours from s149d,
ensure genuine consumer consultation, so that parents can have access to program criteria information, and input into decision-making for their home environment,

PETITION.PARA: because children are defenceless and helpless, because they have no vote, no power, and no advocate other than you.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Campbell (from 1,521 citizens) and Senator Watson (from 13 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Commonwealth Threatened Species Bill recognises that Australia has the worse extinction record of native mammals of any country on Earth in recent history and that species extinctions are still occurring at an alarming rate.

Your Petitioners ask that the Senate should support Commonwealth Threatened Species legislation which uses the full powers given to it by the Australian Constitution and which provides the necessary financial resources to halt the loss of species on this, the oldest continent on earth.

PETITION.TITLE: Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia respectfully shows:
That the current Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance made by prospective citizens of Australia pledges allegiance to Her Majesty, Elizabeth II, Queen of Australia, Her Heirs and Successors.

PETITION.PARA: Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should:

PARA.TAB: Legislate to change the Australian Citizenship Oath/Affirmation of Allegiance to a pledge of Allegiance to Australia and the people of Australia, to reflect the true nature of Australian Government and society.

PETITION.PARA: And your Petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PARA.TAB: (1)Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2)The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3)These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a national poll.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pay TV
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned residents of Tasmania respectfully showeth:

1.That the Minister for Communications institute suitable safeguards into the legislation concerning Pay TV so that the program standards that currently exist in relation to ordinary on-air transmissions should also apply to Pay TV;

2.That the Minister for Communications be aware that there should be some restrictions to the programs shown on Pay TV in the interests of community standards, the safety of people and in particular the protection of children.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

PETITION.PARA: 1.The majority of Australians are completely satisfied with the existing Australian national flag and condemns the attack on the Australian flag by the Prime Minister Mr Keating while he was overseas.

2.We therefore request that the Senate ensures that the Australian national flag, as provided in Section (3) of the Flags Act, is not changed or replaced without first being voted upon and approved by the people of Australia in a referendum.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Slaughter of Walers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament:

PARA.TAB: The petition of certain citizens of Australia—
Walers Association of Australia and all interested parties.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should stop the senseless slaughter of walers in Australia, at least, until selection of some has taken place, for breeding purposes.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Waste in Urban Areas
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament Assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That exposure to radiation causes cancer, leukemia, and death;
(2) That the storage of radioactive wastes near urban areas risks the health of residents;
(3) That the Land and Environment Court of NSW has declared that the present storage of radioactive waste at Lucas Heights is illegal;
(4) That a Bill before the Senate seeks to remove all State restrictions on the storage of radioactive waste at this site.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the Senate reject the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill, 1992, and that the Senate take action to prevent the storage of radioactive waste in any populated area.

PETITION.TITLE: Women and Work
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled—
The Petition of the undersigned shows:
(1) That Australia has one of the most highly sex segregated workforces of any OECD country;
(2) That after nine years of Labor Government, women on average still earn only 83 per cent of equivalent male wages;
(3) That women suffer disproportionately from unemployment, making up 75 per cent of discouraged job seekers;
(4) That inflexible working hours and a lack of sufficient childcare facilities are detrimental to women in the workforce;
(5) That the economic platforms of both the Government and the Opposition fail to address these gender issues adequately.

Wherefore your Petitioners request that the parliament should recognise the significance of these facts, immediately take appropriate action to remedy the disadvantages suffered by women in economic life, and ensure that the power to make economic decisions affecting women is placed in women's hands.

PETITION.TITLE: Aims for Controlling Unemployment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled, the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully requests that:-
With the aim of reducing and controlling unemployment
(1) Parliament investigates the feasibility of creating a system to grant to the States interest free progressive credit to construct beneficial and precosted utilities.
Agreed continual percentage repayments to commence when project starts and credit to be fully repaid by an agreed time after completion.
(2) Examine the constitution to ascertain if sections facilitate or prohibit such finance. If not banned and feasible to implement, in the National interest, at the earliest possible time.
And your petitioners will as in duty bound ever pray.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on relations between Australia and the republics of Latin America, together with the transcript of evidence.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On behalf of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade I have pleasure in presenting the Committee's report Australia and Latin America and the Hansard record of the public hearings held by the Committee. Last year the Senate directed the Committee to inquire into Australia's relations with the republics of Latin America. The Committee was required to investigate opportunities for greater interaction in trade, investment, economic, political, cultural and multilateral contacts.

PARA.TAB: The Committee concluded early on that it would not be possible to focus on all 22 Latin American countries equally. Hence, while relations with all Latin American countries were examined, the Committee focused on those countries where economic activities, points of common interests and trade opportunities are strongest. Particular attention was paid to relations with Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Colombia, Mexico, Peru, Uruguay and Venezuela, all of which have missions located in Australia.

When it took on the task set by the Senate, the Committee was aware that it would be exploring a relationship about which little is known and even less written about. Nevertheless, it came as a surprise to Committee members to realise just how little was known or available and how massive a task it would turn out to be. I am happy to say that members of the Committee rose to the challenge. The result of 14 months of intensive work is evident in the substantial report before the Senate today.

In this time, the Committee examined submissions from 120 individuals and organisations, including government agencies, commercial organisations, cultural bodies and representatives of Latin American diplomatic missions in Australia. It was heartening that even some individuals from Latin America made submissions.

The Committee held 12 public hearings and took nearly 2,000 pages of Hansard evidence. With very few exceptions, all submissions, related correspondence and other material will shortly be available for reference as companion volumes to this report.

Throughout the inquiry the Committee received the unstinting support of Latin American diplomatic representatives in Australia. The Senate would be interested to know that four Latin American diplomats—the representatives of Chile, Colombia, Peru and Uruguay—appeared as witnesses before the Committee at public hearings. The fact that four diplomatic representatives gave evidence is unprecedented and a great honour to this Committee and, I am sure, to the Senate itself.

I would like to place on record the Committee's debt of appreciation to the ambassadors of Chile, Colombia and Peru, their Excellencies Mr Juan Salazar, Mr Fernando Navas de Brigard and Mr Gonzalo Bedoya, and to Mr Julio Giambruno, the former Charge d'Affaires of Uruguay. I also place on record Committee members' thanks to their Excellencies Mr Enrique Candioti, Ambassador of Argentina, Mr Marcos Cortes, Ambassador of Brazil, and Mr Marco Requena, Ambassador of Venezuela, and Counsellor of Uruguay, Mr Roberto Tourino, for making valuable up-to-date reference material available to the Committee.

The Committee similarly appreciates the assistance of former Ambassador of Colombia, Dr Antonio Puerto, and former Ambassador of Mexico, Mr Alejandro Morales. I would also like to take this opportunity to thank the staff of the Committee secretariat: the secretary, Ms Ilze Svenne, principal research officer, Kay Chee Lance, senior research officer, John O'Keefe, and executive assistant, Rachael Kelly.

The Committee is of the firm view that it is in Australia's interest to seek substantial improvements in the Australian-Latin America relationship across a wide spectrum of political and cultural activities. In 1991 and 1992, the overall picture for Latin America is of growing GDP, receding inflation, decreasing public debt, higher economic growth rates and outward looking economies.

The Committee recognises that a degree of caution remains. The success of Latin American political and economic reforms is not assured in some countries and both political and social problems remain in many Latin American societies. However, on balance, the Committee believes that Australia's interests would be well served by pursuing the economic opportunities that are increasingly evident in Latin America.

The Committee has made 63 wide ranging recommendations addressing the practical and policy aspects of the Latin American relationship. On behalf of the Committee, I would like to commend the report to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Deputy Chairman of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, and as a Liberal senator, I endorse every part of this very important major report entitled Australia and Latin America. The report is original and well researched and I believe that it maps out new prospects for Australia's relations with the Latin American republics.

PARA.TAB: I am very proud to say that this report would rank in the top half dozen of the 50 inquiries that I have been involved in in my time in this place. It has been a total pleasure to be involved in this inquiry with my Senate colleagues and staff. We are indebted to the family of ambassadors and other Latin American diplomatic representatives in Australia who made submissions and appeared before the Committee.

The seeds of this inquiry were sown as a result of a conversation I had in October 1990 with the first Colombian Ambassador to Australia, Dr Tony Puerto. He opened my eyes to the modernisation that was taking place in Colombia. My horizons were extended as a result of reading about and researching what was happening in Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Uruguay, which is our best partner in the GATT Round, and oil rich Venezuela. It was a very real sense of discovery to me personally to learn about the enormous prospects of closer economic relations between Australia and Mexico. It was exciting to find that we could have a useful task in this Senate inquiry, setting out a clear set of parameters regarding our relations with this whole region.

Thirty years ago there was a parliamentary initiative in that the then Minister for Trade, Jack McEwen, encouraged Senator John Gorton to lead a seven member—three Liberal, three Labor and himself—parliamentary delegation to six countries in the region. Many initiatives were set out then, but I am afraid most of them were frustrated in the decade or so that followed.

I was happy to visit seven countries in the region a year ago. The direct contact I had with government, business and parliamentary representatives in the seven countries I visited served to inform me in my contribution to this report. I am enormously grateful to my hosts in Latin America.

In the half minute that remains to me, I note the 63 recommendations of this inquiry. They are all, I believe, well formulated. I refer to recommendation 14, for example, which sets a target of 3 per cent for Australia's share of trade with Latin America. At the moment it is one per cent. I believe we can move to this target of 3 per cent by the end of the decade. Recommendation 31 calls for the establishment of a task force, focusing initially on the next two years, to provide a foundation so that our relationship can live up to its full potential.

There are many recommendations relating to general education exchanges, Spanish language, people to people exchanges, immigration changes, and development of aviation and shipping. Of course, most of the recommendations relate to economics and politics. Some, such as recommendation 62, are very specific in recommending to the Australian Government that Mexico's application for membership of APEC be supported.
Finally, I wish to thank my fellow senators, staff, the Latin American ambassadors and my hosts in Latin America for their contributions, directly and indirectly, to this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased, in the brief time available to me today, to join Senator Maguire, Senator Teague and my other colleagues in commending to the Senate this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I guess the general ignorance of Australians with regard to Latin America was typified by my own experience. I had very little knowledge of the wealth and cultural diversity of Latin America and of the enormous opportunities for trade and further contact between Australia and Latin America. This report focuses on those opportunities and is one that I believe will lead to a much greater recognition and contact between Australia and the Latin American countries.

PARA.TAB: I join my colleagues also in thanking the staff of the Committee for the excellent work that they did, under the secretary, Ilze Svenne. I also thank the Latin American ambassadors and representatives—many of whom are in your gallery at the moment, Mr Acting Deputy President—for the considerable assistance they gave in putting this report together. All of the recommendations are very important. I would like to have time to speak about many of them. I simply highlight recommendations 14 and 26 for further specific consideration, and generally commend the report and the recommendations to the Government and this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the one minute available to me, I simply want to say that this report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade puts to rest for all time the question as to whether or not Latin America is part of the Pacific Basin. Clearly, this report establishes that it does in fact form part of the Basin and ought to be contemplated in any discussions the Government ever has in considering the aspirations for trade growth in the Pacific Basin. I have for a decade belonged to the Pacific Basin Economic Council. In that Council we have always considered, and had membership from, some countries in Latin America. Let me echo the thanks that have been given by my colleagues. I am delighted that we now officially recognise Latin America as part of the Basin.

—I would also like to associate myself with the comments that have been made on the report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on relations between Australia and the republics of Latin America. I acknowledge the presence in the gallery today of a number of ambassadors and representatives of the countries involved. I hope that this report goes some way, and it should, to dispelling a lot of the myths about Latin America that are prevalent in the community, even among people who should know better.

PARA.TAB: If this report achieves nothing else but to dispel the myths and accurately to portray the situation that exists in those places and the importance of the relationship that there should be between Australia and Latin America, we have still achieved a great deal. I realise that the report is large, but I recommend that people read it, particularly the 63 recommendations. I look forward to hearing the Government's response, especially when we are asking other departments and organisations to look at the importance in Australia of learning foreign languages.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (ADMINISTRATION) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE CHARGE BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION GUARANTEE (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992SUPERANNUATION LEGISLATION (CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS AND TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1992

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the second report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation on the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 and three related Bills, together with the provisions of those Bills.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The subject matter of the report has been widely covered in the media recently. Before I go into the details of the report, I would first like to acknowledge the very hard work of the dedicated staff of the Committee secretariat. It has been an extremely difficult job to produce the report within the time requirements, particularly given that another report—a 150-page report—was prepared on prudential and safety matters only two weeks ago.

PARA.TAB: In saying that, I would also like to acknowledge the role of Lynne Curran, who is leaving our secretariat and going back to the Department of the Treasury before the completion of our third report, which is due in September. I would also like to thank the printing office; it was placed under enormous pressure. I would also like the thank my colleagues on the Committee, although I have to say, regrettably, that the significant degree of unanimity we had in the last report is not reflected in this report.

In the majority report, the recommendations are contained on page 81. The majority of the Committee, including the Australian Democrats, recommend the passing of the various Bills with a range of amendments which we recommend. Most of the amendments that are recommended in the report have been well canvassed in the media and include the current matters.

Under the schedule of provisions, the improvement in superannuation benefits from 3 per cent to 9 per cent is to occur from this year to the year 2002-03. That is a two-year increase in the timetable. The 4 per cent is to apply from 1 July this year to 31 December this year. The 5 per cent is to apply from 1 January next year to 30 June next year, with one proviso, which is that the timetable can be varied by six months.

The payroll threshold between small business and large business was originally flagged at $500,000. It is now recommended that that go to $1m. Originally the payment of superannuation moneys was proposed to be monthly; now it is proposed that it be quarterly. It is recommended that the minimum wage contribution threshold above which superannuation money should be paid be increased from $250 a month to $450 a month with the proviso that, where existing award provisions are lower than $450 a month, that should be maintained.

Matters included in the report but not reported on widely in the media include a recommendation that a ruling be sought from the Tax Commissioner as to a definition of `employee'. There are also some recommendations with respect to some fairly minor but important technical matters: for example, that remuneration for local councillors not be covered; that there be a rewording of the way in which defined benefits apply; and also that there be a rewording of the clauses of the Bill with respect to problems where a person's income on some occasions drops below the monthly threshold and on others goes above it.

A range of related announcements were made by the Government and these are important in the context of the majority report which recommends accepting the Bills. Firstly, the Government has announced acceptance of a range of regulations and safety improvements which were outlined in our report entitled Safeguarding Super—The Regulation of Superannuation that was tabled only two weeks ago. It must be almost a record time for a government to respond positively to a range of recommendations and report to the Senate. Secondly, the Government has announced that the preservation age for superannuation payments should be increased to 60 by the year 2025. Thirdly, a tax package will be announced by the Treasurer. Fourthly, in terms of the wages aspect, there will be amendments to the Industrial Relations Act to ensure that the increases in superannuation are taken into account in future wage movements. Finally, it is recommended that group training companies and service organisations not be disadvantaged and that any cost increases be taken into account in terms of the Budget.

I will now address some of the wider issues relating to the superannuation guarantee levy. This country faces an ageing population. At the present time there are 1.9 million persons over the age of 65—11 per cent of our population. By the year 2000 that will rise to 4.1 million—some 17 per cent. By the year 2031 it will be 5.2 million—some 20 per cent of Australia's population. Currently, pensions cost 2.8 per cent of gross domestic product. By the year 2025 they will cost 4.5 per cent of gross domestic product. It was very clearly evidenced before the Committee that we need to ensure that contributions of 12 per cent are made over 40 years to ensure a decent old age pension.

We carried out an evaluation of the overseas experience. We surveyed some 24 countries and all but two of those countries provide for very substantial levels of compulsory contributions with respect to superannuation and social security payments. Of the two exceptions, one, New Zealand, is interesting; it has not provided for old age pensions. New Zealand is an interesting example because it is so often touted by those opposite as a country on which our public policy should be modelled. But, interestingly, only last year the new National Government in New Zealand attempted to reduce old age pensions because it simply has not been able to afford them through the Budget process.

The evidence before the Committee was overwhelming on the issue of establishing adequate levels of compulsory superannuation for pensions. There were significant differences in two areas. Significant areas of business complained about the timetable and about who should pay. But they did recognise the principle involved in compulsion and setting realistic levels. There was also opposition from a range of welfare groups—and I will go into that a little later. But without these reforms the pressures to reduce the old age pension will be enormous. There are significant sectors of the work force at the present time that are not receiving the supposedly compulsory 3 per cent contribution—some 14 per cent of the work force. That is the estimate of the Department of Industrial Relations.

I will turn briefly to the opposition to these measures. In terms of business groups, a commitment has been given that the estimated cost of 3 to 4 per cent over the next decade will be taken into account in future wage cases. In terms of the vociferous complaints, particularly from business and, I notice, from some State Premiers, including Labor Premiers, there will not be any significant increase in unemployment resulting from these measures. The cost will be taken into account in future wage negotiations.

In terms of the complaints of some welfare groups, I would have to say that, frankly, they are misguided and lack a vision of what, potentially and catastrophically, could occur in terms of the current old age pension if we do not tackle this issue now and if we do not provide substantial levels of self-funding for those who can afford it. Thirty to 40 years hence, I would predict that, if we do not have the substantial levels of compulsory superannuation that are provided for in the legislation, the current old age pension will be reduced by future governments. That is something we must avoid.

In that context, I emphasise that, in terms of the proposals, low income earners will be substantial beneficiaries. Because of this legislation, when persons who are on 50 per cent of average weekly earnings—or about $15,000 or $16,000 a year—retire after 40 years, they will have a 31 per cent increase in retirement income over and above the current old age pension. Those persons who are on 75 per cent of average weekly earnings—about $24,000 or $25,000 a year—will have a 17 per cent increase in their retirement income. I want to put to bed this myth that low income earners are disadvantaged.

This is a progressive measure. Those persons in our society who are receiving very substantial levels of superannuation, who tend to be the higher paid, will not receive any benefit from this legislation; that is as it should be. At the same time, in terms of future wage cases, they will be expected to forgo an across-the-board 3 to 4 per cent in future wage increases. Those persons who receive little superannuation or none at all, who will receive a 6 to 9 per cent benefit from this legislation, will be expected to forgo only 3 to 4 per cent in future wage increases. It is a pretty good deal for low income earners.

With regard to those persons who do not spend significant time in the work force—that includes, particularly, women who, for significant periods, are in many cases bearing children—it is important to emphasise that the current old age pension will be maintained. The potential will exist, because of improvements in the budgetary situation, to improve the old age pension. The only way we can improve the old age pension is to adopt the measures outlined in the legislation that has been presented to the Senate.

There have been complaints that there should be an option of a wage increase for lower income earners. I say to those persons in the welfare community who continually advocate that option that it is simply not available in the current economic or industrial relations framework. With regard to those persons who are on very low levels of income, no more than a few hundred dollars a month, assistance can be, and has been, targeted by this Government in other ways, through the social security system.

The contrast between the majority report and the principles underlying this legislation and the position that the Opposition is presenting is quite stark. The Government is proposing by the year 2002 a 12 per cent level of contributions. As I have outlined, we believe that will be adequate to fund and improve old age pensions, in order to avoid the catastrophic problems that are confronting New Zealand and the catastrophic problems that could confront this country in 30 or 40 years time.

Those opposite, of course, are advocating a 5 per cent level of compulsory contributions and then they would rely on so-called tax incentives to encourage people to get to the 12 per cent threshold. All I can say is that it has not worked anywhere else in the world.

What the Opposition is prescribing through its Fightback package is a recipe for disaster. In fact, it is a recipe for halving old age pensions. That would be the reality of the outcome if the Opposition's package were ever adopted. It is a recipe for halving old age pensions.

The proposals outlined in the legislation are realistic, economically responsible and the right way for this country to go. The policy that is outlined is visionary. It is very rare for politicians to look 30 or 40 years ahead, but this policy is very long term. It overcomes a variety of public policy issues with respect to old age pensions that have been debated over the last 80 years and about which nothing has been done. It was not until the election of this Labor Government that we started to tackle the issues of the ageing population.

With this legislation and other matters that will be announced in the Budget session we will bed down the big picture issues affecting retirement incomes in this country. It is this Government that is presenting a realistic vision of the future. It is this Government, led by our Prime Minister, Paul Keating, with the policies enunciated through the One Nation package, that has provided an adequate and improved level and an improved pension level for Australia's elderly.

With those remarks, I commend the report to the Senate. It is, regrettably, a majority report. I again pay tribute to the Committee staff, the Government Printing Office and Opposition members of the Committee. They cooperated very significantly during massive number of hearings and in the production of the report. I also pay tribute to my deputy, Senator Alston. We may disagree on the basic underlying principles, but it was a pleasure to cooperate with the Opposition, at least, in the committee work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation which examined the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill and related legislation—a very significant package of Bills. I think this matter deserves a lot more attention than it is going to get today. I echo the thoughts of Senator Sherry, the Chairman of the Select Committee on Superannuation. I found the spirit of cooperation to be quite exemplary. Certainly, in my time I have not worked better with a group of disparate members.
—You said `disparate'.

—I did—it was not meant to be a freudian slip. I also pay tribute to the staff of the Committee. As I said in the context of the first report, which dealt with safeguarding superannuation, in my experience the quality of their contribution is unsurpassed. I found their assistance to be of enormous value. I pay tribute also to Senator Kernot and other members of the Committee. I think we have worked very well together.

PARA.TAB: This Bill raises passions and has very high political stakes attached to it. For that reason, it is easy to be sidetracked. Unfortunately, this week has seen probably the greatest example of sidetracking. For nine months now the Committee has been assessing a whole range of very important issues in the area of superannuation and conducting extensive hearings in relation to this Bill. One would have thought if the democratic process were operating effectively, at the very least the government of the day would wait and hear what the Committee had to say on these issues. Instead, all we have had is the usual unseemly horse trading behind the scenes, totally ignoring any public—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very public.

—The deals were not; the outcome was. Saturation media coverage is no substitute for sensible and rational debate. But let me say that that is probably almost inevitable in the context of a government that is desperate to put in place prior to the next election some sort of deal to demonstrate to the workers of Australia that it has not forgotten them entirely.

PARA.TAB: The tragedy of the matter is that, in the midst the worst recession in 60 years and record levels of unemployment, what we are now seeing as a result of this deal done with the Australian Democrats is a package that will inevitably guarantee significant levels of unemployment. Indeed, the low and middle income earners, for whom the Government professes a great deal of concern, are the worst losers of all. As we know, this generation will have to pay twice. Those at the bottom end of the income scale will simply be forced to accept lower standards of living in order to have the privilege of disqualifying themselves from the age pension. As that message gets out over the weeks and months ahead, I cannot imagine that anyone is going to be particularly grateful to either the Government or the Australian Democrats for what is now going to be imposed on employers.

If we look for a moment at international experience, it is unique to suggest that somehow all the burden ought to be borne by employers and not by employees. This is one of the examples of gross hypocrisy that I find quite entertaining in one sense because it is so logically flawed. The Government is saying, `Look, there will not be any significant level of job losses'. Now the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) is talking about negligible losses. Senator Kernot concedes that there will be job losses. It is all a question of how much. We are not going to get any more admissions than that, but I would have thought that it is quite sufficient for the people of Australia to realise who is going to be paying the bill.

The Government's proposition is that there will not be any significant job losses because employees will bear the burden. How will they bear the burden? Treasury has made it perfectly clear. They will bear the burden because the cost of the SGL regime, compulsory superannuation, will be offset by discounts against wage increases. The only possible way in which we can afford to have both—which is now the pre-election preferred position of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—is if we suddenly start to get very significant levels of economic growth and productivity increases.

The classic three-card trick that the Democrats have fallen for is that somehow, by amending the Industrial Relations Commission legislation, the unions are going to take this into account before the event. They are not. They will do what they have always done, and that is go along to the Commission and say, `Things are crook. We cannot afford it on paper, but give us a wage increase and we solemnly and sincerely declare that we will deliver massive work practice reforms and massive productivity increases more than sufficient to pay for what you are giving us up front'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let the Industrial Relations Commission decide, not you.

—The track record is such that there is no basis at all for believing that the Industrial Relations Commission is suddenly going to turn around and say that. But, even worse, the IRC charter is to settle industrial disputes—above all else. The unions do the deal by going out into the field and threatening massive chaos and industrial confrontation. Once the deal is done, and wage increases are ensured, they go along to the Commission and ask for the agreement to be ratified. As Senator Cook is wont to say, the parties accept the umpire's decision, but if it does not suit the unions then they will get out there and push and shove once again.

PARA.TAB: There is absolutely no basis at all for confidence. Look at Jackboot John Halfpenny's latest contribution. The union movement now wants an extra one per cent compensation because somehow the Democrats have managed to get the Government down from 5 per cent to 4 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you know they are going to get it?
—They will get it in the field. They do not have to get it from the IRC.
—How? Not at the moment. There is not much scope for it at the moment.

—We will wait and see. All I can say is that history is very much on the side of those who believe that, inevitably, we will see higher levels of unemployment, higher levels of inflation and, I would have thought, lower standards of living; in other words, the worst possible outcome. The future will be a combination of all of those; it will not be all or nothing. But the end result will be a complete disaster.

PARA.TAB: Looking at the model in Singapore or anywhere else, it can be seen that one simply cannot impose compulsion without it squeezing out somewhere else. It will be squeezed out in times of declining living standards and falling levels of disposable income in the form of transfers of savings from one pocket to another, people going further into consumer debt, and people not being prepared to accept a lower standard of living. By definition, if people think that employers can afford to pay—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is why they have not saved.

—Because they cannot afford to—precisely. If governments are fair dinkum about jobs, they make that their No. 1 priority and do everything possible to try to get the economy moving again—take the burden off the back of employers, enable them to create jobs, new investment and whatever else is needed. I will not give honourable senators a lecture on Fightback but, as they would know, Fightback is all about taking a $20 billion burden off the backs of business in order to create jobs. That ought to be the No. 1 priority for all of us. Yet what is being said is that somehow we can impose a multi-billion dollar payroll tax on industry and on small business—and it is going to treble and quadruple over the next 10 years—and somehow pretend that that is going to create jobs. It will do precisely the opposite.
—Most of the editorials in the newspapers around this country don't agree with you.
—That is just not so.
—Even Professor Knox doesn't agree with you.

—Do not talk about Professor Knox. I will tell honourable senators precisely where Professor Knox stands. Professor Knox has been on the record time and again as saying that he believes that there ought to be a core level of compulsion, but that it ought to be in place in accordance with the capacity of the economy to pay and that there ought to be significant taxation incentives and a universal system of rebates to encourage people to go beyond the floor. That is precisely what we have put down. So there is no quarrel with us, I can assure the honourable senator. Professor Knox may well prefer a higher level of compulsion. In the industry they prefer a 20 per cent level of compulsion, but that is not the way one judges these things in the national interest. One judges them by taking a macro-economic view of the world. One will not get too many rational economists saying that we can simply impose a compulsory burden on people without something having to give elsewhere. That is the tragedy of this sordid little deal. It is not going to be in anyone's interests. It is simply going to have very disadvantageous consequences for the people it is designed to help.

PARA.TAB: If one talks about, as people often do, the desperate and overwhelming need for bipartisanship, one will not ever get that when one has a government that is quite happy to turn its back on the Industrial Relations Commission. It went along and asked for a second round 3 per cent. It got hit on the head for a variety of reasons. Because the IRC, and I say this to Senator Kernot in particular, does not have a mandate to really look at capacity to pay—if one reads the judgment one sees this—its members did not really address that issue. They just inferentially picked up a lot of the CAI concerns and then went on to say that they shared the concern about impact on part time and casual workers and then they recommended a national conference. That was a polite way of saying that the whole system was flawed and unaffordable and that it was about time someone got out there and had a sensible and dispassionate public debate about the subject.

Instead, what we got was absolute silence and Kelty's mob saying things like, `We don't believe in talkfests. We are determined to devise a new and better enforcement mechanism for a failed award superannuation system'. That then turned itself into compulsory superannuation, and that is what we have got. They have religiously refused to talk to anyone in the public arena ever since. They have done deals behind people's backs and finally managed to corral the Democrats this week and sweet talk them over a couple of days and it has all happened.

The tragedy is that, if one wants a sensible and rational public debate, one will take the industrial relations component out of this. No-one will say that compulsory superannuation still requires award superannuation. They will all say, `If you are going to go the compulsion path—go there. Just tell people what to do. Allow them to contribute to any complying fund, you will build up your levels and away you go'. No-one in his right mind would attempt to justify the need for award superannuation, even to the point where one can meet one's SGL obligations and still be in breach of the awards. The agenda is so naked and transparent. This is a means of ensuring that ever-increasing amounts go into industry funds and that the ACTU has something to show its members to justify the fact that its members have been leaving in droves and that they have been getting falling standards of income over the last 10 years and to somehow pretend that 40 years down the track they will be better off. The fact is that they are not.

I will just give the Senate the classic example of hypocrisy, which I find quite extraordinary. The two principal justifications for compulsory superannuation are that it will boost national savings and that it will help to reduce the rising cost of age pensions. Enough said about national savings; one boosts those on a macro-economic basis. One does not do it by simply having a narrow retirement income superannuation perspective, thinking that somehow that will do the trick, because it will not, and all the evidence says it will not.

When it comes to arresting the rising cost of age pensions, I have to say that I know why the ACTU and Senator Sherry want to get up and talk about catastrophic consequences and all this other scare scenario stuff. The fact is that there is no tidal wave about to engulf us. Someone sent me something the other day and I thought it was very good. It said that with the best will in the world no-one can tell what is going to happen in 30 or 40 years time. The pace of technological change is ever-accelerating. Who knows? It could be anything from euthanasia to dramatic reforms in bio-technology—

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that in Fightback?

—No, that is not in Fightback. I am just saying that, the way some of the honourable senator's colleagues believe in meaningful exits or whatever they call them, they are probably going to be in favour of some form of euthanasia before too much longer. We are not. I am saying that there will be so many technological changes in bio-technology that we may well find that the cost of maintaining the elderly is actually a great deal cheaper than it is today. We talked about how the abolition of compulsory retirement ages will also ease the burden quite dramatically. I want to quote from one objective assessment—not the Barry Jones report, which I thought made the point very well, but from a book which is called The Greying of Australia, Japan and the United States, written by three international demographers. It says this:

SPEECH.PARA: Not only is most of the "burden of the elderly" literature over-simplistic, it encourages us to look for solutions in the wrong places. Today, as in the past, the most important determinants of the future economic welfare of people (of all ages) are the longstanding factors discussed by economists and others as influencing growth: labour force participation, saving, investment in human and business capital, technological change, entrepreneurial initiatives, managerial skills, government provision of infrastructure, and so on. Thus the debate over how best to run an economic system is not primarily an ageing discussion. In fact, the ageing of populations may have little to do with the outcome.

They are the facts. No-one can tell what is going to happen 40 years down the track. It is sheer, utter, arrant hypocrisy to pretend that somehow things are so desperate that not only have we got to impose a 12 per cent regime but also that it has to be done before the next election, that we cannot wait for the Senate Committee to report, that we cannot wait until Mr Dawkins's paper on simplification comes out, that we cannot possibly afford to talk to any of the interest groups, all of whom came along and bagged this legislation to the Committee. It has to be done by a deal as quickly as possible. I do not know what the Democrats got out of it. I know what the Government gets out of it. It gets out of it some sort of plausible little package that it can dish up in the run-up to the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —We get a bit of economic credibility, actually.

—I do not follow the economic credibility argument. This is a complete and utter disaster. I want to address the other major leg, which is arresting the rising cost of age pensions. Senator Sherry said this morning that the Government was now prepared to raise the preservation age to age 60 in 35 years. It is not even prepared to do that. If we look at the answers that Senator Kernot got we see that the Government is going to consider doing that. It is absolute nonsense. How could any responsible commentator say that this will do anything other than blow that double dipping gap out to such a point that there are not going to be any savings at all? The first witness I would call is Iain Ross. Iain Ross has made it abundantly clear that the union movement believes that a person has a right to take a lump sum at 55, pay off his mortgage and get the age pension. The union movement is not in the business of cutting the rising cost of age pensions. So how do we save money? Sorry, I am getting too excited.
—Aren't you going to give Senator Kernot some time?
—I thought I had 20 minutes.
—We can do it all again next week.
—Yes, we can do it all again next week.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Senator, I have just become aware of the official agreement at the moment. I understand that you are taking about 15 minutes each.

TALK.START.PARA: —All right, I will wind up. My understanding was that I had 20 minutes. I simply want to conclude by saying that this is not much more than a pre-election gimmick. It certainly does not address the long term retirement needs of Australia. The only sensible way to do that on a tripartisan basis is to ensure that we discuss the issues and the implications at length. In the absence of any material to persuade the Democrats that there will not be any significant job losses, I am simply at a loss to comprehend how this deal could have been done in the way that it has been done. All the tinkering at the edges will make very little difference to the core issue, which is that there will be very significant job losses or very significant cuts in the standard of living.

PARA.TAB: If we are fair dinkum about providing for people's retirement incomes, we do that by getting the economy back on track, and by ensuring that we do not put any further burdens or obstacles in their path. Instead of a sensible retirement incomes policy, what comes out of this is simply an employer funded, taxpayer subsidised early retirement scheme. It is an industrial relations solution to a wages and union membership problem and it will not go anywhere near doing the task that needs to be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Select Committee on Superannuation has engaged in an extremely demanding but rewarding examination of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill and three related Bills. In a very short space of time, the Committee heard over 200 witnesses and had access to over 6,000 pages of evidence. So Senator Alston should not say that the Committee did not canvass the issues—200 witnesses, 6,000 pages of evidence and some of the witnesses had the opportunity to come back and reargue their case in the light of previous evidence, which does not happen very often. Amongst those witnesses were the foremost persons in Australia on superannuation, social welfare and industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: This inquiry has been unique for a number of reasons. Firstly, the Bills were referred by the Democrats on the initiative of the Committee. A most detailed and lengthy report has been prepared. One normally does not see in this chamber a report of this size on a Bill.

The Committee's report, Safeguarding Superannuation, contains Government commitments to implement key recommendations. I have a letter from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) committing the Government to enact this legislation in the coming Budget session. The Government responded to the Committee's report in the record time of 12 days. That was a factor in my reaching a decision on this matter on behalf of the Democrats.

The hearings unearthed a host of issues which the Committee has considered, many of which it agreed on and others it disagreed on and even agonised over. I refer to the issues of vesting, preservation, double dipping, what is an acceptable target to aim for and the urgent need for extensive education so that, in the same way as we need to have an informed democracy, we need to have an informed membership of superannuation funds so that members can exercise their right over where their money ends up.

The Committee spent quite a lot of time on the issue of compulsion versus voluntarism. The overwhelming evidence was in favour of compulsion. However one looks at it, for some reason there has been a market failure in Australia. I think the reason is a combination of both political and cultural factors. As a nation we have failed to save. We do not take provision for ourselves in the long term future seriously.

I do not believe that governments have been serious enough about savings incentives. I acknowledge that the Opposition in its Fightback package plans to address that. We need to do that as well as put in place this compulsory superannuation system.

So one of the big issues to weigh up from the 6,000 pages of evidence is: can we afford to wait? I say to Senator Alston that we do not know with any certainty what lies ahead of us in 30 or 40 years. But do we have to wait until we get there and find out before we decide what we should have done? Of course we do not. We have to make a judgment now.

Having gone through the 6,000 pages of evidence of the 200 witnesses, the ultimate decision making comes down to one's fundamental view of the world, based on experience. If I had to decide on putting in place something which has a probability of working and which could minimise impact on business, I would make the judgment that we need to do something now rather than do nothing and wait for the Opposition to come into government—wait for the Opposition to give us another three or four years to find out whether what it thinks about voluntarism is right or wrong, wait for the Opposition to review that and to decide what it will do about the fact that it has not worked. In the meantime this nation would have lost the opportunity to tackle retirement incomes policy in a meaningful way for another five or six years. I decided that it was not fair for us to do that.

The recommendations in this report will go a long way towards placing Australia on the threshold of a sound retirement income system. But it is not my preferred model. The fact of life is the Democrats do not get to impose their agenda, as they would really like it, on either the Government or the Opposition. Our policy is for a national portable superannuation scheme, along the lines, perhaps, of the Singapore model, but that was not on the table. On the table were Government and Opposition proposals. That is the way things work here. I had to make a judgment on what I think, based on the evidence, about either of those proposals. So I made a judgment.

I believe that, as long as the increments on employers are not too onerous—and honourable senators know my concern about that; it is well documented; hence the substantial amendments to this timetable—then this SGL proposal in these Bills will succeed. I do believe that a correct balance has been struck between the national interest, business considerations and individual welfare.

Senator Alston said I had not talked to interest groups. The fact of the matter is I did talk to interest groups between the Government's response on the Sunday night and the party room making a decision on the Tuesday afternoon. Again, I had to make the difficult judgment of whether to put something in place for 90 per cent of employees in Australia and at the same time try to do something complementary for low income earners.

I do not approach this legislation as the beginning and end of retirement incomes policy. This is one important part. I believe that we can pursue justice for low income earners through this Bill. Despite the fact that the appendix contains details of the discussions which took place between the Government and the Democrats, not all of those have been agreed to. We have agreed to a schedule, a rate of implementation and quarterly payments. But there are many other things which are still in the negotiable phase, which interest groups need to understand.

One can support the concerns of low income earners by attempting to gain community and parliamentary support for a flat rate instead of a percentage wage increase in any national wage case. That is an important aim that is complementary to the objectives of this legislation.

Before I get on to the wider political context, I commend the report and draw attention to the Democrats' dissent, which represents my Party's policy on retirement incomes as well as the need to mobilise national savings for the long term benefit of all Australians. I also pay tribute to the Chair, particularly for his tolerance under extreme political aggro. I pay tribute to my colleagues. Despite our acknowledgment of the seriousness of this topic and the decision we were making for the provision of retirement income for generations of Australians from now, most of the time we conducted ourselves in an exemplary manner.

I commend the secretariat for its capacity to produce another long and comprehensive report under the considerable pressure of time frames imposed upon it by political imperatives. I especially mention the printers, Mr Gordon Kimber and his staff, who toiled in what we call the dungeons till 1 o'clock this morning. That really needs to be on the record. We are grateful to them for allowing us to meet our deadline.

I will now say a few final words in the wider political context regarding whether the Democrats have done the right thing in agreeing to the passage of these Bills. I refer to the Adelaide Advertiser, not known for its support of any Democrat initiative ever. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians must have a national superannuation scheme to provide for retirement and to remove the massive pension burden from the taxpayer as the population ages. While it is unfortunate that the introduction of this imaginative reform has to coincide with a severe recession and the highest unemployment this country has suffered since World War II, it was vital the Democrats and the Government reached agreement yesterday to allow it to proceed. The nation now has an acceptable scheme which will come into effect next month.

PARA.TAB: Predictions of job losses and the likely financial stresses on business because of the superannuation guarantee levy should be treated with caution. Initially, there will be no additional financial burden on small to medium enterprises now that the Government has agreed . . .

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that is wrong.
—Just listen; there are two categories here:

SPEECH.PARA: to lift the higher rate threshold to $1 million. This leaves most of those businesses committed only to the current 3 per cent that they have already been paying as award superannuation.

PARA.TAB: For bigger companies, those with a payroll of $1 million or more, the position is also relatively comfortable because the levy calls for a total payment by the company of 4 per cent in the first year. As most of these companies already have staff superannuation schemes in place, the additional 1 per cent in most cases is more than covered. . .
In theory, the ACTU's productivity proposals should fund that additional payment, with an extra two years' grace now that the rise to 9 per cent is to be phased in by the year 2002. . .
Employers do not need additional cost burdens during a recession—

SPEECH.PARA: that is true—
so a compromise along the lines suggested by the Democrats was necessary.

Funny how it is called `a compromise' and not `a shabby little deal'. When is a deal a deal? That is one of my themes in this place, but we will go into that at another time. The Democrats have, it goes on to say:
. . . held their ground justifiably and Australia now will have a scheme that provides adequately for self-funded retirement without standing in the way of job growth.
Now from the Brisbane Courier-Mail—

TALK.START.PARA: —That could have been written by a cub journalist.
—Please listen, Senator Alston, because the Courier-Mail is certainly not prone to praising Democrats either.
—Why don't you tell us about the preservation age, and about companies that go from naught per cent to 3 per cent?
—I will address all those things next week. I only have a couple of minutes left. I quote from the Courier-Mail:

SPEECH.PARA: The Democrats' position on compulsory employer-funded superannuation is not, as Dr Hewson apparently wants everyone to believe, a function of their having found a cosy nest in the Labor Party's pocket.
How I will frame these words! It continues:

The facts of life in the Senate—where the Democrats hold the balance of power—have forced the Federal Government to make a substantial concession on starting price, if not the tote. Any means of lessening the impost on employers in these grim times is sensible politics.

To be fair, I note that the rest of the editorial goes on to ask the Democrats to consider the argument about incentives to save and the burden that businesses do have to bear, and I am prepared to consider those.

PARA.TAB: Finally, let me put on the table what we have. We have agreement from this Government to act on prudential supervision legislation between now and Christmas. That is wonderful news, and I will be holding the Government to it. We have agreement that the Industrial Relations Commission Act will ensure that the Industrial Relations Commission takes the superannuation guarantee levy specifically into account when determining national wage decisions. We had an indication yesterday that there is some room for movement on the issue of flat rate increases instead of percentage rises in national wages. This will go a long way towards assisting low income earners.
The big issue for the next six months and beyond is prudential supervision. I can assure honourable senators that, in the words of yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: It's obvious from this that keeping the superannuation industry honest is the real task now facing the politicians.
I can assure honourable senators that the members of this Committee will be pursuing that initiative with vigour. I commend the Committee's report.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the second report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. This particular report focuses on four Bills collectively known as the superannuation guarantee Bills. I suppose the best feature of this report is certainly the minority report produced by Senator Alston and myself, because that focuses on the problems associated with these Bills.

PARA.TAB: Before proceeding, I would like to acknowledge the very important role of the secretariat staff in assisting with this particular inquiry. It has indeed been a rush job. In being a rush job, the quality of both the first report and this report is unsurpassed, I believe, and therefore special tributes must go to the Secretary, Mr Richard Gilbert, who is present; principal research officer, Miss L. Curran, from Treasury; principal research officer, Mr Game; senior research officer, Mr Power; and executive assistant, Ms H. Hibbitt.

However, there is one unfortunate aspect of the presentation of this report today in that, before the tabling of this report, the Australian Democrats, having gained all the insight and information from this report, rushed off and did a deal with the Government. I think the timing is most unfortunate. It certainly does not assist in terms of solidarity amongst members of the Committee when certain sections of that Committee rush off, armed with inside information, to then do deals with the Government. They may have indicated that time was a problem, but given the fact that this did happen, it will not enhance the status or reputation of Senate select committees or the presentation and manner in which they present reports.

The Government's position is really to impose further costs on industry by imposing a further impost on wages. The timing of such an imposition could not have been worse—in the middle of a recession. At the lowest level, the superannuation regime represents the loss of one job in 30 mathematically. With so many businesses operating at such a low level of activity and profitability, this change certainly will cost jobs.

I suppose one surprising feature arising from the appearance of witnesses representing the disadvantaged and the welfare groups was the total lack of consultation by Government with this important section of the community. I wish to state that all groups so represented in these categories believe that the low income earners of Australian society, certainly in the short term and as a result of this legislation, will be worse off. I think this is indeed regrettable. So there are problems with this whole regime which Senator Alston and I outlined in our extensive minority report, in that this superannuation guarantee levy is built on an inequitable foundation. Therefore it will tend to exacerbate poverty and hardship, certainly in the short term. But in the short term it will not lead to an efficient investment and it will have a definite bias towards one form of saving.

I think overall the Senate inquiry demonstrated how inequitable and abysmal superannuation is in Australia. Certainly, the problem with the current regime is that relatively few people will be able to get a significant superannuation benefit on retirement. The guarantee charge, which comes from an industry agenda of the ACTU, is not based on social security type considerations. I find it surprising that this should come from an Australian Labor Party.

The evidence was overwhelming that jobs will be shed in huge numbers and that more businesses, especially small and marginal ones, will be forced to the wall. The charge will certainly have an impact in that it will deepen the recession. The levy is an attempt to make employers pick up the tab for the ageing population in Australia. Employees will not be required to make the slightest contribution. It is not until we reach something like 9 per cent that there is some suggestion that there may be some trade-off in terms of tax or that some contribution will be required from the employee. In other words, it is just another tax on an already overtaxed and overregulated nation.

In addition to the job shedding and the business failures that the levy will create, there will be an increasing trend towards the use of small contractors at the expense of the bulk of the Australian paid work force which operates under the PAYE system. There will be situations in which many contractors and their employees will still be outside of the scope and intentions of the legislation.

Undoubtedly, the legislation will impact severely on many sections of the community. I think it is regrettable that we could not get an undertaking from Government representatives or the departments associated with welfare that they will top up Government contributions to the welfare agencies which will be caught in the net and have to pay the superannuation levy. That means that less money will be available for the essential welfare agencies.

I urge Government senators to ensure that the disadvantaged and the welfare groups in Australia do not suffer any loss in terms of the real value of Government assistance as a result of the imposition of this levy. It is important that Government members especially put pressure on the Government to ensure that the real value of Government contributions to welfare groups in Australia is maintained. Certainly, it appears from the evidence given that in the short term there will be a loss of benefits to the welfare lobby as a result of this legislation.

The impact on the States is similarly a matter of concern. Never before have I heard the States speak in such unison as they are doing in their comments against this levy. Some State parliaments which are in recess at the moment will have to enact retrospective legislation to cover certain types of schemes. I think this is unfortunate.

The Government's stated intention is to reduce the massive social security pay-out which it has itself created. Mr Dawkins says that self-provision will mean an increase in the flexibility of the Government's Budget in future years, especially as our population ages. But, in a sense, that is not really a true statement. This provision is required to be made by the employers. The compulsory 3 per cent levy that has been written into awards in the industrial arena was not based on productivity increases and was not off-set against wage increases—it was a further cost imposition. The superannuation levy will make Australian industry much less competitive.

The training guarantee levy and the superannuation guarantee levy are two recent examples of government imposed costs on business. Surprisingly, the new sales tax simplification arrangements will impose further costs on business and make business less and less competitive. The Liberal-National coalition's Fightback proposal is centred on creating more jobs. Certainly, the bias might be one of taking costs off business. But in doing this, we will reduce the level of unemployment. We will increase the number of people who are engaged in productive full time work.

Under Fightback, we will reduce very significantly the taxes that apply to individuals—in terms of individual tax rates and the tax threshold at which people begin to pay tax. But most importantly, we will be taking off business those additional costs that this Government and other governments have imposed—costs that have made businesses uncompetitive and not able to compete on world markets. We now have a situation in which there is massive unemployment.

But even in the face of massive costs to business, the Government will save very little because there has been no attempt to address the problem of double dipping which allows retirees to spend their superannuation entitlement and then apply for the pension. So, maybe, people are being denied wage increases at a time when they most need the money. Low income earners in particular need money at a time when they are struggling to buy their homes and educate their children. People will certainly give priority to assisting their children—to giving them the best possible education. But if they are to be denied an adequate income or security of employment, they will not be in as strong a position to give their children a sound education and security. So the long term implications mean that this is not `clever type country' legislation. People will make some sacrifice now to get some sort of benefit. People in their fifties will be encouraged to take a trip around the world.

What do people really want to do? I guarantee that the majority of Australians would prefer to have that money so that they can educate their children at a critical time of their life. This is particularly the case with low income earners. The problem with this legislation is that it will enable retirees to spend their superannuation and then apply for the pension. So the timing of this legislation in terms of its introduction and its implementation could not have been worse. I think it is incumbent on the Government to improve the benefits that will accrue from the superannuation guarantee charge and to find a system under which double dipping will be stopped and eliminated.

Most of the contributions that will be made by employers on behalf of people on the lowest incomes will be swallowed up in administration and other costs. Some of these costs are quite outrageous. I must draw attention to the fact that the taxation system in terms of the contribution levy and earnings is somewhat confused. The treatment of tax is not equitable across the board. The tax treatment in respect of an employee entering one fund may not be equivalent to that in another fund. I think it is important that the Government address this issue. Certainly, I will be bringing this to the Committee's attention when it is considering its third report.

The Treasury estimates in relation to the level of savings are also flawed. This was the subject of some heated debate between Treasury officials, particularly Mr Cole who was clawed in at the last minute and obviously had not had time to read some of the answers that were given by other members of Treasury.

The estimates are flawed on the basis of failing to recognise the amount of time that families spend outside the work force, and in terms of the lump sum $30,000 dissipation level, because it will be substantially higher. In fact, I think it is incumbent on Treasury to provide this Parliament with a lot more information to establish the link between savings and the superannuation guarantee levy.

When we look at the analysis fairly closely, we find that it is not until the end of the scheme, towards the year 2000, that there is any significant level in terms of the overall impact on savings. Certainly, it will channel some types of funds into certain activities. But this raises the question of the national interest and the availability of those moneys, particularly to small business, and particularly to those small businesses that are struggling and could well be pushed over the brink.

Let me give some examples of job shedding in terms of evidence given to the Committee. David Jones (Australia) Pty Ltd, employing 100,000 people, said that in the event of a 2 per cent increase in costs it would have no choice but to reduce employee numbers. That sort of sentiment was also expressed by the Coles-Myer Group. So if we are talking about 3 per cent, increasing to 12 per cent, it does not take a mathematical genius to work out that that represents 1,200 jobs with one company over the eight years specified for the implementation of the levy. There is no doubt that this is representative of the impact nationwide. There will be a massive increase in terms of job shedding. The Confederation of Australian Industry has estimated that the effect of the levy will be to put at risk between 45,000 and 60,000 jobs.

The Government continually talks about the economy's capacity to pay. I put this to you, Mr Acting Deputy President: what about individual businesses' capacity to pay, and individuals' capacity to employ people, especially in these stringent times when it is necessary to employ more people, not fewer?

The coalition is concerned, in opposing this legislation, about the whole Australian economy, particularly the employment generating sector—small business. Again, I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that Fightback has a different approach. It is designed to increase employment. It is designed to reduce substantially those numbers that are unemployed.

I mentioned that double dipping will continue, and at certain levels the scheme will cost more than it will save. That is probably why Treasury has not been able to analyse it, or perhaps it is because Treasury has been too busy analysing Fightback. But at least the Fightback proposal has positive elements—something which is lacking in this legislation which is the subject of evaluation by this Committee.

I think it is unfortunate that the Government did not wait until this Senate Select Committee report on superannuation was completed so that at least it could have had the overall picture. It would have been better if this legislation—the four superannuation guarantee Bills that will be before the Senate shortly—could have been examined in a better, less pressured atmosphere in the Budget session of parliament.

I put it to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the reason for the rush is that the Government knows its time is running out. Its accord with the ACTU and the imperatives of the 1993 election require the scheme to be in place urgently. But the scheme represents another tax on a population heavily burdened by taxation and regulation. The Government is providing the coalition with the opportunity to say to the nation that there will now be eight taxes which it will have to remove, instead of the seven outlined in Fightback. I look forward to the continued debate when the Bills come before the Parliament. I hope there will be substantive amendments to the Bills as proposed, arising from this very important inquiry on superannuation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the report of the Select Committee on Superannuation into the provisions of the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992. I will be brief because, as Senator Watson has said, this legislation will be before us shortly.

PARA.TAB: I would like to congratulate the members of the Committee. It was one of those committees dealing with legislation in which each of the parties had a distinctly different view. It is always very difficult to deal with matters in such a situation. I think the Committee behaved very well under those circumstances. I must disagree with Senator Watson, however, by pointing out that he is confusing the role of an ordinary select committee dealing with an issue and a select committee dealing with legislation. Because of its very nature, a committee dealing with legislation, working against a timetable, cannot do some of the things that an ordinary select committee with unlimited time would do.
