I do not intend to go into a great deal of detail. I congratulate the staff of the Committee who were thrown together to face a most difficult and complex subject and have served the Committee particularly well.

I want to refer very briefly to a couple of things that Senator Watson said. I note that the Whip is looking at me so I will be very brief. Senator Watson talked about double dipping. The double dipping issue has not yet been proved. It cannot be asserted that people are going on world trips and doing other things. I believe there is a certain urban myth that the Opposition has picked up in this regard. There is not yet any proof. I believe it is possible that that could happen, but it is also true that the vast majority of people facing retirement use their money in a sensible way. Sometimes that sensible way is to pay off part of their house mortgage or to buy their house. At other times it is to convert that lump sump payment into an annuity. There are a number of things that can happen. The truth is that the jury is still out. I would prefer to wait for the inquiry that the Department of Social Security is making so that we can have real facts.

That is the problem with the Opposition. The Opposition and employers are always against change and are always against progress. In this particular case the employers' organisations all said when award superannuation came in that the time was not right and that we should wait until legislation came in. When legislation has come in, the employers have opposed it. The Opposition, of course, as their voice, has also opposed it. Those are the simple facts and that is the situation we face. I will wait until later to deal with the other matters that Senator Watson and his colleagues have raised.
Debate (on motion by Senator Bjelke-Petersen) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE FUNDING) BILL 1992COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE) PAYROLL LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1992COAL MINING INDUSTRY (LONG SERVICE LEAVE) PAYROLL LEVY BILL 1992STATES GRANTS (COAL MINING INDUSTRY LONG SERVICE LEAVE) AMENDMENT BILL 1992COAL RESEARCH ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1992COAL TARIFF LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992COAL INDUSTRY AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating cognately seven Bills relating to the great coal industry in Australia. I would like to echo the views of a colleague of mine in the other place. Mr Fischer, the honourable member for Farrer and shadow Minister for Resources, made the point that it really is an appalling situation that debate on seven amending Bills relating to the coal industry is limited because of the guillotine. The fact that this debate is being limited within the Senate to one hour shows the lack of interest of this Government in export industries and employment in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Coal is an export orientated industry without which, quite frankly, Australia would be bankrupt. I cannot put that in plainer terms; it is something that our friends the Australian Democrats should take on board. It is an industry with which I am proud to have been associated for over 20 years. It is also an industry in which just about everyone knows everyone else. It has been my pleasure to count as friends a broad spectrum of people in the industry, whether they be gardeners, bulldozer drivers, engineers—civil, electrical, mining and mechanical—geologists or union officials. In fact, at some time in the future a tribute must be paid to some of the great pioneers of this wonderful industry. They are a great bunch who historically have been under attack by people such as Mr Whitlam and the renowned R.F.X. Connor of the Labor Government of the 1970s and, more recently, by the lunatic fringe dwellers in the Green movement.

Coal is an essential ingredient throughout the world in electricity generation and in the production of steel, cement and chemicals. As a component in the generation of electricity, it is indirectly involved in the production of aluminium and other products.

The coal industry is not commonly understood. There are some 50 or more varieties of coal. Broadly, coal can be divided into two categories: coking and steaming. Australia mines some 160 million tonnes of coal per annum and exports around 120 million tonnes, which is worth in excess of $6 billion—$6,000m—to the Australian economy. Coal is our largest single export earner.Having said that, we must keep this contribution in perspective. Compared with the United States and China, the production from our mines pales into insignificance. According to figures that I saw some years ago, the United States mines approximately 800 million tonnes of coal per annum.

I recently met with mainland China's vice-Minister for coal. He advised me that mainland China currently mines 1,000 million tonnes of coal, which satisfies 75 per cent of that country's electricity generation requirements. Because of the increased demand for electricity in China, it is planned to increase the production of coal in China to 1.4 billion tonnes per annum over the next few years. Honourable senators should compare that with Australia's total coal production of 160 million tonnes per annum.

The Australian Democrats, particularly Senator Coulter, and Mrs Kelly give the impression that the world relies on Australia for its supply of coking and steaming coal. This was the same crazy notion held by the Whitlam Government in the 1970s, led by the mentor of the current Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the late Mr R.F.X. Connor. Mr Connor went down the resource diplomacy path, ruthlessly bucketing both the Americans who had invested here and the major Japanese buyers. Looking back, I say without equivocation that that stupidity might have won a few political nationalistic brownie points at the time but it cost this country dearly—it cost us thousands of millions in export dollars.

I could not help but notice a report in the Australian Financial Review of a week or so ago, which stated that the current Prime Minister urged his troops `to get angry'. In a passionate speech to the Labor Caucus, Mr Keating told his members of parliament that the first lesson he learnt from his mentor, Mr Rex Connor, when he entered politics was always to remember that `we hate the Liberals'.

Mr Connor, whom I met on many occasions, could be best described as hating just about everybody. I do not recall him ever publicly saying a kind word about anyone in those few years that he was in power and did so much damage to a growing industry. In fact, looking back, I would have to say that he was a sad figure who made a lot of noise, insulted a lot of decent people, achieved nothing and was ultimately dismissed by Prime Minister Whitlam for his role in the infamous Khemlani affair. Some mentor!—although the attraction of one for the other is understandable.

Let us look at the Bills. The purpose of the Coal Industry Amendment Bill 1992 is to amend the Coal Industry Act 1946 and to reform the powers and functions of the Joint Coal Board. This is a step in the right direction. Therefore, we will not oppose it, although we will be moving a second reading amendment.

The Opposition agrees with the recommendations of the Industry Commission that the continued existence of the Joint Coal Board is not justified, and we will move to abolish the board when we are in government. The board is anachronistic in every sense of the word. It was set up in 1946 by the Minister for Postwar Reconstruction to control the New South Wales coal industry. The major reason for this was the actions of militant trade union leaders who had no hesitation in pulling on strikes willy-nilly, notwithstanding the grim war situation between 1941 and 1945. This was not a great success, as evidenced by Prime Minister Ben Chifley putting troops in to operate the coal mines in 1949.

The coal industry is steeped in tradition, with the miners union having a vested interest in perpetuating a false `them and us' position. Thankfully, in recent years, with more enlightened leadership—mainly from John Maitland—there is more of an awareness that the Australian coal mines are competing with the rest of the world and that the future of the coal industry depends on real increases in productivity. Regrettably, I must say that although in the last couple of years we have had something like a 2 or 3 per cent increase in productivity within the coal mines—certainly in New South Wales—wage increases have been of the order of 9 per cent. This is unsustainable for an industry that is relying on exports markets.

The Joint Coal Board is a hangover from the past. There have been attempts—from memory, as far back as 1976—to remove the board. I do not know why it continues. This Bill certainly reduces its duties. The board was introduced at a time when there was really only one coal producer in Australia, and that was New South Wales. If one looks at the terms of reference of the board, one will see that it talks about maintaining adequate coal supplies for Australia and the world. In those days, there were no real coal mines in Queensland or even in Western Australia. I was heavily involved in the growth of the coal mines in the Bowen Basin. These mines have had a great impact since the late 1960s.

The purpose of the Coal Research Assistance Amendment Bill 1992, which the Opposition's supports, is to transfer coal research and development from a government run system to an industry funded and managed scheme. Australia is in a fortunate position in respect of its coal deposits. That is the key thing. Time and again we are told that a particular Australian industry is the most efficient industry in the world. How many times do we all hear that said about a particular industry, whether it be coal, sugar or anything else?

If that is the case, one has to question why we have this balance of payments deficit that grows bigger and bigger year in and year out. The point that I make is that in many instances, as with the coal industry, we are blessed with having one of the best deposits in the world, but not necessarily the most efficient industry in the world. I do not say that with any sense of malice. It is simply to draw people's attention to the fact that we could become much more efficient if permitted to do so.

But the growth of the industry depends on the use of latest technologies and on ongoing research. If this industry is to develop, that is a must. The sharing of information gained by companies is a feature of the coal industry. Even though on the export market these companies are competitive, they are only too happy to share information on new developments and programs with each other. I think that is very important.

The other day in here I heard Senator Coulter from the Australian Democrats actually arguing that we should reduce the amount of research that we undertake on coal. Here is our greatest export industry, one that has the potential for growth and where the demand appears to be continuing, and we have people such as Senator Coulter saying, `Cut back on research'. I hope that he reads the information that I gave earlier about where Australia was going and how we fit into the total world scene—we account for 160 million tonnes of production compared with the United States at 800 million and China at 1 billion and growing to 1.4 billion. So let us keep it in perspective. We do not have a monopoly on world supplies of coal; nowhere near it. In fact, our exports are about 10 per cent of the total of American coal production.

Mrs Kelly, in her profound announcements, made it perfectly clear that she did not know the difference between sulphur and carbon. One of the good things about Australian coal is that it happens to be low in sulphur compared with Northern Hemisphere coals. She said that it is great because we will not really have any effect on pollution because we have coal that will not contribute to the greenhouse effect. She did not really know the difference between sulphur and carbon. To have an environment Minister who does not know the difference between sulphur and carbon is outrageous—it makes you worry.

I refer people such as Mrs Kelly and Senator Coulter to today's Sydney Morning Herald in which there is an excellent article by Julie Lambert in Tokyo about where our coal industry is going and what the Japanese are doing. Senator Coulter was in here some weeks ago complaining about the Japanese and their handling of the environment. I asked him whether he had been to Japan and he said no and that he did not intend to go there—which is a nice open mind from someone who purports to lead a political party in Australia! I suggested that if he went to Japan he would see that substantial improvements have occurred in Japan over the last few years. I just draw his attention to one particular paragraph in Julie Lambert's article which says:

SPEECH.PARA: A world leader in clean coal technology, Japan records substantial exports to other advanced countries of equipment to remove sulphur and nitrogen oxides from coal emissions.
The technical words used are `Nox' for nitrogen oxide and `Sox' for sulphur oxides. It also says:
Gasification, involving the use of coal-derived hydrogen, is expected to form the core of coal-fired power systems in the next century.

So the article the goes on. I will not go into any more detail on it. It is absolutely vital that coal research continue. Australian companies in the coal industry have a good record. In fact, they have basically funded it through the 5c a tonne levy. That will continue but, instead of bureaucrats determining where those funds go, it will now be determined by the industry itself, and we support that.

PARA.TAB: There are four Bills involved with the long service leave amendments. These Bills change the method of funding long service leave from a rate per tonne basis to a percentage of payroll. Quite clearly, the former method was inequitable in that the capital intensive open cut operations were funding the long service leave of the labour intensive underground mines. Notwithstanding the levy, which raised about $32m a year, the current fund is underfunded to the tune of about $300m.

People forget that long service leave in the coal industry falls due every eight years. It was a give-away at a time of some affluence in Australia, like a lot of these work practices that are now being addressed in a range of industries. When we add to that the wage rates, which are by far the highest in Australia, the figure becomes a fairly high impost, which now falls back on the underground mines. But that is where it should be and, even though it is a step in the right direction and one that we will not oppose, I have to say that it is absolutely ridiculous that one of the better industries in Australia has a centralised system of determining long service leave when long service leave should be paid by the companies who employ the people who work for them.

I comment briefly on comments made in the other place by Mr Peter Morris, the Labor member for Shortland. The only reason I want to comment is that remarks continue to be made about the coal industry which would indicate that the people making them either live in the last century in the days of How Green Was My Valley or they have a vested political interest in pursuing the idea of a them and us situation, not recognising the fact that we have a highly technological industry. No longer do people crawl in little caverns with picks and shovels. We have long-wall miners, underground mines, open cut mines, drag lines, trucks and shovels and so on. So it is a sophisticated industry. Mr Morris made some remarks with regard to marketing. He said:
As long as we have in this country a disorganised, fragmented selling basis, as we now have, and as long as our largest customer—

SPEECH.PARA: he did not say whom, but everyone knows that our largest customer is Japan—
who buys over 50 per cent of our coal—is buying on an organised, highly regimented buying basis, we will be exploited. . .
That is the sort of language one expects to hear from Third World countries. It is utterly wrong.

PARA.TAB: I was involved in the marketing of coal to Japan for something like 15 years. The facts are that the prices obtained by people in the coal market are market prices—the market determines the price. This business of whether there is a fragmented selling basis is nonsense. If it were true, why is it that every coal company in Australia, if given the choice, would prefer to sell its coal to Japan? The reason is that they get the best prices in Japan. They also get ships turning up on a regular basis, and, once you have made that long term arrangement, that relationship, with the Japanese, it is one that both can trust and it is to the benefit of both parties. This notion is a phoney thing that was spread around back in the 1970s by the then Minister, Mr Connor, whom I referred to earlier, and it did us a lot of damage because it forced the Japanese to diversify some of their markets into Canada because they were worried about this so-called resource diplomacy at that time. Mr Morris also said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australian producer competes against Australian producer to the benefit of external purchaser.

That is another phoney myth. He further talks about mines that shut down. Mines shut down; they will always shut down. Whether it is coal, iron ore, or anything else that is being mined, it is a definable resource. The continuation of a mine depends on the cost of recovering that resource.

PARA.TAB: That cost can be affected by a number of things. It can be affected by work practices. It can be affected by government charges. They are by far the most damaging because they are charges over which producers have no control. The cost can be affected by the market. It can also be affected by the exchange rates. A range of things can affect the continued operation or closure of a mine.

We see Mr Morris running down this track and saying that the reason these things shut down from time to time is the `rip it out and sell it to the first bidder' approach. That is a slur on people who are marketing around the world. There are good marketers in Australia. They are as good as anywhere in the world, and they are out to maximise their price. Mr Morris talks about the greed of companies. I have yet to see a company that did not take a long term view with any of its resources. It will balance off its cheaper mine operations with its more expensive ones to prolong the life of the mine. It is in the interests of the companies to do that.

The only time I ever saw high-grading come into a mining operation was when we had the silly former Prime Minister go over to Western Australia and say, `In two years time we are going to introduce a gold tax'. That gave producers a two-year notice to go out and high-grade. That is not normal. It is a very abnormal situation.

The predictions made, for instance, in the early 1970s by the Labor Party that the nasty multinationals—one does not hear that word much these days—were going to rip the best of it out, clear out and leave the worst to Australia have not been fulfilled. The mines that it predicted would have five- and 10-year lives are there after 20-odd years and probably have another 20-odd years to go.

This is a subject on which we could have a grand debate. It is a great industry. It is our biggest export industry. It is a great pity that debate is limited because this Government saw fit to bring in a range of Bills at the last moment and put a guillotine on us. It put a guillotine on the House of Representatives and we are also subject to a one-hour guillotine in this place.

I will conclude, because I know a few of my colleagues who come from coalmining areas would like to say a few words on this matter. In relation to the Coal Tariff Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:
(a)notes that the Government has adopted in the Bill one of the seven key tax abolition planks of `Fightback'; and
(b)calls on the Government to implement the other six key abolition planks of `Fightback', among them being the abolition of payroll tax, sales tax and fuel excise tax".
In relation to the Coal Industry Amendment Bill 1992, I move:
At end of motion, add ", but the Senate:
(a)notes that this legislation is complementary to legislation of the New South Wales Parliament; and

(b)calls on the Federal Government to negotiate with the New South Wales Government with a view to abolishing the Joint Coal Board and transferring the occupational and health and other key components to industry managed bodies".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill and related Bills because they have a particular relevance to the industry at the heart of my own area, the city of Newcastle and the Hunter Valley. The Senate is fortunate to have Senator Parer speak on this Bill. He is our shadow Minister and before coming to the Senate was one of the leaders in the coal industry in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: Today, I would like to give a Hunter perspective. The Hunter produces approximately 70 per cent of the output of coal in New South Wales. Coal is overwhelmingly the dominant export that goes through the port of Newcastle. More than 90 per cent of the tonnage that goes through Newcastle is coal. It is easy to see, therefore, the importance that coal has to our Hunter region. It is also easy to see that changes to the coal industry will have a profound effect on the lifestyle of many people in the Hunter who depend on this industry for a living.

Coal is Australia's biggest export earner—$9 billion per year. The industry has the potential for even more if we can legislate properly so that the infrastructure of the industry is in place to allow it to give more. There are plenty of opportunities for further export dollars, but we have to ensure that this industry increases its competitiveness and that it stays highly competitive.

Currently, our wage costs are growing at twice the rate of productivity in the industry and our production is not growing nearly as fast as that of our major competitors. With the right economic conditions and incentives, new coalmines could be developed across New South Wales, particularly in the Hunter Valley and the Gunnedah areas. This would contribute enormously to our export potential and ultimately be of benefit to all Australians.

Costs have to be kept to an absolute minimum. Some of the measures in these Bills before the Senate contribute to keeping costs as low as possible. Some of the measures do not go far enough in circumstances that can only be described as typical of this Government, a government that has run out of steam and lacks vision to carry out the reforms that are necessary.

However, the Government is to be congratulated on repealing the coal export duty in accordance with the coalition's Fightback policy. The coal export duty was imposed in the mid-1970s to take profits from the coal exporters in the wake of the oil price shocks. This can no longer be justified. It has distorted investment decisions in the coal industry and acted as a tax on exports.

Another measure that is contained in these Bills is the reform of the Joint Coal Board. This is an example of a measure where the Government simply does not go far enough. When the Joint Coal Board was set up in 1946 it was to ensure that the coal produced in New South Wales was in such quantities that it could meet the trade and domestic demands of the nation. It was also set up to promote the welfare of the workers in the industry. Extensive powers were given to this particular body. As Senator Parer mentioned, it was established after World War II. Obviously, the industry has undergone dramatic changes since that time.

The Joint Coal Board is the classic example of a quango that has long outlived its usefulness to the industry. The Bill before the Senate reforms the Joint Coal Board, but keeps it in existence to perform four tasks that could be easily performed more efficiently by other government instrumentalities already in existence, or better still by the private sector. These functions are to administer the coal industry workers compensation scheme, the coalminers occupational health and rehabilitation service; to collect and collate accident and industry statistics; and to undertake coal promotion and market development activities.
The Opposition believes that the board should be abolished. The Industry Commission agrees. The Commission concludes in its examination of the JCB:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the perceived uniqueness of the Australian Coal Industry has meant that it has become subject to a wide range of government inventions. Many of them have no counterparts in other industries. The Commission considers there is little evidence to suggest that the extra degree of regulation is successful. The removal of all impediments, including unnecessary regulations is essential to allow the industry to become more efficient and internationally competitive.

The Commission's conclusion largely agrees with that of the Australian Coal Association and the New South Wales Coal Association. Thus it can be clearly seen that the Government has failed to take the decisions necessary to put the coal industry firmly on the path to economic recovery so that it can achieve its potential. If it had done what was necessary it would have completely abolished the Joint Coal Board and distributed its functions to other government instrumentalities.

PARA.TAB: In the very brief time available, I have been able to point out that once again the Government has failed. It has undertaken half hearted reform. It has adopted some of the Opposition's Fightback package. But this lack of decisiveness is a sign of a government that is on its last legs. It is unfortunate that in this case the people who suffer most from this fault of the Government are the people of my region, the people of Newcastle and the Hunter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Coal Mining Industry (Long Service Leave Funding) Bill 1992 and related Bills. In the very short time available under the guillotine, I wish to make some brief comments about an industry that is very important to my State of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I support the amendments moved by the Opposition and express concern as to the effect of those aspects of this legislation that deal with long service leave in the coalmining industry. It is of concern to me that as a bottom line the Griffin Coal Mining Co. of Western Australia will be required to pay an additional $400,000 on top of the $500,000 it already pays by way of this levy.

I do not know how long this Government can go on putting additional costs onto the private sector at the expense of jobs. It is not in the long term interests of the Australian economy and ultimately of its employees that this Government continually formulates legislation that raises business costs. Businesses cannot cope with it any longer and therein lies the difference between what this Government is doing and what we as a coalition are proposing in our Fightback! document. We are taking $20m of costs off business and this Government, through almost every piece of legislation that we are seeing come before us now, is putting costs on business.

I have before me a media release from the New South Wales Coal Association, dated 17 June 1992, which quite clearly says that the impact of the superannuation guarantee levy on the coal industry in New South Wales will cost it another $17m per annum. How much further can we go? Extra costs are all the more unwelcome when businesses are to be slugged by the Labor and Democrats superannuation levy that was revealed yesterday. It cannot be allowed to continue. We should recall that this kind of levy arrangement does not exist for other aspects of mining such as the iron ore industry. I might add that I am not advocating that it should. We no longer live in the 1940s and I do not consider that there is any case for the general regulation of the coal industry by this Parliament. I wish that this Parliament and this Government would get out of dabbling in business instead of constantly getting into it.

I do not believe that it is being parochial to raise the point that since 1984-85 the Griffin Coal Mining Co. has contributed $1m more than it has drawn from the fund, and can claim with some justice that it will be further called upon to subsidise arrangements in the New South Wales coal industry. The extension of the definition of `eligible employees' in referring to the operations of the mine `wherever they are carried out' is going to bring head office as well as the mine site employees into the provisions of the legislation and thus increase the costs to the company. I fail to be convinced as to the need for any kind of centralised corporation to administer long service leave, as the principle should hold good as far as possible that individual companies should be responsible for the employment conditions of their own work force. There is no guarantee that the voice of the coal industry in Western Australia will be effectively heard—and this Government is making sure that that is so. We can with confidence look forward to a new and different approach to industrial relations from the next Liberal-National Party government, under which enterprises and their employees will have the freedom of choice to determine rewards and conditions of work.

Underground coalmining operations such as we have in Western Australia will be at a cost disadvantage through the levy compared with, for example, major Queensland producers where the use of draglines reduces the need for work force numbers. Has this Government taken that into consideration? I doubt it. Does it care? I know it does not.

It is a fact that, under these centralised arrangements for the administration of long service leave in the coal industry, all companies will, in effect, be paying according to the most generous long service leave arrangements that pertain to the industry. Now that head office employees entitled to long service leave after 15 years are included with mine site employees, whose leave is due after eight years, a levy per employee is simply not equitable.

There is absolutely no incentive for any individual company to negotiate with its work force for some possible reduction in generous long service leave provisions—reductions that may be acceptable to the individual work forces as part of general agreements. It is this kind of centralised arrangement, casually put forward by this Labor Government, that spokes the wheels of moves towards real enterprise agreements. The Government puts it forward so casually, hoping to high heaven that the industry itself will not notice, and that the particular sections of the industry that are more seriously affected than others will not take a keen interest. That is not so. The industry is particularly concerned about the impact of it.

Employees as well as employers will be the winners when a new industrial relations system replaces the current higgledy-piggledy, anomalous system that we have, which has constantly been put forward by Senator Cook, the `Minister for unemployment'. We must certainly make sure that we in the Opposition give the public a full understanding of the options that we are promoting; namely, an option for working conditions to go back to where they belong, at the individual enterprise.
Amendments negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992SOCIAL SECURITY (FAMILY PAYMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a great deal I would like to say about the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. It is a large Bill and it contains changes of importance for the veterans' community. Yet today I can reasonably take only 10 minutes to address the issues raised by it. While the Opposition will be supporting the Bill, it is an absolute disgrace that, both here in the Senate and last month in the House of Representatives, debate on this legislation has been restricted to what will be an effective sum total of 10 minutes in each chamber.

PARA.TAB: The Government should be condemned in the strongest possible terms for its complete failure to properly manage its legislative program. The Democrats should be equally condemned. Every time they support the Government in guillotining legislation, they further undermine what little credibility they still possess. Veterans and war widows will judge for themselves the actions of the Government and the Democrats in restricting debate on these matters of concern to veterans. They should ask themselves whether it is a reflection of the attitude of the Government and of the Democrats to our veterans and war widows.

One of the inevitable consequences of rushing through legislation in this way is that the Government, in the next session, will try to correct its mistakes. Indeed, in the Bill before us there is an important provision correcting what the Government says is a mistake in legislation it rushed through at the end of 1990. This Bill will allow certain defence personnel, who revoked their entitlements to benefits under the Defence Service Homes Act in favour of benefits under the new housing scheme, to withdraw their revocation and regain eligibility under the Defence Service Homes Act.

This provision has been introduced in response to the Government belatedly accepting an AAT decision that a service couple, each with an entitlement to a subsidised housing loan, may pool their entitlements for the same home. The Government claimed that this was due to a drafting error in earlier legislation which opened a loophole. The Government did not announce its acceptance of pooling until just before the end of the period last year in which those with a DSH entitlement were allowed the option of revoking their entitlement and taking up one under the new defence housing assistance scheme.

Consequently, many who revoked their DSH entitlement did so in the belief that they could not combine their entitlements under the old scheme. It was only the persistence of the Opposition that finally forced the Government to recognise its obligations to service couples. I should say for the record that, in the end, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs took a unilateral decision on this after he found no support from the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Mr Bilney). It is disgraceful that the Minister of State appointed to oversee the conditions of service for our service personnel was so unwilling to recognise their rights with respect to defence service housing loans.

The arrangements introduced in the present Bill represent an added administrative burden that the Government should have avoided by more quickly accepting that pooling of DSH entitlements is possible under the Act. A very important provision in the Bill is to allow Australian Defence Force personnel serving in Cambodia, as part of the United Nations peacekeeping effort, access to repatriation benefits, including the service pension, and disability and death compensation, at the more generous standard of proof. The amendment will commence on 20 October 1991, since this was the date on the advice of the Department of Defence that ADF personnel first served in Cambodia.

At some point—probably the UN ceasefire—service in Cambodia will become peacekeeping service. Such service allows access to disability and death compensation at the more generous standard of proof, but does not allow access to service pensions and associated benefits. This Bill also provides that Army Reservists, if they are called on to serve in Cambodia, will be entitled to the same benefits as those available to full time members of the regular defence forces. In this context, yesterday in the Senate, the Opposition successfully moved an amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992, ensuring that Parliament, and not the Government, will decide when Cambodia is no longer an operational area for the purpose of the tax treatment of allowances.

I also remarked yesterday that events in Cambodia are very fluid. Recent developments, where the Khmer Rouge have been refusing to meet their obligations under the UN peace plan, are cause for great concern. The climate in Cambodia is not stable and, while our troops are perfectly able to meet the demands placed on them, they must be reassured that benefits which are rightly due to them, like the tax exemption, will be continued until Cambodia is made safe, not just until there is some artificially declared ceasefire.

Other important provisions in the Bill which the coalition supports include changes from a telephone voucher to a telephone allowance and increased telephone concessions for World War I veterans. There are also beneficial changes to the assets test for veterans who are farmers and for veterans who may wish to enter into sale lease-back arrangements on their homes.

I would like to conclude by commenting on two further changes contained in the Bill. The first is the removal of the statutory age limit of 65 years for part time members of the Veterans' Review Board. The removal is not being extended, however, to full time members. An important element of the Fightback plan is the end of compulsory retirement. Compulsory retirement is a waste of valuable human resources and reduces individual self-fulfilment. It seems that the removal of the statutory age limit is not being extended to full time members of the VRB because Cabinet so far has only given approval for the removal of the limit for part time statutory positions. Cabinet certainly has no excuse not to act decisively on this issue.

In the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, Expectations for Life, presented to the Parliament in April, two important recommendations regarding compulsory retirement are made. The first is that the Commonwealth Government abolish compulsory age-related retirement in the Public Service and other Commonwealth employment areas. The second is that the Minister for Industrial Relations review industrial relations Acts and awards so that discrimination based on age is removed, and so that more flexible working arrangements are possible. The coalition strongly endorses these recommendations and calls on the Government to do the same and to implement them as soon as possible.

The final provision I would like to comment on is the change aimed at streamlining the process for some applications for war widows pensions. Despite automatic entitlement to a war widows/widowers pension and funeral benefits on the death of a veteran in certain circumstances, formal lodgment and determination of applications has been necessary. This will no longer be required. This is a very straightforward amendment for which many war widows will be grateful. It is surprising that it has taken so long for the amendment to be made. While any improvement to the claim system should be supported, I believe that this is a token measure and that it does not go to the heart of the problems with the determining system.

This weekend I am going to Western Australia to address the Western Australian RSL State Congress. In that State, the real problems with the determining system are starkly highlighted by the fact that in 1990-91 the Veterans' Review Board overturned a massive 72 per cent of the Repatriation Commission's disability assessment decisions. The Government concedes that the real problems lie at the first level of the claims system, but it is doing nothing of substance to deal with these problems. Veterans and war widows everywhere are rightly concerned at the inefficiencies, the legalities and the adversarial nature of the present claim system. They know that change is necessary.

As was outlined in the Fightback proposals last November, the coalition intends to take positive action to fix these problems, with a central change being to include ex-service input into the decision-making progress at the first level. This will be done by establishing two-member claims panels to consider claims, with one of the members being a nominee of the ex-service community. I believe that the benefits of this system will be a closer working relationship between Government and veterans, with ex-service involvement at the first level of the determining system; increased flexibility and timeliness at the first level, with claims being decided closer to where the veteran lives; and the likelihood of a decrease in the number of appeals over and above the natural decline due to greater veteran satisfaction and confidence with a more transparently equitable system. There will also be a reduction in legal and bureaucratic costs. Of course, the coalition intends to be in constant consultation with veterans' organisations to ensure that the changes are made in the most sensible and timely manner.

I would like to conclude by reaffirming the coalition's support for the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. For once it appears that legislation is being passed where the Government is not seeking to erode veterans' entitlements. I regret that I do not have more time to spend on the substance of the Bill, but we have the Government and the Democrats, and their guillotine, to thank for that.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall begin where Senator Newman left off, with regard to the limited time we have today. We would have had a lot more time for this Bill if the Liberal Party had not spent day after day on the Appropriations and if we had not had so many other interruptions to the program—in particular, the habit Liberal senators now have of moving to take note of Ministers' answers after Question Time, which does not extend beyond the half an hour that seems reasonable but which goes into the hour and the next hour. Indeed, on some occasions we have had 2 1/2 hours of taking note of Ministers' answers, which is a lot more time than we unfortunately have for this Bill.

PARA.TAB: I see another hole in Senator Newman's argument, and that is the fact that she, like the Democrats, has no problem with this Bill. Of course we could sit in here for another two or three hours debating ad nauseam a Bill that we have no problems with, but that hardly seems logical. For once it does not—and I commend the Government for this—erode veterans' entitlements. This is actually a very positive Bill. Indeed, I have had no complaints whatsoever from the veteran community and no requests for amendments, and certainly no requests in any way to hold up this legislation.

I would now like to go on to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill and the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill and the number of policy changes that they implement. I would like to make a few general comments before I look at what is in the Bills. Firstly, the way in which the Government continues to amend the Social Security Act is of great concern to the Democrats. There have now been several major pieces of legislation amending the so-called plain English version of the Social Security Act, but no consolidation of the Act has been printed by the Australian Government Publishing Service since the Act was actually rewritten in 1991. Therefore, the Act is now virtually inaccessible to the Department's clients and their advocates and, I might add, it is pretty clear that some departmental officers now have considerable difficulty finding their way through it. Looking at what we have today, the drafters are also having trouble with it.

Now, without access to specialised services, it is very difficult for people to figure out what their entitlements are, know exactly what they want when they go in and be able to get what they are entitled to. This highlights why it is so important for the Government to fund the welfare rights centres across Australia. Obviously, it defeats the intent and purpose of the plain English version of the Act.

Secondly, social security Bills since 1991 have contained a large number of technical amendments to the schedules, frequently without any accompanying explanation, either in the explanatory notes or the second reading speeches. The Democrats also find this unacceptable. We suggest to the Minister for Social Security (Dr Blewett) that this practice should cease.

In the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill before us now there are over 70 amendments, most of them to schedules, which have a retrospective effect. This is clearly not acceptable. An awful lot of these amendments are needed to correct previous drafting errors or oversights. However, some are substantive. The element of retrospectivity is highly undesirable and causes further confusion to the Department's clients.

Basically, what we have now is a social security area that is a legislative nightmare and a legislative mess. I am not saying that it is an easy mess to amend or clarify, but even so I do not accept, and I do not believe that other senators should accept, the drafting sloppiness and inaccuracies as an excuse for retrospective amendments. There is a way out of this mess. I ask the Minister whether he is willing to consider two measures: firstly, that the Australian Government Publishing Service should consolidate the Social Security Act annually and, secondly, that the Department should agree that there will be only two start-up dates each year. We suggest, for example, 1 July and 1 February, but it would be up to the Department to look at what is more administratively convenient. This would reduce confusion, eliminate the need for retrospectivity and improve access to, and understanding of, the Act. I strongly urge the Minister to take action to remedy the present unacceptable situation. I ask him whether he is prepared to look at those two suggestions.

Turning to the legislation, generally speaking the Democrats are not opposing these Bills. However, I wish to raise three particular concerns. I refer firstly to the Job Search and Newstart training supplements. By way of explanation, these supplements are made up of three components. Firstly, there is a training component. That is a maximum amount of $60 a fortnight to help with direct expenses related to training. Secondly, there is living away from home component. That is a maximum amount of $40 a fortnight for those over the age of 18, and a maximum amount of $30 for those aged under 18. This is to assist with expenses incurred in living away from the person's usual place of residence while actually undertaking the training. The final component is a home-based maintenance component, to a maximum of $75.80 a fortnight, to assist with the expenses of maintaining the person's usual residence while living away from it.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill imposes an age limit on the training component of the supplement, restricting it to persons who have turned 21. This effectively legalises what, in fact, has been carried out illegally for quite some time. It is in line with a 1987 Cabinet decision to equalise youth income support. That has basically meant a progressive reduction in all forms of income support down to a level well below the poverty line.

In effect, the Government has been unlawfully denying those under the age of 21 the training component of this supplement since 1 July last year. It has been caught out, as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal found only last month that there was absolutely no legislative basis for denying young people that allowance. Now the Government faces a pay-out of up to $5m in back payments to those young people who have done training courses over the past year. It is now moving to make sure that the 18-, 19- and 20-year-olds will not be able to get that component in the future.

The Democrats believe that this action is callous and illogical. We note that, despite all the bleatings and comments by members of the Opposition, they are going to support the Government again. I note that Senator Baume has made many speeches in this place, for which I commend him, on the major problems of young people who are unemployed. I appeal again to the Opposition to reconsider what it is now doing—further pushing these young people into poverty.

To argue, as some do, that giving those under the age of 21 access to the component will give them financial incentive to give up long term study and move into short term training courses is a nonsense. It is laughable. Anyone who is seriously running this argument obviously does not have a clue about what is actually going on out there in the real world. Firstly, it is absurd to argue that a young person receiving Austudy and fortunate enough to actually have a place in a university or TAFE will voluntarily relinquish his long term training option to take up a short term training course—which he might not get into anyway, because only about a third of people actually make it—just to get $30 a week. This is not about choice between long term education and short term training. There are simply not enough places in higher education, particularly in the TAFE system, to go around. Those young people who have such places are not going to give them up for the difficulty and uncertainty of unemployment on the off-chance that they may somehow one day end up with an extra $30 a week.

Secondly, removal of the component not only acts as a disincentive for young people to voluntarily undertake training; it actually penalises young people on Job Search allowance who are required by the CES to undertake a training course. Thirdly, the component is not play money. It is used, it is needed, to make sure that the young people can access these training courses and assist them with meeting the additional expenses incurred when undertaking these courses. This effectively means that most, if not all, of the money does not actually see its way into the young person's pocket to buy anything that could even be vaguely considered a luxury. The amount left over, if any, is scarcely enough to be touted as some sort of an incentive for people moving from full time education into these part time courses.

Finally, there are many 18- to 20-year-olds who simply cannot get a place in long term study or training. Why should these young people be denied access to the extra component? They are already far more disadvantaged than their counterparts who are in long term study and who will get a piece of paper at the end of it that actually means something.

In short, the Democrats see no sense in this move at a time of high youth unemployment, when we should be creating opportunities for our young people, not taking those opportunities away from them. We will be opposing these amendments. I make one last appeal to Opposition senators to really demonstrate their support for young unemployed Australians by joining us in the committee stage of this Bill to oppose these moves by the Government.

Our second problem relates to third party consent. There is provision in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill to enable the Department to obtain the consent of third parties to have deductions made from their social security payments in satisfaction of another person's debt to the Department. While I can see a need for this and it may be acceptable to some social security recipients in some circumstances, I seek the Minister's assurance that it will be very clearly set out in the guidelines relating to the provision that the Department will not actively go out pressuring, inviting or requiring spouses or partners to agree on a deduction from their payments for their partner's debt.

My final concern is self-incrimination. The number of calls and material coming into our office would indicate that the changes to the provisions of the Social Security Act relating to self-incrimination have been a cause for considerable concern and confusion. Until now persons required to give information to the Department could not refuse to provide the information on the ground it may tend to incriminate them. These provisions were coupled through the Act with sections stating that information given to the Department pursuant to a notice was not admissible in criminal proceedings and, accordingly, the Department or the Director of Public Prosecutions could not rely on this for prosecution.

The amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill repeal both of these provisions. The effect is supposed to be that information provided under the notice provisions will now be admissible in criminal proceedings. But a person will be able to rely on the common law privilege against self-incrimination and refuse to supply the information in the first instance. There has been considerable confusion about whether the amendments as they are structured will in fact have this effect or whether they will work to the disadvantage of social security recipients.

I am grateful to the Minister for making available to me his letter to the Welfare Rights Centre in Sydney which sets out the Department's arguments about the changes. I accept the argument that the notices used by the Department are not likely to result in a person incriminating himself or herself but could still be used as evidence of fraud in a criminal prosecution. However, the point has been raised with me that there is really no need for the Department to prosecute under the Crimes Act; that the provisions within the Social Security Act are perfectly adequate; and that this change is really directed at the very small number of social security recipients whose fraud is not poverty related.

It seems to me that these changes are not necessary to protect government revenue but the Department is simply adding another string to its bow which it can use if necessary. If that is the case, I ask the Minister for his assurance that it is not his intention to use these changes to prosecute under the Crimes Act the majority of social security recipients whose fraudulent activities could best be termed crimes of poverty.

I also point out to the Minister that, when a confusing and complex change such as this is being mooted, it is desirable to have some solid consultation with key groups and to ensure that the change is adequately explained to these groups. Here again, I highlight the need for the welfare rights centres to be fully involved in these sorts of changes. Lack of consultation on significant changes was a feature of the previous Minister's handling of this portfolio. I would not like to think that such an unacceptable and unsatisfactory practice will continue under the new Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Two of the Bills we are debating today are the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 and the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992. Both of these Bills provide the legislative machinery required to implement a number of relatively minor changes to the social security system which were foreshadowed in the last Federal Budget.

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill provides for the introduction of a telephone allowance for pensioners. After many adverse reports on the telephone voucher system over a number of years, the Government has finally replaced it with an allowance. In 1990, the Auditor-General found that 20 per cent of telephone vouchers did not even relate to telephone accounts held by eligible beneficiaries. So the Opposition supports the Government's attempt to overcome the loopholes inherent in the old telephone voucher system.

This Bill will also implement a number of improvements to current bereavement provisions. These will ensure that the single benefit rate will be paid to the surviving member of a couple from the date of death of the spouse and not from when a claim for the higher rate is lodged, as is currently the case.
Thirdly, the Bill will amend the eligibility criteria for Job Search and Newstart—
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., I call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this matter of public interest debate, I have two such matters that I want to raise. The first concerns the question that I have spoken about both in parliamentary committee hearings and in other places, that is, the concern that many, aside from me, have of the way in which the Australian Taxation Office and the Commissioner of Taxation have chosen to deal with members of political parties. I deal only with matters that are on the record.

PARA.TAB: I deal with a comparison that I have drawn between the way in which Mr Paul Keating, the Prime Minister, who was the Treasurer at the time, was dealt with for failure to lodge his annual tax return—I have tabled in this place a letter asking him in very polite terms whether he would please get it in—and the way in which 10,800-odd Australians were prosecuted in the course of 1990-91 for failure to do the same thing. Clearly, a favour was done for Mr Keating.

On the other hand, I have drawn attention to the treatment of Mr Phillip Smiles, and I have been scrupulous in not commenting on the merits of the case and breaching the sub judice rule. I have simply said that the way that the Office has chosen to prosecute Mr Smiles using the Crimes Act as distinct from the Taxation Administration Act is a political act in that, were a conviction to be obtained and the penalty under the Crimes Act imposed, the Greiner Government would in fact be brought down—a very political action.
Many people have been as incensed as I have been, but now I am even more incensed. I have received from the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions a letter which I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite frankly, I have looked at this letter in terms of whether or not it constitutes a breach of privilege and whether or not there was any attempt to improperly influence me in what action ought subsequently to be taken. It is an important issue.
—What does it say? I don't mean from the point of view of giving you leave; I am just interested.
—Leave has been given.

—Leave has been given and I have tabled a copy of the letter; I want to keep the original. I find part of the letter quite offensive. He does in fact in his own letter address some of the merits of the case, which I find a curious thing to do. It has been tabled for anyone who wants to see it. The letter states:

SPEECH.PARA: I would ask you to desist from any further comment which may tend to prejudice a fair hearing of Mr Smiles' case.

I have been scrupulous on all occasions to deal with the matter as a comparison with things that are on the public record and not go to the merits of the case. So I have taken this action today because I am truly very angry about the matter.

PARA.TAB: The second matter I want to raise is the question that we have discussed in this place before relating to the lease that the Australian Labor Party has secured from the Auditor-General for 15 years, with a five-year option, at 9 per cent annual increments for 6,000 square feet at a base rental of $330 per square metre.

In looking at the discussions we have had, both my colleague Senator Parer and I have said that it is quite unacceptable that a political party, and any political party—and I stress that; my objections would be just as strong if it were the Liberal Party—should be the landlord of the Auditor-General. I have said that the Auditor-General has to be like Caesar's wife—above suspicion. The fact is that the taxpayer, via the rental paid by the Auditor-General, will totally fund the building of the Labor Party headquarters, and not only will the rental repayments more than adequately meet the mortgage payments which will be entered into but also, at the end of the day, there will be surplus funds. Aside from that, the terms of the lease will provide that the tenant—that is, the Auditor-General—will meet all the outgoing expenses, all the maintenance, repair of lifts and anything else.

I bothered to go out into the marketplace to find out just how legitimate any of this would be, even if one leaves aside the question of whether a political party could possibly be the landlord of the Auditor-General, the Australian National Audit Office. Professional advice tells me that the rental quantums and the increased percentage per annum border on being unprofessional; that the figures seem to be based on what the market was like three years ago rather than what it is like today; and that the lease document is bankable.

I think it is not without importance to note that none of the correspondence between the Australian National Audit Office and the Department of Finance, from whom permission had to be sought, in fact refers to the Australian Labor Party as being the landlord of the Australian National Audit Office. We are advised that by the beginning of this year the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) was aware of it, but it seems that great effort was put into not disclosing, in any of the correspondence—and I refer to all the correspondence that is tabled—that it was in fact the Labor Party which was to be the landlord. The title of the building all along seems to be `Lot 22 Barton' or the `yet to be named Lend Lease site at Barton opposite the National Press Club'. Clearly, this is totally unacceptable.

In looking at the figures, I went a little further. It seems that the excavation for the building only went ahead after the lease agreement had in fact been signed. Indeed, as this is a bankable document, the money was forthcoming to provide the funding to build the office for the Australian Labor Party.

Let us get clear what I am saying: the Australian taxpayer, via the Australian National Audit Office, is paying to build the headquarters of the Australian Labor Party; that it is taxpayers' funds that will pay for the maintenance of this building; and that this arrangement will exist for 20 years. The term of the lease is 15 years with a five-year option to be exercised when 10 years have expired.

Quite frankly, for the taxpayer to be financing such an overgenerous lease for such a sensitive office which, as I have said, has to be above suspicion and which can ultimately provide a steady cash flow for political purposes, is totally unacceptable. I just wish we could find some way in which the lease could be broken so that the Auditor-General could be freed from this preposterous proposition and so that the taxpayer would not be forced to pay to build a headquarters for the Australian Labor Party and subsequently provide a cash flow for it to spend against the interests of all those people who do not vote for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not for the first time in this chamber I rise to defend a person who has been subject to an attack in the Senate under privilege. I refer to a speech made on 3 June by Senator Bell in which, in the course of alleging unfair treatment by Australia Post against a former employee, he named a claims manager, Mr Lippiat, as hampering his efforts to assist the person concerned. I might say that I was unable, of course, to advise Senator Bell that I would be making these comments, as is the normal courtesy, as Senator Bell, I believe, is away on parliamentary business.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lippiat was described by Senator Bell as a `self-appointed vigilante', an unusual description, I believe, for an employee engaged in carrying out his duties. There was a strong inference that Mr Lippiat was a liar. Not only was Mr Lippiat subjected to this pejorative description, but he was the only Australia Post employee named by Senator Bell. The inference can also clearly be drawn that Mr Lippiat is the individual bearing prime responsibility for the alleged unfair treatment of the former employee, who I will call `Mr Y', catalogued at length by Senator Bell. I do not, of course, wish to canvass the merits of the case or indeed risk adding to the distress of Mr Y. Mr Lippiat has the right to raise his case with the Senate Standing Committee of Privileges, and it would not be appropriate to argue any detailed case at this stage.

The point that I do wish to make very strongly is the gross unfairness of Senator Bell in attacking an individual with whom he has not sought to speak and who he has not contacted prior to naming him in Parliament. Surely, if Senator Bell thought that Mr Lippiat was as guilty as he claims him to be, he would have sought to find the facts and at least speak with Mr Lippiat prior to making a speech about the issue.

Mr Lippiat is an employee simply doing his job. This type of public attack cannot be a threat to his continuation in that job, and it is the very kind of affront to natural justice that Senator Bell was alleging. Whatever steps are now taken to put the other side of the story and to clear Mr Lippiat's name, the damage has clearly been done. I do not believe that parliamentary privilege in any way, shape or form was ever designed for any senator or any member of parliament to damage a person's credibility in the way in which Senator Bell has damaged Mr Lippiat's.

At times there may be grounds for senators to make strong attacks on the actions of statutory bodies, but this should not, however, degenerate into attacks upon officials who have no quick access to rebut such allegations. The Democrats in the Senate are entitled to pursue a particular attitude to compensation questions, even if some of us doubt that in all cases the client is in the right. I am not suggesting for one moment that was the case with Mr Y as I am not in a position to judge. What saddens me is the recourse to abuse of individual claims officers or medical practitioners, wilfully damaging career prospects and professional reputations.

A former Western Australian Democrats senator, Jean Jenkins, was an offender in this regard, causing the Privileges Committee to authorise a rebuttal that was tabled on 19 September 1990. I would certainly ask Senator Bell not to follow the same path as former Senator Jenkins.

In closing, I might add that I find this totally contradictory to the position being touted publicly and frequently by the Australian Democrats that there is a need for some formalised code of conduct in this Parliament. If they believe there is a need for some formalised code of conduct, I wish they would start demonstrating their code of conduct and cease wilfully attacking the credibility of people and damaging their livelihood.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some senators may recall that in October 1990 six women from this Parliament were invited to Moscow and Leningrad by what was then the Soviet Women's Committee. Four senators of that group reported to the Senate their impressions of what was then Leningrad, and Moscow.

PARA.TAB: The Soviet women we met were extremely anxious about the changes that were occurring in economic and political life in the USSR at that time, and at the advent of democratic elections. Many aspects of their lives which had been very much taken for granted at that stage were being thrown into confusion. For example, the previous high participation rate of women in the USSR work force was being threatened as the economy changed, and many women were facing unemployment.

We discovered in our time in the USSR that, amongst other things, careers for which there was little if any training included social work and small business management. Both of those careers, of course, were going to be providing work for women who had the required qualifications.

Senator Newman, a member of the delegation, having discussed this with the Soviet Women's Committee, commissioned a project in conjunction with the Women's Committee whereby Soviet women would be selected and would undertake a course which was going to equip them as trainers in small business management. Tutors from Australia would conduct this course and the Soviet Women's Committee would cover the costs in Moscow.

Students were quickly nominated from all the Soviets and the course would have proceeded late in 1991 but for the events of last August. In particular, the splintering of the USSR placed a question mark over the future of the Soviet Women's Committee. At this end, it frightened off possible sources of private funding for the project in Australia.

The introduction of the Australian Program for Training in Eastern Europe, which extended educational aid to that part of the world, offered a new funding option. With the support of our Ambassador in Moscow, His Excellency Cavan Hogue, the project was approved. In the meantime, the Soviet Women's Committee had survived and regrouped as the Women's Union of Russia. It has refocused its activities but maintains both its independence and a coordinating role as the peak non-governmental organisation for the women's unions of the newly independent states.

The modified course proceeded with 15 students selected from cities and regions of Russia. Teaching and other qualifications were prerequisites for the course. One tutor from Australia conducted the six-week course which commenced early in May. The course itself was complemented by English lessons and sessions led by dignitaries and officials of the Russian Parliament and from our own Embassy.

Senator Newman and I were invited to attend the graduation ceremony to be held in Moscow on June 11. Unfortunately, Senator Newman was unable to leave Australia at such short notice. Although travelling 18,000 kilometres to attend a graduation ceremony might be considered excessive, I was able to rearrange my diary and my bank account and accept the invitation in the spirit of sisterly solidarity and some motherly pride.

The graduation was held in the remarkably grand reception hall of the Australian residency and was an altogether delightful occasion, thanks to the hospitality and the wholehearted cooperation of the Australian Ambassador, Cavan Hogue. Mrs Hogue presented the certificates and we were regaled with a very sumptuous morning tea of champagne and lamingtons. Of the students who graduated, eight will establish their own training courses in the Russian cities and provinces from which they come, three plan to establish other business enterprises and others are looking for more specialised training.

Australian support for the project included $20,000, which I understand was approved from the Head of Mission Fund. The Women's Union of Russia, as it is now, contributed a considerable amount of support, premises, accommodation for the students, equipment and so forth. The Women's Union of Russia plans to establish a small business centre in its premises in Moscow and this will provide continuing support to the students, interpret and distribute relevant legislation which they will need in their new occupations and ensure that relevant information is readily available to them.

The whole exercise had its genesis in what was the Soviet Women's Committee, a long established and highly regarded NGO, which for many years has been establishing an international network focusing on development, peace and disarmament. Of necessity its focus has changed over the last few months but, as the needs of Russian women have become more apparent, it is now committed to providing training in a wide range of occupations which Soviet women will need in order to be employed in their new economy. All concerned in the project are unanimous in their satisfaction with the course. Clearly, as far as can be assessed at this point, the cost effectiveness is very impressive.

A second course is under consideration. I understand that a submission to assist another course along the same lines would be favourably entertained by our Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. I congratulate very sincerely—and I am sure Senator Newman also does—the Women's Union of Russia for its initiative, which gave rise to the course being designed in the first place. I give our very sincere thanks to Ambassador Hogue and the Australian officials who were so readily supportive of the course and whose participation had a great deal to do with its success.

I also very sincerely thank the Women's Union of Russia for organising my few days in Moscow last week. The graduation ceremony was the highlight, but there were many other quite outstanding opportunities for me to see a little of Russian life at this time. I was accommodated in the home of one of the officials of the Women's Union of Russia. I was invited to other homes, and was able to discuss the difficulties that the people are facing.

I was given a conducted tour of the White House and met a number of the members of the delegation which came from the Russian Parliament to Canberra in March of this year. I was welcomed in the Chamber of Nationalities, as we welcome dignitaries who come to our Parliament.

Amongst other highlights was a meeting with the Editor-in-Chief of Izvestia, Igor Golembiovsky, and renewing my acquaintance with Valentina Tereshkova, whom honourable senators will recall was the first woman to be included on the space program not quite 30 years ago. Ever since, Valentina has been hoping to visit Australia, which of course she saw from a very great distance in 1963. I understand that she has been invited to take part in a conference sponsored by the International Space School to be held in Sydney next month.

Being able to spend time with the Soviet women members of the course, the members of the Union of Parliamentarians and the ordinary Soviet people enabled me to learn something of the changes that are taking place in their lives.

I would have to say that Moscow in mid-summer looks very much like any large city. I saw a little of the countryside, too, and I greatly appreciated a visit to the dacha of Mr Kouzmin, who is known to many of our colleagues here as an ex-official of the USSR Embassy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take this opportunity to raise an issue that has attracted considerable comment in the business pages of most newspapers today. I refer to the sudden concern about the possibility of some tax avoidance under the Australian Taxation Office's new swaps regime for bringing income to account by bankers under what is known as swaps trading. The Commissioner of Taxation, Mr Boucher, has today announced that he is suddenly very concerned at the opportunity for tax avoidance created by his Office's ruling on swaps which was issued on 21 May 1992.

PARA.TAB: My response to that is: I told you so. From the very beginning of the debate on the appropriate tax accounting for swaps transactions, the banking industry at large and I in the Senate asserted two things: firstly, that the cash basis will give rise to tax avoidance, and I refer to Hansard of 4 September 1991; and, secondly, that the cash basis is wrong tax accounting, and I refer to Hansard of 4 September 1991 and 26 May 1992. The answer is and always has been that, if one wants to fix the avoidance risk in this industry, one just fixes the tax accounting treatment.

The error in the ruling was to require daily accruals for cash flows in arrears but cash basis for cash flows in advance. The remedy simply is to require daily accruals for all swaps flows, irrespective of their time of payment. The fact that there are two regimes, one for swaps flows in advance and another for swaps flows in arrears, means that at a 30 June take-off one is bound to have a bringing together of as many of the transactions as possible before the end of June, or to commence at 1 July, depending on one's particular position.

I make the point that, if the Commissioner of Taxation had bothered to listen to what was said in the Senate on this matter, he would now not be concerned, he would now not have to make another ruling and he would not have been subject to such a run on the revenue. This is because, if an advance swaps payment or a prepayment were treated on a daily accruals basis and thus tax effected over the period to which it relates, which is the appropriate method, there would be no up-front tax deduction obtained before 30 June for an advance payment under a swap entered into today. It is as simple as that.

This brings me to the burning issue of retrospectivity. The ruling issued in May discriminated against taxpayers, especially banks, who in the past had tax effected all their swaps cash flows on a daily accrual basis, which is the normal, internationally recognised method of bringing income and expense to account. In my speech on 26 May I pointed out that this discrimination was ludicrous and it was very costly to business because the Tax Office had just recognised in its ruling that the daily accrual basis was the correct method.

Today I can add that the tax accounting method adopted by such banks saved the revenue significant amounts because it deliberately did not take advantage of the loophole that Mr Boucher is suddenly so concerned about. Those banks did not take up-front deductions for advance swaps payments, which the cash basis and that ruling in May permitted. It was a surprise ruling. It astounded everybody who has any notion of accounting or understanding of tax.

I urge the Senate to support the following: firstly, the consistent application of daily accruals tax accounting to all swaps cash flows, which is logical but necessary; secondly, a non-retrospective operation for the ruling so that taxpayers who consistently and, may I emphasise, correctly adopted the daily accruals basis in the past should not have their tax position disturbed; and, thirdly, an amendment to the recent ruling to achieve the outcomes in which both the first and the second recommendations can be achieved. I therefore urge the Senate and the Tax Office to ensure that we have a situation where the Tax Office can examine these positions and amend its rulings accordingly.
Motion (by Senator Collins) agreed to:
