DEBATE.TITLE: DAIRY PRODUCE AMENDMENT BILL 1992DAIRY PRODUCE LEVY (No. 1) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 28 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills that we are debating are the Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1992 and the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1992. These Bills phase out assistance to the dairy industry to ensure that by the year 2000 the level will be equal to a 5 per cent tariff. This is important legislation because it will carry the manufacturing sector of the dairying industry, in particular, through to the turn of the century and beyond—that is 70 per cent of the industry in Australia, with over $700m of export. It is the most significant regional industry in Australia, employing about 100,000 people directly and indirectly.

PARA.TAB: This legislation replaces what has become known as the Kerin plan. It has been a basically successful five-year program which has given stability to an industry through the all milk levy and other components. At the same time there has been a very rapid rationalisation and increase in productivity in that industry. People tend to forget that the Kerin plan bears very little relationship to Minister Kerin. The original proposal he brought to the Parliament was held up for 12 months and considerably amended by a combination of my colleagues, including Ralph Hunt, the then honourable member for Gwydir, the Australian Dairy Farmers Federation and the Dairy Industry Council.

I would remind the Senate that the five-year program owes its success very much to the Opposition as well as to the Government. The dairy industry has made it very clear that it does not want any delays to the legislation, and the coalition agrees with that.

As is the normal practice, whether it is a Labor or a coalition government in office, there was an Industry Commission inquiry into the industry. One of the major aspects of the Industry Commission's recommendations related to city milk. Of course, that is regulated by the States. The States said that they were not going along with that particular part of it, so that has been put to one side, as I think everyone anticipated.

In relation to the manufacturing sector, the Government has basically followed the recommendations of the Industry Commission, with two exceptions. The Industry Commission recommended a phase-down starting with 20 per cent support through all milk levy for the coming season and going down to 5 per cent by July 1986. The Government, through the legislation, has recommended a 12-month delay or holding at the present 22 per cent level, down to 10 per cent by the year 2000. As the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, has said, this is the equivalent of about a 5 per cent support arrangement because of the mix between the domestic market and export market.

The Government's decision is basically in line with general coalition policy, that is, that all industries should by the year 2000 be down to a negligible or 5 per cent level of tariff or its equivalent. The Government in this case has actually treated the dairy industry harder than it has some other industries, for example, the textile, clothing and footwear industries and the motor vehicle industry. By the year 2000 they will be down to tariff levels of 25 per cent and 15 per cent in each case. The fact that the Government is not treating those industries in the same way as it is treating the dairy industry and many other industries adds to dairy farmers' costs, and the dairy farmers of Australia are well aware of that. They know very well that there are absolutely no tariffs on imported dairy products and there have not been for some time.

Even if there were tariffs on dairy products imported into Australia from other countries, the fact is that under closer economic relations with New Zealand there are no tariff restrictions on products from New Zealand; there are no dumping or countervailing procedures on products from New Zealand. New Zealand has, in overall terms, the most efficient manufacturing dairy industry in the world.

New Zealand has some advantages, particularly now that the New Zealand Government has undertaken some very significant industrial relations reforms so that there is greater efficiency in its factories, greater efficiency in its transport and, particularly, greater efficiency on its waterfront. It is said that the average New Zealand dairy farmer is $3,500 a year better off than he was before these reforms, purely because of the genuine reforms that have taken place on the waterfront. The Australian dairy farmer has not had the equivalent advantage. New Zealand dairy farmers also have the advantage of a goods and services tax which reduces their cost of production and assists them with exports.

The point that I am making is that the presence of New Zealand limits the ability of the industry, irrespective of any other arrangements, to increase the price of dairy products sold on the domestic market in Australia—that is, butter, cheese et cetera. There are absolutely no impediments to those products coming in from New Zealand. I know that some people would add other arguments, that there are benefits for New Zealand because of its pooling arrangements and the special access it had to the European Community—still at quite a high price. I believe we had a good example of industry leadership that has worked its way through the Government in a sensible and pragmatic way.

The major feature of this legislation is the all milk levy. It provides the stability with regard to export assistance or incentives, which maintains the stability on both the domestic market and the export market. That is paid for by every dairy farmer in Australia. It is not paid for by government under any budgetary arrangements. The maximum is 45c per kilogram fat and the maximum level of theoretical assistance was 30 per cent. But it is at 22 per cent at the present time and I have indicated that it is coming down over the next five years.

The dairy industry has suffered more than any other agricultural industry in Australia from unfair trade practices internationally. The European Community got a surplus position with the dairy industry over 10 years ago. It was well ahead of the grain industry, the sugar industry, the beef industry or any horticultural industry. In fact, there have been countervailing actions against those European export subsidies for quite a few years. At the same time as we have given unlimited access to European cheese, provided it is on a fair trade basis, the EC has restricted our access to a far larger market in Europe to 3,000 tonnes a year, with a 24 per cent common external tariff.

I am pleased that the Government has accepted the advice of the Senate Committee and, after pressure from the coalition, has now changed its previously absurd three-year sunset arrangement when there is any dumping or countervailing action, to a five-year arrangement which allows for the case to be looked at again to see that, if subsidisation is continuing, the countervailing duty also continues. The industry does have a dilemma. Does it go back to try countervailing again or does it stick with the current arrangement? That is a difficult decision for the industry.

I make the point, too, about the pressure having been on the dairy industry longer than on other processed agricultural industries in Australia. It was probably the first to be put under pressure by the supermarkets for generic or home brands. That has also been coupled with pressures on imports by some of the supermarket chains. It is one of the problems that the industry faces at the moment, in spite of improvements to the fair trade procedures.

In a coalition government, as we have indicated publicly, we would have far tougher criteria on this question of material injury. It would allow for a shorter time span before application was made, and then halve the time after that application was made for both tentative and final duties. There is still a problem, and it is something that we in opposition and the Government have to face up to. It is not just unique to the dairy industry and the case it has with Dutch edam, which is definitely being export subsidised and sold at the moment here in Australia at a far less than normal selling price.

The pig industry and other industries face it. Even when an industry has a wider ability to make an application—that is, one that is affected, such as the farmer with the dairy or the pig producer with pork—unless the processing sector is prepared to provide the necessary information on costs and therefore work through to a selling price et cetera, or unless the supermarkets, if they are the straight importers, are prepared to provide that information, there is still a difficulty in really making the application and reaching a just decision.

Food standards is another area in which the dairying industry was probably subjected to some of these problems earlier than others. The States have been very lax in their determinations of these standards. Preservatives which have been banned in Australia because they are supposedly cancer forming have been allowed in imported cheese. We are never told publicly about the degree of listeria that is uncovered in tests on imported cheese. I am pleased that we now have a National Food Authority and are making progress. I acknowledge that it is up to the States, as the component parts of the National Food Authority, to push a damn sight harder than they are at the present time.

Another factor in relation to this legislation is underwriting. The Industry Commission recommended that underwriting be continued. It was the Industry Commission that invented this in the first place quite a few years ago. The underwriting for dairying is very market related. There is an eight-year trend line and then 85 per cent of that, and then the Industry Commission also recommended a $22m ceiling. I know that my colleague the shadow Minister for primary industries, Mr Bruce Lloyd, personally supports this and believes that underwriting, whether it is for dairying or for wheat or whatever, is a sensible thing to have in place to provide stability when something happens unfairly in the international market.

Underwriting has been triggered only once in the past five or six years, at the $22m mark in 1991. That was the year in which the Europeans increased their export subsidies and it was the bad year for grain. That would have provided a maximum of $4,000 for Victorian and Tasmanian dairy farmers who are the major beneficiaries of underwriting because they have the greatest export exposure.

Let us compare that with the coalition's Fightback policy on reducing costs to farmers by the removal of fuel excises, payroll tax and sales tax. Every year farmers will have their costs reduced by $8,000 and it will not matter whether they are Victorian dairy farmers or Northern Territory dairy farmers. That is the positive that puts us far ahead of Labor when it comes to total policy.

We are also committed to implementing a far better income equalisation deposit scheme. I hope the Government itself is doing that because, although there is stability in relative terms in the dairy industry compared to some others, there still should be better incentives to encourage farmers to take out their own self-insurance.

The Minister has acknowledged that he is prepared to do some work with regard to getting uniform State cooperative legislation. I believe that my colleague Mr Bruce Lloyd is in concurrence with the Minister as he has also been having discussions with some of his State colleagues. Cooperatives are essential, in both the horticultural and dairy industries, to provide some leverage and reasonable power for producers. The State restrictions we have at the present time do not allow cooperatives to become national in a sensible way. We all know some of the examples of State legislation having prevented sensible amalgamations for cooperatives from taking place.

The coalition parties support the legislation because it provides further rationalisation of the industry in the sense of moving to a more internationally competitive position in relation to what it is producing. But we recognise that if anything like a level playing field develops internationally over the next few years—whether it is for a commercial price for dairy products as distinct from the corrupt price of the present time, or for access to a fair basis to those markets—the dairy industry in this country has a very great future as an expanded industry and one which will play its part in further exports.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dairy Produce Amendment Bill 1992 and the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill 1992, which are before the Senate today, represent a tremendous change for the dairy industry. This industry has been determined to restructure, to become more efficient and to be able to compete on world markets. It has had no choice, naturally, because if it had not rationalised and restructured, it would not be able to compete in the way it is required to.

PARA.TAB: In this legislation the Government has basically followed the recommendations of the Industry Commission report with a number of exceptions. One of the main arguments in that report was that Australian consumers would get cheaper milk if controls in the Australian dairy industry were removed. It said that further reductions in assistance must take place if the dairy industry is to maximise its contribution to national welfare, adding that the Australian industry had to prepare for increased competition from New Zealand dairy products.

In addition, it recommended that assistance to the industry should be phased out in the next two to 10 years and that the Commonwealth should phase down maximum market support payments from 20 per cent of average export prices to 5 per cent by 1996. The Government, through this legislation, has recommended a 12-month delay or holding at the present 22 per cent level down to 10 per cent by the year 2000.

As I said earlier, I am pleased that some of the Commission's recommendations have not been accepted by the Government. Indeed, if the report were accepted in its totality, I ask honourable senators whether they honestly believe that the whole community would have benefited if, in the long run, its proposed changes resulted in decreased production, a significant reduction in jobs and the industry being unable to compete on world markets.

So often now we see that the Industry Commission seems to believe that it is acceptable for Australia to become a dumping ground. It is asking Australian farmers and manufacturers to accept as right and proper, prices which are based on the world market's dumped prices. We have seen this asked of producers in other rural industries. These prices are the result of political decisions in Brussels and Washington, and do not reflect retail prices in the exporting countries where consumers are paying more for their produce than Australia.

The Australian dairy industry is alive with innovation, technical progress and a driving will to compete. Our dairy foods are as good as, and in many cases better than, any in the world. Dairy food exports earn more than $700m each year. The industry's major investments in research, technology and market development will see these export earnings grow. Dairy farm productivity is increasing by 5 per cent per year, as it has for the past decade. The industry's willingness to adapt to change means that it will benefit from even minor reforms in the international trading environment. Already Australians buy premier quality dairy foods at prices as low as anywhere in the world. Australian dairy farmers produce milk at lower cost than those in Europe, the USA, Canada or Japan, thanks to our pasture-based farming. In fact, few countries can produce quality dairy products as cheaply as Australia.

More than 100,000 Australians have jobs thanks to the dairy industry. The industry provides about 20 per cent of employment in a number of important dairying regions. This is especially important in light of the particularly difficult times that rural Australia is now experiencing. Studies show that, for every 100 jobs in dairy factories, an additional 110 jobs are created in associated regional activities and the flow-on effects beyond the region are about as large again.

Dairying is a very `real' industry, close to the people it employs, part of everyone's day-to-day life, and earning export dollars for all Australians. Currently, Australia's dairy industry manufactures many specialised products for markets here and overseas and its farmers currently produce milk valued at some $1.7 billion each year, all of which is processed within Australia. On top of this, processed dairy foods are valued at about $4.5 billion a year, an added value of $3 billion annually.

Representations to me from the Australian dairy industry indicate that it recognises that neither regulation nor protection offer a panacea for the problems created by unfair world trade policies. However, the industry does advocate a thoughtful and cautious approach to addressing the future. The Australian dairy industry, with minimal assistance, competes in corrupted world markets and against subsidised imports—and, importantly, the industry funds its own export marketing arrangements. Nothing will be gained by sacrificing the dairy industry's hard-won international competitiveness.

The Australian dairy industry has asked for a continuation of existing marketing arrangements in order to capitalise on the changes already implemented, to obtain significant returns on the large investment in research and development, to continue to enhance productivity, to facilitate continuing change, and to take advantage of improvements in the international trading environment. I believe that those are very worthy objects of the Australian dairy industry, and the National Party supports these dairy Bills before the Senate today.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it the International Air Services Commission Bill 1992. This Bill deals with the allocation of international air traffic rights. International aviation is covered by bilateral agreements between the countries to which the airlines are operating. This matter has not been a problem for us in Australia in the past. We have had only one international carrier, Qantas, so the allocation of the traffic rights as a consequence of the various bilateral agreements which Australia has had in existence since the Second World War has not been a problem at all.

PARA.TAB: The situation has now changed, following the Government's policy statement earlier in this year which allows other Australian carriers to enter the air traffic between Australia and other countries. I presume—I have not checked this—that the policy statement of the Government does not mean only Ansett but any new carriers within Australia would be entitled to bid for these routes, in the fullness of time.

It is quite obvious that, if routes are to be allocated, there is a situation where fairness needs to be seen to be done in the allocation of those traffic rights—that there is clearly equal treatment afforded. That is what this Bill sets out to do: to set up a commission to sit in judgment on the allocation of those routes so that the public interest is preserved and, of course, the commercial interests of the airlines applying for those routes, so that they have a fair opportunity to prosecute their business.

In international air traffic at the present time, there is clearly a place for other carriers of Australian origin to become involved. One of the difficulties of a monopoly situation is that a monopoly carrier, as Qantas has been, does not always meet the market demands. It tends to look after its own interests to the exclusion of others. As a senator from a State where there is quite a deal of primary production—Queensland is probably the leading primary producer for the Australian export market—on many occasions over the years I have been made aware that international freight traffic, in vegetables and flowers, for example, cannot be developed because of the lack of a freight service.

Despite numerous appeals to Qantas to set up a dedicated freight service, where time is of the essence of getting into markets in South East Asia and Europe, Qantas has never done so. It has shown no interest at all in running a freight service. Unless that service is there, the export trade simply cannot be developed. The two go hand in hand and the provision of the freight service is fundamental.

Another example of where Qantas failed to meet the market occurred some years ago, when it became the only airline in the world to have an all-Boeing 747 fleet. It made a great thing about that at the time but the consequence of having a single aircraft type to operate its route structure was a great deal of inflexibility. Qantas simply could not service a lot of the routes in the South Pacific region and the near Asian markets, where the traffic was not too heavy. It is a matter of history that it had to go to a second aircraft type—a smaller aircraft, the Boeing 767, which has worked out very well for it.

There is need for competition on this but in the allocation of new route structures, in all fairness to Qantas, recognition has got to be given to the work it has put into developing routes and the financial investment it has made in carrying routes that were not profitable for years until they did become profitable. There is a need for a fine balance here. It is not a one-way street.

I would like to make a few general comments about the Bill. The first thing is the structure of the Commission itself. The Commission is going to have a staff of 12: a part time chairman working three days per week; two members working one day per week; a secretary, a second level SES equivalent; three divisional heads class 2; and five research and support staff. The Minister estimates that it is going to cost the Commonwealth $2.2m a year initially to operate this.

Such a commission to determine the allocation of routes is something that has been used in a number of countries overseas where there are a number of international flag carriers for that country. It would appear that the approach being proposed to the Australian Parliament is one that is based on the United States system. There is an alternative model used by the United Kingdom which provides for public hearings for the allocation of all international rights, and, of course, this Bill does provide that, wherever practicable, hearings will be in public also.

One of the difficulties that has become apparent with the United Kingdom system, though, is that it has developed into a goldmine for aviation lawyers, where every decision has been fought and fought with great tenacity by all the interest groups involved, the airlines, the tourist agencies and things like that. I would hope that the Australian Commission does not act as a source of income for the already profligate number of lawyers that we have in this country. Not only are we tying up personnel there, we are certainly tying up the commerce of the country on the development of routes.

It is the coalition's view that in government we would certainly support the Commission and its duties as defined in this Bill, but we would think that a more appropriate staffing would be three on the Commission as proposed, two research staff for research and performance monitoring of the route structure, and 2 support staff. In other words, we would favour a staffing of seven instead of the 12 that are proposed here.

We would certainly also include the allocation of charter flights, which is not mentioned at all in this Bill. It may be the intention of the Minister to include it—he may make reference to that in his reply. Certainly, it is part and parcel of all the traffic and the charter services really ought to be included.

The second point I would make is that in the interpretation section of the Bill, there is simply no definition of an Australian carrier, and I find that quite unusual. In the interpretation section, it says:

SPEECH.PARA: "Australian carrier", in relation to particular capacity, means a person who:
(a) conducts, or proposes to conduct, an international airline service to and from Australia; and

(b) under the bilateral arrangement to which the capacity relates, may be permitted to carry passengers or freight, or both passengers and freight, under that arrangement as an airline designated by Australia.

As a nationalist, I would have felt much more comfortable if there were some definition as to who owned an Australian carrier. But maybe there is a reason for that. The general conditions under which the Commission has to operate are, first of all, as I have said before, the preservation of the public interest, which is important. There is provision for a finite time allocation of rights, in general five years. An airline cannot be granted a traffic right and hold it in perpetuity. There is an ability to transfer: if one airline which has been awarded an international route cannot use it or does not wish to use it, there is provision for that to be transferred to another carrier. Most importantly, there is a prohibition on stock holding, which is somebody applying for and being granted a traffic right and not using it merely to keep a competitor off that route. There are limitations on that.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I would make the observation that the Bill does show evidence of hasty drafting. The sequencing of the clauses could have been much neater and it could have followed a much more logical grouping of clauses than we have in this Bill.

In general, the Bill does vest very considerable powers in the Commission. It certainly has a great degree of independence in coming to its decisions, though it is required to comply with the general requirements laid down in policy statements by the Minister. I only hope that complying with those policy statements does not mean that we are faced with a very mobile area. I hope that policy, once set, stays reasonably permanent for a number of years so that we do not have that opportunity provided for legal challenge and all the costs and delays that come from that. Also, if there is not stability in the way the Commission operates and the way the policy statements are laid down, we are going to have a great deal of commercial uncertainty, which will reflect on the profitability of the airlines. If the airlines are unprofitable, Australia's interest is not being served. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator MacGibbon for his support of the International Air Services Commission Bill. I must say that his support for the Bill does not surprise me because as someone who long campaigned along with my then opposite number, the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Paul Everingham, for an end to the two airlines agreement, I had cause to read the Federal Parliamentary debates that were conducted on the two airlines agreement when that agreement was renewed, amid a great deal of controversy, by the Fraser Government.

PARA.TAB: I did note in those debates the views of Senator MacGibbon on the renewal of that arrangement. So I know, and am prepared to concede, that he has adopted a very pro-competitive stance in respect of airline arrangements in the past. I will just address those matters that Senator MacGibbon has raised. As the Bill makes quite specific, the applications, of course, are open to anyone, not simply to Ansett. However—Senator MacGibbon would acknowledge this in terms of the need to have a viable carrier operating these routes—Ansett would be well placed following the amalgamation of Australian and Qantas, to be certainly in the running for those routes.

In respect of the start-up costs, we have attempted—and I am sure Senator MacGibbon would acknowledge this—to keep this as lean and mean as we can. I do stress that the $2.2m is a start. The reason that I make that statement is that I think that within probably a relatively short period of time, hopefully, this body will have to do less and less work. I say that because there is a continuing trend around the world, which I know Senator MacGibbon is aware of, to make even more and more liberal the capacity arrangements that are made currently by bilateral arrangements between countries. I hope that it does get to the point where these capacity constraints are removed and that capacity will be able to meet these demands without any need for any real adjudication.

So far as the feast for lawyers is concerned, you open up that possibility with any piece of legislation that is introduced into the Parliament. All I can say in respect of that is that we have received advice from people who are acknowledged as being experts in the area of aviation law. A comment that was made to us by one person eminent in that area was that it is as good an attempt as he has seen compared with other regimes around the world, two of which Senator MacGibbon referred to, to make this as sensible and as dispute-free an approach. All we can do is acknowledge that that is a potential problem and hope, along with Senator MacGibbon, it will not occur.

Charters will certainly be an area which will be made clear later on. I will be looking to advice from the Commission on that, particularly in relation to the impact of those charters on the designated routes that were available for scheduled carriers on such routes.

So far as the definition of `Australian carrier' is concerned, I will take that on board to see whether there is any need to further define it. But we cannot, as Senator MacGibbon is aware, under the ICAO agreements around the world designate a national carrier unless that carrier is owned 65 per cent by nationals of the country for which the designation applies. For that reason it was not thought necessary to define it but we will certainly take that on board and if we think that we could add further clarification then we will have a look at that.

One final point I would simply like to make is that this is a pro-competitive model. There are screams and yells about it. I acknowledge that and they are coming from the airlines because you cannot expect airlines that have enjoyed a monopoly for a very long period of time—and for a large part of that time for good reason—to be particularly happy about having competition introduced. But the people who do undeniably benefit at the end of the day are the public.

I would like to highlight one section of the Bill, clause 8, which indicates how pro-competitive this measure is. Section 8 is an important section in the legislation. It provides for the Commission to examine the renewal of allocations at the end of an original determination. Under the legislation, read in conjunction with the policy statement, the Commission will be able to properly consider reallocation of part of the capacity allocated to an incumbent carrier in appropriate cases to encourage competition. The criteria which must be applied under the policy statement by the Commission when assessing the renewal of existing determinations include carrier performance and public benefit. This could provide reallocation where it is demonstrated that an alternative use of the capacity would better serve the public benefit even though the existing use was of some benefit to the public. With that final clarification I thank the Opposition for its support of the legislation and commend the Bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (TRAFFIC IN NARCOTIC DRUGS AND PSYCHOTROPIC SUBSTANCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports passage of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Amendment Bill. This is the second stage of Australia's progression towards ratification of the United Nations Convention Against Illicit Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances, which was entered into in 1988. The purpose of the convention, as set out in article 2, is to promote cooperation among the parties so that they may address more effectively the various aspects of illicit traffic in narcotic drugs and psychotropic substances having an international dimension. Pursuing that aim, the parties to the convention are to take necessary measures, including legislative and administrative measures.

PARA.TAB: For Australia, the first step was the passage of the Crimes (Traffic in Narcotic Drugs and Psychotropic Substances) Act of 1990. That Act, which will come into force when the convention takes effect, was designed to extend Australia's extraterritorial jurisdiction over drug related crimes. It preserved existing State and Territory laws which create criminal offences for conduct involving dealing in drugs. This Bill amends the 1990 Act to give effect to obligations under the convention to criminalise money laundering and to confiscate the proceeds of drug offences. The effect of the Bill will be to apply Federal legislation to allow for the confiscation of assets in relation to State drug offences.

The Opposition has three separate areas of concern in relation to this Bill. Firstly, we are concerned that the Bill may affect the balance of Federal-State responsibilities in the area of drug offences. During the 1990 debate it was emphasised that ratification of the convention could not occur until consultations with the States and Territories had been concluded and all States and Territories had enacted legislation for the confiscation of assets derived from dealing in drugs. However, not all States and Territories have yet done so.

The coalition was concerned that it was not clear that the States had agreed to the Federal Government proceeding with this Bill using the external affairs power. However, during the debate in the other place, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Attorney-General (Mr Duncan) emphasised that this Bill will apply only to those States and Territories which have not yet made it an offence to launder money or property which is derived from drug trafficking. All States and Territories have expressed their willingness to do so and only three are yet to act. This legislation will enable the Government to press ahead towards ratification of the convention, and we, of course, support it in this.

Secondly, we are concerned about the minimum 12 months imprisonment penalty level which is to apply in determining what is a serious State drug offence. Specifically, we are concerned that this threshold may be too low. For example, related offences under the Federal Act may lead to imprisonment for up to 20 years. Moreover, there are many State drug offences which are not particularly serious which carry penalties of more than 12 months imprisonment. We further note that under the Federal Telecommunications (Interception) Act of 1979 a serious offence is defined as one attracting a penalty of more than seven years imprisonment.
Our third area of concern is about proposed new section 8A, which reproduces article 3.3. of the convention. It provides that if a particular—
Debate interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I refer to the Prime Minister's comments on Tuesday when he said that something good was happening in the labour market, and that the jobs that were being created in recent years were ones where, `people can start off quite young in the job and find themselves in London for six months or find themselves in Tokyo and back in Australia'. How many of Australia's youth jobs are of that type? Is a youth unemployment rate of 34 per cent—according to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, the body which officially monitors these figures—something good happening in the labour market? If it is not—and we hope the Government thinks it is not—what is the Government doing about this tragedy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In making that statement, I think the Prime Minister was drawing attention to the changing nature of Australian industry, the increasing internationalisation of Australian firms and the consequences which flow from that in terms of job opportunities and different kinds of job opportunities both now and into the future.

PARA.TAB: As to the question of 34 per cent of the 15- to 19-year-old age cohort seeking employment and not being able to obtain it, yes, that figure is correct. But I have to say that it has to be put in this perspective: while the overall tragedy of unemployment is particularly saddening in respect of youth unemployment, it also impacts on other groups in the community very severely and, particularly, in the present circumstances, on male wage earners and those who are in the older age group.

I just make the point that I made the other day, that in terms of the consequences of this recession and youth unemployment, the aggregate numbers of people in the 15- to 19-year-old age group seeking work and unable to obtain work are fewer than they were in the 1983 recession. That is because of significant changes which have taken place in the composition and activity of that age group. For example, in Senator Hill's own State of South Australia, there are 2,000 fewer people in that age group seeking work and not able to obtain it in this year than there were in 1983. That is a pattern which results, as I said, from increasing participation in the education system by a whole range of young people, which is an important advance in terms of our international position and comparisons which we like to make at the present time with other countries.

As I have said on a number of occasions, that does not mean that the Government is not very concerned about that age group; it is giving consideration to ways in which the problem of that group may be alleviated. The Opposition ought not to get overexcited about this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are very concerned about it; you should be too!
—Senator Kemp has cast himself in the role of Rumpole. He keeps interjecting when I am answering questions. As was pointed out in an article in the Bulletin of 23 June:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . opposition Treasury spokesman Peter Reith tried to seem crestfallen and sympathetic but looked like a man thinking only of the next election. He said the jobless figures were a `desperate call' for the coalition's goods and services tax package, which he described as `a job creator'.

In the goods and services tax package there is a lot of assertion and mystical rhetoric about creating jobs. There is no hard, supportive material of any kind which suggests that that package would significantly improve the employment prospects of Australians, both immediately or in the long term future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Whilst there is an important debate about the need to get taxes off production in this country, as every other industrialised country in the world has done, my question to the Minister is: what is his Government doing about the tragedy of unemployment which is running in relation to youth unemployment at the incredible figure of 34 per cent? We have not heard one word yet from the Minister about what his Government is doing about it. I ask him, through this point of order: when will he get to answer the important part of this question?
—There is no point of order. The Minister was talking about employment and unemployment. It was becoming a very long answer.

—It is all very well for Senator Hill to get up and display stroppiness about this issue, but Senator Hill is not immune from this process himself. People are beginning to find this Opposition out. Another article in the Bulletin states:

ANSWER.PARA: He—
that is Senator Hill—
gives the impression of savouring every setback.
Mr Reith gives the same impression to the people who comment on these issues.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —No; I am quite happy to make that charge. The Opposition's enthusiasm goes up when unemployment goes up. That is what happens. Members of the Opposition announced all round this building today that they were going to make an issue of youth unemployment. Every journalist has been told that they will make a big issue about youth unemployment. That is their issue today; it was pig farming yesterday.
—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The question was, what is this Government going to do about youth unemployment? When is the Minister going to answer the question?
—The answer is becoming a debate.
—That is right, Senator Hill. I have not even started.
—Sit down or answer the question!
—Rumpole, really, I do not need any help from you. As I have said about unemployment generally, and about youth unemployment in this chamber on numerous occasions—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If those opposite do not want to hear, they should not ask any questions. As I have said about unemployment generally—and, of course, that embraces youth unemployment—on numerous occasions in this place, we will see an improvement in the unemployment figures when the economy starts to grow more rapidly, as it will in the next few months and as it has in the last three quarters. That is the Australian experience, and it was certainly the Australian experience in 1983 when youth unemployment was worse than it is today. That is the position. I have already said that in terms of the particular problems to which Senator Hill adverts, the Government—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—All right, I will finish then.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Australian Defence Force: Code of Conduct

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Is the Minister in a position to indicate whether he has accepted the code of conduct in regard to sexual activity in the Australian Defence Force which has been recommended by the Chiefs of Staff Committee?

—I did indicate to the Senate on 29 April that I would announce the Government's attitude to this particular question once Mr Bilney returned to work. I am pleased to say that not only has he returned to work but also he has set an example for me—he is 10 kilos lighter. Subsequent to his return, we have now endorsed the paper of the Chiefs of Staff on unacceptable sexual behaviour by members of the Australian Defence Force. That policy will be issued shortly. It addresses in some detail the question of unacceptable sexual behaviour by ADF members and the action which may be taken as a consequence. Importantly, it also deals with the issue of sexual harassment in the defence forces.

PARA.TAB: It is also our view that the current Defence Instruction—that is, Defence Instruction (General Personnel) 15-3—which deals with homosexual behaviour in the ADF should remain extant. I have directed that individual service instructions be brought into line with that instruction to ensure that the policies apply consistently through the Australian defence forces. I also concede that this policy may end up in the courts if cases of dismissal are challenged. I am in a position to table that particular paper and also the Defence Instruction on homosexual behaviour, and I do so now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under standing order 72, I address my question to Senator Alston. It is in regard to notice of motion No. 848 which refers to higher inflation and massive job losses which will be inflicted on ordinary workers as a result of the Government's compulsory superannuation scheme and requests the Government to withdraw this legislation. Does Senator Alston regard this is as an urgent notice of motion? If so, does he intend to bring it forward for early debate?

—I thank Senator Tierney for his timely contribution. This is a most important question. The answer to the first part of the question is, indeed, yes, this is an urgent matter because, unless the Democrats come to their senses within the next two weeks, we are going to have a totally unaffordable system of compulsory superannuation foisted on the workers of Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is imperative that the community understands as soon as possible that, as a result of this deal, a multi-billion dollar payroll tax will be imposed on small businesses in Australia at a time of record unemployment and the worst recession in 60 years. That is a catastrophic outcome, because there are only two ways in which one can fund this sort of scheme. Compulsory superannuation can be paid for either at the expense of jobs or at the expense of wage increases. The Government has already ruled out any discount against wage increases. It will therefore be paid for by jobs. We have had that from Senator Cook; we have had that from the Treasurer when he bothers to get involved in questions of superannuation; and we have had it today from Senator Kernot, who said that job losses will be halved.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't lie! Tell the truth!
—I understand Senator Cook's sensitivity, but I am sure that he does not want to contradict the Treasurer.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. My point of order is that what Senator Alston is saying that I said is not true. It is a deliberate falsehood, and it should be withdrawn. Mr President, you should bring him to order and ask him to withdraw the falsehood that he is saying that I said. It is not true.
—Order! There is no point of order. I call Senator Alston.
—Thank you, Mr President. I am astounded—
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order.
—Order! Are you taking a point of order on Senator Alston?
—No; I am taking a point of order on Senator Cook for using the word `falsehood'.
—I have ruled on that.
—I ask you to ask him to withdraw, according to your latest ruling, Mr President.
—Order! I call Senator Alston.

—It is, indeed, urgent that the community understand that the likes of Senator Cook will presumably not contradict the Treasurer of this country, who concedes that there will be job losses but says that they will be negligible, while Senator Kernot says merely that recent changes will halve the likely level of job losses. When the Treasury of this country can tell a Senate committee that if employers are to bear the full burden we could lose up to 100,000 jobs in the next five years, I would have thought that Senator Cook would not be able to lie straight in bed after denying that there will be substantial job losses.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the second part of Senator Tierney's question, the fact is that it is imperative that this notice of motion be brought forward for debate as soon as possible. I do not, of course, want to debate the issues, but I want to take the opportunity to point out why this is a very significant initiative which will crucially damage both workers and employers.

At present Australia wants a rational, sensible and affordable retirement incomes policy. What it will get from this Government is an employer funded, taxpayer subsidised, early retirement scheme. One thing that is clear in all the debate is that, if the Government is serious about arresting the rising cost of age pensions, it has to do something about raising the preservation age. The Australian Democrats, to their credit, have agreed with us that an increase in the present preservation age to 60 years ought to be phased in gradually over the next 10 or 15 years.

What is the Government's answer to arresting the rising cost of age pensions? It will consider raising the preservation age to 60 years in 33 years. Have honourable senators ever heard a more ludicrous cop-out in all their lives, pandering to the ACTU, which has a power of veto over superannuation policy in this country? It is an appalling abrogation—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your superannuation?
—Sixty years, phased in over a 10-year period.
—No; yours.

—That is a matter for others. I am not seeking to foist it on the work force of Australia and I am not seeking to force taxpayers to pay ever-increasing amounts of money. It is crucially important that we have this debate as soon as possible. The workers of Australia ought to know that over the next decade they will be forced to take reductions in their standard of living in order to disqualify themselves from receiving the age pension. If they think that is a pretty good outcome, I am sure they will make it clear. But the real alternative is that employers will pay the burden and there will be massive job losses as a result. The Government can take its choice.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training aware of reports that between 30 and 40 per cent of the total youth population is unemployed? Is this a true reflection of youth unemployment rates in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to that question is no, although, unfortunately, some reporters in the media keep reporting that that is the level of youth unemployment and some members of the Opposition, obviously in order to scare young people, constantly present this incorrect concept of the true level of youth unemployment. It is a fact that this Government takes no joy whatsoever in the level of unemployment. It takes no joy, either, in the level of youth unemployment. In our view both the general level of unemployment and that of young people are too high.

PARA.TAB: But it is important that we be honest about what the figures actually say and do not misrepresent the position as the Opposition has done and as some newspapers have done. They have relied on a presentational quirk in the figures. The Opposition has said that 34 per cent of teenagers are unemployed. That is not true.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Statistician said.

—That is not what the Statistician said. I thank Senator Macdonald for drawing attention to the fact that he and other members of his Party continually misrepresent what the Australian Statistician says.

PARA.TAB: I wish to set the record straight. The number of unemployed teenagers seeking full time work represents 9.9 per cent of the teenage population, not 34 per cent as claimed by the Opposition and regurgitated by some sections of the media. In fact, there are fewer 15- to 19-year-olds looking for jobs in Australia now than there were during the Howard recession in the early 1980s. The seasonally adjusted employment level for 15- to 19-year-olds looking for full time work fell from 157,700 in April 1983 to 131,100 in May 1992, a drop of 26,600. In April 1983, 12.3 per cent of young people in this age group were looking for work and unable to find it. As I have said, this figure is now 9.9 per cent.

What the Opposition is not telling Australians is that the ABS unemployment figures only measure those at work or those seeking work. The figures do not take into account teenagers at school or in tertiary institutions. Two-thirds of teenagers are in some form of education. It is important that the facts of this matter are properly presented so that people can make their own judgments. Since 1983, when this Government came to power, it has succeeded in doubling school retention rates. We have increased expenditure in real terms on education by 42 per cent. Since 1972 there has been an explosion in the number of university places. Since 1983 we have created the equivalent of 17 new universities in this country. In the One Nation statement we propose an extra $720m for technical and further education training.

The Prime Minister will shortly be holding a youth summit to address matters of youth employment further. That should be contrasted with what the Opposition would do. A 15 per cent consumption tax will not help youth unemployment; a cut in TAFE funding will not help the young unemployed; and kicking people off the dole after nine months will not help young people. The Howard search for the bygone era—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr President. My point of order is fairly simple: this is merely a rehash of the statement that the Prime Minister made earlier in the day. It amounts to a ministerial statement. There is provision for that on the agenda. That is the time to make it, not now.
—Order! There is no point of order. There are consistently too many interjections from both sides of the chamber today. I would like to point out that so far there have been four questions.
—One of them they asked themselves.
—I did not ask for that comment.

—Is the Minister representing the Attorney-General aware of the recent statement by Human Rights Commissioner Brian Burdekin that conditions in many Australian gaols contravene Article 16 of the convention against torture and other cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment of prisoners? Does the Minister agree that this international convention brings State prison systems within the constitutional powers of the Commonwealth? If so, is the Minister prepared to introduce a prison officers' code of conduct for the treatment of prisoners, including substantially increasing vocational training and general education programs; reviewing the existing training courses for prison officers; establishing new courses with a view to upgrading qualifications; placing greater emphasis on education and rehabilitation of prisoners; and, finally, introducing redundancy packages for staff unwilling to accommodate the new direction?

—I am aware of some press reports of recent statements by the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin, concerning his description of the conditions that prevail in some Australian gaols, as he put it, in contravention of the United Nations convention concerning torture in relation to cruel, inhuman or degrading conditions of imprisonment. I must say that he had never brought those matters to the attention of the Federal Attorney-General before he appeared before a committee. When matters were presented to the United Nations committee which deals with these matters—the torture committee—in November 1991, no note of concern emerged from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in the preparation of Australia's report to that committee. So I find it quite extraordinary that this very lurid description of the state of Australia's gaols should fall from the lips of the Human Rights Commissioner in this way. That is not to say that it is not a matter which ought to be of concern. It obviously needs to be assessed by the Government, as it no doubt will be by the committee.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the Federal Government has certain interests in relation to the State prison system and the Territory prison system in so far as Federal prisoners are incarcerated in those institutions—we do not have Federal prisons as, for example, is the case in the United States. Of course, that is what gives the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission its interest in the matter of the holding of some prisoners in State gaols, namely Federal prisoners in those gaols. That is one way in which we as a Federal Government get a particular interest.

Senator Spindler asked whether the United Nations convention itself might give us power. The only way in which the United Nations convention of itself can give the Federal Government power is by agreement of this Parliament that a law be passed through both Houses to allow the convention to have that effect. It is not the case that merely ratifying the treaty overrides any State or Territory law in relation to prisons or any other matter of State or, for that matter, Federal activity. It is always dependent on the judgment of this Federal Parliament as to whether the convention should be implemented into Australian law.

I believe that the matters raised by Senator Spindler require further consideration. It has certainly been the case in Federal sentencing law that we have made it abundantly clear to judges and magistrates that when a person accused of a Federal offence—such as drug trafficking, fraud against the Commonwealth or tax evasion of some types—is convicted before them, imprisonment is a sentence of last resort and that everything ought to be done short of imprisonment if that is at all possible and appropriate.

As to Senator Spindler's final question about a prison officers' code of conduct and the particular training of prison officials, officers and so on, I think that is a matter that could well be put before the meeting of corrective service Ministers which I understand is to take place in mid-July. I will undertake to ensure that all Ministers are apprised of Senator Spindler's concern and that of the Human Rights Commissioner, Brian Burdekin. No doubt we will be able to have a discussion then amongst all those who have an interest or responsibility for the condition of prisons in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his constructive answer. I would like to follow up on one particular point. He mentioned that for the Commonwealth to have power in these areas under this convention, the Parliament would have to pass an appropriate law in both Houses. Does the Minister favour such a law being introduced? Would he be prepared to introduce such a law?

—Quite clearly, Australia as a nation has undertaken to the United Nations that it will abide, within the Federal system, by an understanding with the terms of the convention. So, as a nation state, we have already indicated our preparedness to be subject to the terms of that particular convention. Whether it ought to be translated into a law which would, by power of this Commonwealth Parliament, override State laws in relation to the conduct of prisons is a matter which would require further consideration.

PARA.TAB: I believe that, quite clearly, State prison Ministers and officials would want their prisons to be of such a standard and the operation of them to be of such a type that no-one could claim that they were places where we had cruel, inhuman or degrading imprisonment. I believe that that expression of support for that principle will emerge from the meeting of Ministers in mid-July. That probably will be a sufficient basis to ensure that this sort of statement by the Human Rights Commissioner should have no foundation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I understand that the negotiations for a chemical weapons convention are at an advanced stage. What is the Government doing in Australia's immediate neighbourhood to reinforce its efforts in Geneva to get a global ban on chemical weapons agreed shortly?

—As well as continuing to actively pursue the final negotiation of a global convention in Geneva, which is in the final and most critical stages of negotiation right now, we have been pursuing, since the then Prime Minister Mr Hawke initiated the exercise in mid-1988, a regional chemical weapons initiative designed to develop within our own immediate area of South East Asia and the South Pacific an active support program to stand behind that convention once implemented.

PARA.TAB: The program has sought to strengthen the existing regional consensus which exists against chemical weapons and to prepare countries of the region for early signature of the convention. We have successfully hosted two policy seminars on this subject in 1989 and 1990 and a technical workshop in 1991. This weekend there will be a further major seminar in Sydney of senior policy officials from 21 of the 23 regional countries—and that attendance reflects the close and increasingly intense interest this exercise is generating. We are looking for quite tangible outcomes from this seminar, in particular, agreement on practical preparatory activity by regional states. We will also be proposing the exchange of statements now of non-possession, non-production and non-development of chemical weapons as an action in support of the convention and as a kind of regional confidence building measure.

We are convinced that early adherence to the convention once its text is agreed, as we hope it will be in the next two or three months, by all states of the South East Asia and South Pacific regions, is a very important Australian economic and security policy objective. We are investing resources required to keep these issues squarely in the forefront of the minds of regional policy-makers and the basic strategy, as I have said, is to try to ensure maximum regional support for the convention because of the demonstration effect that will hopefully have in other parts of the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is it correct that the current Danish proposal to import live pigs with genetic material was first put forward in 1990 when it was raised at the prime ministerial level? What was the nature of the Government's discussion at that time concerning this issue; who did those discussions involve; and who in the Government knew about the proposal?

—If Senator Boswell is talking, as I think he is, about the proposal to import live pigs into Australia, there were discussions between members of the quarantine service and—I have a note here somewhere, but I think it is called this—the Danish Pig Corporation or something of that kind, which had with it in its delegation representatives of the company Danpork. Those discussions, I understand, which I referred to yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Boswell, took place in May 1990.

—I ask the Minister representing the Attorney-General whether he is aware of the US Supreme Court decision that a person abducted from a foreign country to the US may be lawfully tried in the US. I further ask the Minister whether he has any response to that decision.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I became aware yesterday that the United States Supreme Court in a six to three majority decision decided that it was lawful for the United States Government to seize suspects in a foreign country and forcibly return them to the United States for trial, notwithstanding that the United States has an extradition treaty with the foreign country concerned. I think that decision is a deeply disturbing one for the international community. It makes the question of proceeding under an extradition treaty something which is optional as far as the United States Executive is concerned if it wants to bring a person before a United States court for trial on some alleged offence.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought that honourable senators would find the notion of government sponsored kidnapping of persons overseas to bring them back for trial a deeply disturbing one. It certainly requires reflection by the Australian Government. The Attorney-General's Department is having a look at the implications as far as they may affect the structure of our extradition arrangements with the United States.

The Supreme Court seems to have taken the view that, in the absence of a specific provision in the United States-Mexican extradition treaty prohibiting the unilateral abduction of a suspect from the territory of one party by the other party, such abductions are permitted. As Australia does not have a clause in its extradition treaty with the United States expressly prohibiting kidnapping, it obviously raises at least the theoretical possibility of the United States exercising the option now sanctioned by the United States Supreme Court of abducting a person from Australia to face trial in the United States.

It has to be said that that would involve a breach of Australia's sovereignty and expose the United States personnel, or anybody else who committed such a kidnapping within Australia, to criminal sanctions under Australian law. Therefore, it requires a very deliberate reflection by the Australian Government on this judgment, and that will occur.

It is worth stating that this was a six to three opinion, which is a very substantial majority. Nevertheless, it may be of interest to honourable senators if I quote the dissenting judgment, which states that legal opinion:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . throughout the civilised world will be deeply disturbed by the monstrous decision the Court announces today.
This is the three dissenting judges. They went on to say:

It is shocking that a party to an extradition treaty might believe that it has secretly reserved the right to make seizures of citizens in the other party's territory. . . (It would make the treaty) into little more than verbiage.
As I say, there is a lot within both the majority and dissenting judgments for us to reflect on.

PARA.TAB: The general questions of international law, the rule of law and the status of extradition treaties which have been very painstakingly negotiated between nations in order to ensure the civilised presentation before courts of those who have sought safe haven in a foreign jurisdiction away from the ordinary law enforcement processes of the country in which it is alleged that a crime has been committed are all at risk. Therefore, I can assure the Senate that this decision and its consequences will be subjected to the most thorough reflection by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister and it relates to `porkergate'.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Government gets its collective snout out of the trough I will proceed. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's declaration to the Clerk of the House of Representatives that, on 15 May last year, while Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister, he invested in `a company which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business', but that this did not constitute a controlling interest and that he was not a director. Senator Button has continually claimed that `the Prime Minister's family company has invested in a joint venture company which is composed of Danpork and Brown and Hatton; the Prime Minister's returns and declarations of interest have been published in relation to that matter; and he has been absolutely diligent in declaring his interests'. Where in this allegedly full declaration by the Prime Minister is there any mention of Brown and Hatton, or Danpork, or any statement or even indication that he has in reality a half interest in the pig investment company involved in this multi-million dollar, multinational, payroll tax exempted joint venture in pigs; that his nominee is on the board; and that the joint venture stands to gain considerably from decisions by his Government, such as FIRB approvals or exemptions?

—If I declared an interest in a company—let us take BHP as a hypothetical example—as an investor in BHP it is not incumbent upon me, in making that declaration of interest, to follow down the corporate chain and tell Senator Baume or anybody else inspecting the register what investments or interests BHP has in various other companies. That is precisely what the declaration of interest system requires. It requires a member to declare an interest in a business, not to go through the corporate chain of any subsequent investments made by the company in which the member is investing.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that I described the Prime Minister as being diligent and proper in what he had done in respect of this matter. He not only made a declaration of his interests in May, as the honourable senator pointed out, but also made two subsequent declarations about changes in the investment which he had made and which was declared in May 1990. This of course contrasts with the situation of a previous government in this country which had no system of declarations of interests whatsoever. At least one half of the Ministry in that government—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question was asked in a concise form. The first part of Senator Button's answer attempted to equate a few shares in BHP with a 50 per cent interest in a greenfields project, which is clearly not any sort of comparable analogy. Now we are about to have the Minister defame Ministers of a previous government. I ask you to call him to order and ask him to answer the question in a relevant manner.
—There is no point of order.

—Senator Alston wants to walk along the trail of slime which has been left by the snail-like activities of Senator Baume. It shows how much he comprehends the issue. Never having made a declaration of interest himself and never having belonged to a political party which believes in declarations of interest, he confuses the question of declaration of a member's interests with the question of whether it is a greenfields company or an established company, whether or not it has to have FIRB approval and all of these sorts of things. I am surprised that in his point of order Senator Alston did not go on to say that it is a multinational company and use all of the pejorative terms which Senator Baume put into his question.

PARA.TAB: What we have seen from this grubby Opposition in the last week—I read the Hansard the other day and it is all there—have been the politics of envy from Senator Kemp; the politics of grubbiness from Senator Baume; the politics of xenophobia from Senator Boswell; and the politics of the National Party from Senator O'Chee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister is debating the question. I ask you to call him to order.
—There are too many interjections which are leading to long answers. I ask both sides to cease.
—Are you finished?
—Yes.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I was hoping the Minister might answer the question so I delayed jumping up. I remind the Minister that I asked where in the statement of the Prime Minister there was any mention of the names `Brown and Hatton' or `Danpork'; or any statement or even indication that he has a half interest in this venture, with all of the pejoratives, which stands to gain significantly from Government decisions. By way of a supplementary question, I ask the Minister: does he agree that interests, where a conflict of interest with a member's public duty could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise, should be stated? I take those words from the House of Representatives declaration of interest.

—I have already referred to Senator Baume's precarious hold on the front bench of the Opposition—a precarious hold which he seeks to secure by doing clean Dr Hewson's dirty work in the Senate. That is what is happening here. If Senator Baume looks at the conflict of interest provisions as adopted, which are set out in the register of members in the House of Representatives, he will see what the penalty is for failing to comply with the requirements of the register.

PARA.TAB: The penalty for failing to comply is that somebody in the House of Representatives gets up and moves that the member is in contempt of the Parliament for not having complied. But Dr Hewson does not do that. He sends this desperate creature, this refugee from a hundred shadow ministries, over here in order to do his dirty work for him. He does not even read the conflict of interest rules; he gets this bloke here to do it for him. I understand why Senator Baume has been a bit of a favourite of Dr Hewson. He has done all that for Dr Hewson in the past few weeks and I think he has made an indelible impact on Australian political life—the grubby side of Australian political life. Senator Baume accused me of not answering his question.
Senator Lewis interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Lewis does not understand it, the answer to the question is this: in terms of the Prime Minister's investment in his family company, the Prime Minister has done everything he is required to do by rules which this Government introduced and which those people opposite did not even support and did not support in the Senate at any time.

—I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Will the Minister confirm that the latest figures from the OECD Quarterly Labour Force Statistics show that Australia is fourth behind Italy and Portugal, with 38.8 per cent of the total unemployed in Australia being between the ages of 15 and 24 for the last quarter of 1991? Secondly, with youth unemployment now standing at 46 per cent in Victoria, does the Government acknowledge the possible link between teenage suicides and youth joblessness as outlined in recent reports? Finally, will the Government ensure that young people, their concerns, their ideas and their aspirations are given an opportunity to be heard at the forthcoming youth jobs summit, or will the summit simply be another window-dressing talkfest for the Government, bureaucrats and peak lobby groups?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not familiar with the OECD statistics as quoted by Senator Sowada. However, I do not have any reason to doubt the accuracy of her quotations as reflecting the statistics of the comparative situation between Australia and other countries. Senator Sowada asked whether I acknowledge a causal link between the level of youth unemployment and youth suicides. I have to make it clear, as I think I have done on behalf of this Government—and this Government makes it clear at every opportunity—that none of us take joy at all in the level of unemployment and certainly not the level of youth unemployment or adult unemployment. It is unfortunately true that, where people are without occupational opportunity, that does lead in some cases to depression which can lead to suicide. So there is a link. I do not think it is as well established as the research might require, but I do acknowledge that there is a link of some sort, and that is further reason for our concern at the level of youth unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sowada asked me, thirdly, whether there is going to be an opportunity at the forthcoming youth summit for the voice of young Australians to be heard. I am not aware of the representational arrangements being made for the youth summit. I am sure, however, that an opportunity will be provided for young Australians to put their views directly to leaders of government, industry and trade unions at that youth summit and that those views will weigh heavily with the Government when we draw from that summit our conclusions and what actions might follow.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Does the Government recognise that Tasmania produces what is generally regarded as some of the highest quality superfine merino wools in the world, a fact endorsed by the representatives of wool mills from as far afield as Germany, Italy, France, the United States and Japan, who regularly attend the Launceston wool sales? If the Government does value the Tasmanian wool industry, is it prepared to intervene to ensure that wool sales are not lost to Tasmania as a result of the new 25,000 bale minimum limit which has been set down by the Wool Industry Council? Does the Government acknowledge that the loss of Tasmanian wool sales to the mainland would seriously hinder Tasmania's reputation as a producer of high-class wools and, therefore, inevitably the future of the industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course the Government recognises that Tasmania produces very high quality superfine merino wool. In the list of nations that Senator Calvert read out as having international interest in the Tasmanian wool product, I think he mentioned Italy, which regards itself as the purchaser of the very highest quality merinos and, unfortunately, sells the cloth to the richest people in the world.
—Like Keating!
—I must say, Mr President, that by any test I do not think we could say that the Prime Minister of Australia is numbered among even the richest people in Australia; nowhere near it.

PARA.TAB: The remaining question that Senator Calvert asked me relates to what treatment the Australian Government will give to wool producers in Tasmania in relation to wool producers elsewhere in Australia. I must say that while one is entirely sympathetic to the situation in Tasmania, nonetheless there needs to be equal treatment for all wool producers. I will refer this element of Senator Calvert's question to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and see whether he wants to make any further comment on the matters that he has raised. If he does, I will promptly report them to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the Legislative Council of the British Virgin Islands led by the Honourable Cyril Romney, the Leader of the Opposition. On behalf of all honourable senators, I welcome the delegation to the Senate and to Australia. I trust their visit will be both informative and enjoyable.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators—Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given the campaign run by housing industry organisations against proposed changes to the Industrial Relations Act to protect workers operating under subcontracts, can the Minister inform the Senate of the effects that the changes will have on housing prices? Is it true that prices for building contracts will increase markedly if workers are protected under the law?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It will not have any impact on housing prices. In his question, Senator McKiernan referred to housing industry organisations. I should be specific. It is the Housing Industry Association which is the reprehensible organisation in the housing industry. Other industry organisations, such as the Master Builders Association, are not in that category. The Housing Industry Association has behaved, I might say, in a most reprehensible manner. The advertising campaign that it has conducted has been an unmitigated flop. No doubt the reason for that is that it is fundamentally based on a lie. That lie is that award rates will flow to subcontract workers because of the subcontractors Bill; that lie is that subcontractors will be required to join a union; and that lie is that housing prices, as a consequence of the two foregoing conditions, will rise, as it says, by 15 per cent.

PARA.TAB: That is the most fraudulent exaggeration of the circumstances that it is possible to imagine.
