There is absolutely no truth in the allegations, and I now formally challenge the HIA, if it wishes to continue with its advertising campaign and those lies, to submit its claims to an independent arbitrator. I would be very pleased on behalf of the Government also to submit our allegations to an independent arbitrator and have the matter determined fairly and openly so that the true degree of lying on behalf of the HIA can be revealed.

The other thing that has to be said about the performance of the HIA is that not only is it prepared to lie about the Government's position, but also it is an organisation which is a stooge of the Liberal Party—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, on a point of order: it is quite improper of the Minister to say that a distinguished organisation such as the Housing Industry Association is lying. I ask him to withdraw.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Not only is it prepared to lie about the independent contractors Bill, but also this organisation, which is a stooge of the Liberal Party, supports the consumption tax. The consumption tax would impose higher costs on houses for home purchasers in Australia and impose on subcontractors a massive cost in the huge administrative burden they would be expected to wear.

PARA.TAB: Treasury has estimated that a 15 per cent consumption tax will have a net cost impost on the industry of $800m per year. That is an additional $800m even after the removal of wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, et cetera. In the residential construction industry, Treasury has estimated that housing prices will increase by about 3 per cent. This means, for example, that an average Sydney home will cost an additional $5,700. Moreover, the GST will increase the cost of furnishings and of maintaining a home: carpets, whitegoods, repairs—

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator Bishop

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr President: you declined to rule in favour of my last point of order, but I would remind you that on 26 November 1991 you said:

INTERJECT.PARA: . . . questions to Ministers must relate to the subjects within their ministerial responsibilities.

You further said that for `a Minister to comment on Opposition policies is out of order, unless the question is linked to the Government's intentions and some matter of ministerial responsibility'. Clearly, the answer the Minister is now giving is debating the question and does not relate to his area of responsibility. I ask you to uphold your previous ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop, you know that there are ways that questions can be asked about Opposition policies and there are ways that they cannot be. I think the Minister is being relevant at this stage but, like the majority of answers today, his answer is becoming too long.

—Let me conclude, therefore, Mr President, by saying that it is also beyond doubt that the compliance costs related to the GST will be enormous to HIA members, particularly those with smaller business. Consider the remarks of Mr Cedric Stanford, a leading British authority on value-added taxes. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: The compliance costs of the small firm were 260 times those of the largest firms. Where small firms are competing in the same market as the larger firms they have been put under a state created disadvantage.
Indeed, Mr Stanford found:
. . . compliance costs . . . became a factor in helping to push small firms out of particular markets.
I conclude by saying that, if the HIA acted in the interests of its members, it would declare the consumption tax off and support the contractors Bill as on.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the fact that the Federal Government is a signatory to the Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and is therefore bound by its provisions, can the Minister advise what steps have been taken to find an alternative to the use of chlorofluorocarbon 113 for finishing proof and commemorative coins at the Royal Australian Mint?
—That question is far too hard for me. I will have to get an answer from the Treasurer about that matter. I will do so as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and concerns Cambodia. What is the Australian Government's assessment of the pressures towards a breakdown of the Cambodia peace process, given the recent statements and actions of the Khmer Rouge? Given that the Khmer Rouge refuses to attend and continues to refuse to allow its troops to be disarmed, can progress still be made at the Tokyo conference next week? What steps is Australia taking to further isolate the Khmer Rouge from the material support it had been receiving from China and Thailand? In particular, what hope lies in any new approach by the interim government in Thailand appointed by the King this week? With regard to China, what influence has the Minister sought to bring to bear concerning Cambodia in his talks today with the Chinese Foreign Minister?

—As I said on the weekend, it is certainly too early to make any judgments that the settlement in Cambodia is imminently in danger of complete breakdown. Opinions differ as to what precisely is motivating the Khmer Rouge to engage in its present attitude of non-cooperation. There are some aspects of the position of the Khmer Rouge which do lend themselves to some rational discussion and consideration by UNTAC, by the SNC and by the other countries that are concerned with a sensible outcome to this matter.

PARA.TAB: Other aspects of the Khmer Rouge's position do have a bloody-minded quality about them, which rather demonstrates a lack of seriousness of purpose as far as the settlement is concerned. But, as I keep saying, it is premature to make any judgment as to whether this indicates some fundamental change of position on its part or whether it is an exercise in brinkmanship designed to secure advantage or an improvement in its position in various ways. The balance of judgment at the moment is in favour of the latter characterisation but, clearly, if this non-cooperation continues for too long, whatever the motivations and whatever the nature of the rationale for its position, it will have the same effect: there will be a breakdown of the peace settlement.

Everybody is extremely conscious of that—the Chinese no less than anyone else. In my discussions today, there was a very clear reaffirmation by the Chinese Government of its support for the settlement process, its concern to ensure that there is a comprehensive and serious implementation of it by all parties—internal and external—and agreement with the proposition that I put. The proposition was that, among other forms of pressure that should be applied at the moment, there should be a very clear message delivered to the Khmer Rouge that, if the settlement were to break down, it would be utterly and completely isolated: it would be a pariah as far as every country in the world is concerned. There was very explicit agreement to that proposition from the Chinese, which I found a welcome reaffirmation of their position.

We are engaged in close discussion with Thailand. Discussions as recently as last night—I saw the cables a few minutes ago—suggest that the Thais are acutely conscious of the significance of their geographic role and the contribution they can make to maintain pressure in securing peace. I do not want to go into detail at the moment about the kinds of strategies that are currently being contemplated to put pressure on the Khmer Rouge and also to persuade it by dealing with such problems as it might realistically have. That is something that I will be discussing with foreign ministerial and other colleagues, including Mr Akashi, in Japan on Sunday and Monday. I will now be getting to the Tokyo conference a day earlier to enable some of these political discussions to take place.

Our hope is that, with that conference and with continuing discussion and pressure emanating from the UN Security Council, and perhaps a graduated series of responses over the period ahead, plus the kind of bilateral pressure that can be directed towards the Khmer Rouge—particularly from those countries which have a long tradition of direct association with the Khmer Rouge—this situation can be contained and the settlement process can be put squarely back on track. I repeat: there is no cause for immense gloom or pessimism about the settlement process at the moment but, obviously, it is finely balanced at the moment, and obviously everyone is working very hard in a whole variety of different contexts to try to ensure that it does not break down.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. Four days ago the Minister contemplated that the UN peacekeeping force could be removed or withdrawn. What circumstances led to that assessment?

—I simply said four days ago that which is the logic of the whole situation. If the peace plan completely breaks down and is acknowledged by the participants to the Paris conference to have broken down, then there will be no choice in the situation but for the UN to leave. Its mandate will be unable to be implemented. It is a peacekeeping mandate. It is premised on the existence of agreement and it is premised on the existence of commitment to that agreement by all relevant parties. That is the logic of the UN intervention, and in the event of a breakdown the UN will have no option but to get out.

PARA.TAB: That would obviously be a tragic outcome. That is what we are all trying to avoid. I do not believe that anyone should get too anxious about setting timetables or precise criteria to identify when the process may have broken down. That is something that we are going to have to keep following very closely and make a decision about when we are closer to that unhappy eventuality, which I hope will not happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier in Question Time today, Senator Alston misrepresented me by linking me with the spurious Opposition Treasury figures on the employment impact of the SGL. He claimed that at a press conference earlier today I agreed that 45,000 jobs would be lost. I did not agree. I have never accepted the assumptions that the Opposition put into the Treasury modelling. Senator Alston and Dr Hewson have deliberately and wilfully embarked upon a scaremongering campaign to frighten the public. The fact of the matter is that the loss of 100,000 jobs was a worst case scenario based on assumptions by the Opposition that there would be no wages offset. The Treasury minute says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . these results are based on the assumption that the SGL would result in a net increase in real unit labour costs. However, this assumption is not regarded as reasonable—

and it is not regarded as reasonable. As a result of our negotiations, SGL will be taken into account at any national wage case. I said that Democrat negotiations have halved the impact in the short term and have protected the positions of the 250,000 employees who work for employers with payrolls under $1m. If job losses occur, they cannot be laid solely at the feet of the SGL. The Opposition has lost this argument and it knows it. Voluntarism as an approach to retirement incomes policy is a failure. It is rejected by the Australian population. The editorials of most major newspapers agree with this and the Opposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I rise on a point of order. This is a debate to recover from being caught out with hands on both sides of the blanket.
—Order! Senator Kernot sought leave to make a personal explanation, not a statement, so please do not turn it into a debate.
—I am not going to. I ask for that comment to be withdrawn. I am sick and tired of the offensive remarks made by the Opposition. I ask for that remark to be withdrawn, Mr President.
—I am sorry, but I did not hear the interjection.

—It is just another variation on ladies of the night, political prostitutes, whatever he wants to say—hands on both sides of the blanket. It is offensive to me, Mr President, and I would like to see it withdrawn.
—I hotly deny that. I never said anything about ladies of the night or political prostitutes. I said that Senator Kernot was caught out once more.
—Order! These expressions were used last night and were referred to me this morning for comment. For the better order of the chamber, Senator MacGibbon, would you withdraw that last comment you made.

—I withdraw that. I can understand that Senator Kernot gets enormously emotional when she is caught this way. She might overcome her emotions to such a degree that she can listen, and listen accurately, to what is going on in this chamber. I am quite happy to listen to—
—What happens when you get caught in that way?

—I am never caught out in this place; I think before I speak, unlike people like Senator Sherry and, quite obviously, the Democrats, who never think at all. They just get up and carry on in the way they have this afternoon.
—Order! Senator MacGibbon, you have withdrawn the comment. Senator Kernot.

—Thank you very much. I have 10 seconds to go. I was about to suggest that the Opposition sit down and look again at this fundamental part of its superannuation policy. There are parts of it that I think are good; this fundamental part is flawed.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—Nobody could misrepresent you, Richard.
—Least of all you, Robert.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take exception to Senator Kernot's assertion that I have deliberately and wilfully misrepresented her position. Senator Kernot well knows that I quoted her both in the press conference this morning and in the Senate this afternoon as saying that, as a result of the Democrats' so-called achievement in changing 5 per cent to 4 per cent, job losses would be halved. I have gone on to say that we can all work out what figure that might involve, but as Senator Kernot and I are in heated agreement that the Treasury figure is a worst case scenario—
—On your assumptions.
—Just let me explain because, clearly, there is an urgent need for a personal explanation.
—You interrupt everybody else; why shouldn't we interrupt you?
—This is an appalling denial of democracy. The fact is that Treasury's figures were not based on any assumptions of mine. Treasury simply said that if you assume that the full labour cost—
—Garbage in, garbage out is what they said. They are your figures.
—I will explain that, too, if Senator Sherry persists in wilfully misrepresenting the position. Treasury said that if the full unit labour cost is to be borne entirely by employers—
—But you said it would be.

—It is not a matter of whether I said it would be. Treasury said, `if'. It makes its own assumption. Treasury said that up to 45,000 jobs would be lost over a two-year period and up to 100,000 jobs lost over the next five years. I should have thought that we are in agreement. This nonsense about garbage in, garbage out, which was trotted out by Tony Cole when he had to be wheeled in to pick up all the pieces, was in the context of someone asserting that somehow we were saying that that must be the outcome of the SGL. No-one said that at all.

PARA.TAB: I am very disappointed that Senator Kernot does not acknowledge that what I am saying and what she is saying is that that is the worst case scenario. I go on to say that all the evidence indicates that the burden will be borne entirely by employers because there is nothing to indicate that there will be any offset against wage losses. In those circumstances it is quite unfair.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr President. Clearly, Senator Allmouth is debating this issue. He is not making a personal explanation; he has moved into a debate.
—I make the same remark to Senator Alston as I did to Senator Kernot: it should be a personal explanation.

—Mr President, I take the point. I do not want to get into a debate about the merits of compulsion or voluntarism. I am simply concerned to explain that my position has always been that there is a worst case scenario of up to 100,000 jobs being lost.
—Based on your assumptions.
—It has nothing to do with my assumptions.
—It is on your assumption.

—No, on anyone's assumption. If the full unit labour cost is borne by employers that is the outcome. The only alternative, Treasury said, is that the burden is borne by employees, and we know that is not on because the Government will not agree that any discount may be taken into account 10 years down the track. Therefore, it is quite unfair and misrepresents my position to say that I am accusing Senator Kernot of saying 45,000 jobs will be lost.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that if we assume the burden will be borne by employers, that is the outcome. Senator Kernot will halve the 100 to maybe 50. That is the logic of what follows from her answer. This morning she conceded that she did not know what the extent of job losses would be, she simply knew that there would be job losses. I am perfectly entitled to claim that one should assume that the burden will be borne by employers. I hope this appalling misrepresentation does not happen again.
Senator Hill—I seek leave to move a motion in relation to an answer given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate to the first question I asked today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

PARA.TAB: Senator Button—Mr President, leave is not granted but leave can be granted on the assumption that the debate concludes at 4 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion standing in my name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: I get five minutes to do that. I think it is deplorable that this Government is not prepared to allow a debate on the most serious issue facing Australia at the moment: unemployment, and particularly youth unemployment. It will allow no longer than three-quarters of an hour to debate such an important issue.

PARA.TAB: I want to raise this issue particularly in relation to the two answers that Senator Button has given to me on this subject this week. The first answer was on Tuesday when I asked him what his Government was going to do about the record levels of youth unemployment—34 per cent overall according to the official statistics and up to 45 per cent in my State of South Australia. His answer to that was, `I am not going to tell you; I am not going to say what this Government's policies are going to be to address this appalling level of youth unemployment in Australia'. It was a totally unsatisfactory answer.

I raised the same issue again today and asked: `What is the Government going to do about the record levels of youth unemployment?'. What was his answer? Firstly, and in a most offensive way, he tried to suggest that the Opposition could gain some pleasure from such a national tragedy. It was highly offensive and contributed nothing worth while at all to the debate. Secondly, he had a swing in passing at the goods and services tax without recognising that the purpose of the goods and services tax is to enable taxes to be lifted off production so that jobs can be created in this country, so that business can once again expand, grow and create jobs.

Thirdly, he sought to attack the figures of the Australian Bureau of Statistics, to talk down the figures. It was the same strategy adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) two days ago when, rather than face up to the consequences of his Government's policies, the recession we `had to have', and the consequences of that upon unemployment in this country which is now at record levels, he also attempted to talk the figures down. Those figures are what they claim to be. For the benefit of Senator Button, I will remind him of what the Assistant Statistician said on the ABC AM program this morning:

SPEECH.PARA: The unemployment rate is defined as those who are unemployed as a percentage of those who were either employed or unemployed.

The unemployment rate for young people under that definition, the always accepted definition in this country at the moment, is a deplorable 34.1 per cent, over one-third. As I said, in Victoria youth unemployment is 46 per cent on the official statistics; in South Australia it is 45 per cent on the official statistics. So rather than simply talk down the figures, the Government ought to face up to that reality and put some policies into operation. What does the Prime Minister say he will do? All we have got out of the Prime Minister is the suggestion that he will now call a youth jobs summit.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had one in 1985.

—We have had many summits. This was the recipe of the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. Rather than taking action, the Prime Minister would call a summit to talk about the issue. We do not mind conferences that occasionally bring forward initiatives or ideas that might in some way be implemented by government. We do not condemn that sort of consultation and public communication. What we do condemn is when such summits simply become an excuse for inaction, and that is what they have become under this Government.

PARA.TAB: Finally, in answer to my question today—I pressed Senator Button twice through points of order to give us an answer on what the Government will do about youth unemployment—he basically said, `Well, when the recession is over the economy will expand and there will be some jobs created for young people again'.

On this side of the chamber we regard that answer as totally unsatisfactory: an appalling failure by this Government to stand by its responsibility as the elected government of this country. It has been a sorry tale that has continued for too long. There was nothing for the unemployed youth in the last Budget. There was nothing for the unemployed youth in the One Nation statement, which simply offered more tax cuts that were unfunded—in other words, further borrowings on the $150 billion that this country already owes. There has been nothing constructive and positive put down by this Government at all in answer to this tragedy. Instead, we get these attempts to attack us, to attack our policies and to talk about what happened in 1982 and 1983. Those opposite do not talk about what is happening today, that is, about these record levels of youth who are out of a job, who deserve to have the opportunity of employment and deserve to have a government in this country that recognises the extent of that tragedy and is prepared to implement policies that will give these kids a chance. That is what this Government is not doing and what it ought to be doing; and the Government ought to be prepared to debate it in this chamber today. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the suspension of Standing Orders, my offer in respect of this matter not having been taken up by the Opposition. Let me say, just to get a few facts right, that this Government inherited an economy with 157,600 full time unemployed people of 15 to 19 years of age. There are now 131,100, a fall of almost 26,500. Even if all of the 14,500 discouraged 15- to 19-year-old job seekers were added in, there are still fewer unemployed youth now than there were in 1983. That is no comfort for the Government.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill chides me for saying that the burden of unemployment will be alleviated as we get growth back into the economy. I say that in the historical context of this economy, because that has been the experience in previous recessions, and was certainly the experience coming out of the Howard induced recession of 1983. That was the experience. We do not derive any particular comfort from that.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was no such thing as a Howard induced recession. It was a world recession, and you know it.

—I suppose the honourable senator has not noticed. I am enjoined by those opposite to deal with the present situation and not go back to the past. Is the honourable senator saying that there is not a world recession now? Is he saying that the rate of unemployment amongst young people under a conservative government in the United Kingdom is less than 12 per cent? Is he saying that? If the honourable senator wants to talk about the contemporary situation, I am quite prepared to do it.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill says that we make comparisons with 1982-83. Of course we do, because this is an economy subject to cyclical fluctuations in which these sorts of consequences, tragically, in terms of unemployment happen. The point about the job seekers in that group is simply this: it has been said and alleged publicly in various places by representatives of the Liberal Party, amongst others, that 34.5 per cent of those in the 15- to 19-year-old age group are unemployed. That is not true—that 34.5 per cent of those who are seeking work or in work are unemployed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Isn't that shocking?

—It is shocking, Senator, but it is much more shocking to tell lies about it in public, which suggest that half the people in that age cohort are unemployed. That is the suggestion which has been made.
—What rate do you get when you talk about the adult unemployment rate?

—Senator Baume should go back to his snail trail and do Dr Hewson's dirty work over here. He should not interject about this matter, which is a serious matter and his shadow responsibility. In the One Nation statement which Senator Hill talks about, there were a number of measures which attempt to alleviate this burden.

PARA.TAB: Senator Cook and Senator Baume interjecting—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! Minister, take your seat, please. There are interjections across the chamber and neither of the two senators interjecting is participating in the debate. I ask that the Minister be heard in some degree of quietness.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are five pages in the One Nation statement to which Senator Hill refers derisively relating to apprentices, assistance to at-risk second-year apprentices, group training schemes, continuation of pre-vocational places, Jobskills additional funding, Jobstart additional funding and the Jobtrain scheme. All those matters relate to young people who are seeking employment in the work force.

PARA.TAB: I told Senator Hill in Question Time today that the Government was extremely concerned about this matter and was examining some other possible measures. Senator Hill always comes in here and says, `What are they?' and I say, `When we have dealt with them we will announce them'. That is an answer that the Government gives and it is not a matter for the suspension of Standing Orders.(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COULTER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the suspension of Standing Orders at this time. Yesterday, the Opposition complained bitterly when we moved a suspension to raise a very important issue in this very area. In the last year 40,000 jobs have been lost in Victoria alone in the textiles, clothing and footwear industry as a direct result of tariff reductions, but the Opposition would not support a suspension on that matter.

PARA.TAB: This proposal has arisen out of an answer to one question from one Minister. This is an important issue and it deserves thorough and comprehensive debate. It should not be trivialised and raised as a consequence of one answer from one Minister on one day. If the Opposition thought this matter was so important, why did it not raise the matter by way of an urgency motion or an MPI today instead of trying to do what it is doing here. This is indeed a very important matter, but it needs to be debated at much greater length than the time given to us today.

Regarding the Opposition's proposal, which it continually repeats, that the GST is in some way an answer to unemployment, I wish to make a few points from an independent survey carried out by chief executive officers, the head of corporate Treasury and finance directors of the top financial and business institutions around Australia. The conclusions are:

SPEECH.PARA: A widespread concern that the probable effects of the introduction of a GST had yet to be even generally understood and `factored in' to business operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. This is a debate on the suspension of Standing Orders and Senator Coulter is talking about somebody's views on whether a GST is introduced.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—The honourable senator will take her seat. There is an understanding in this chamber that senators cannot pull points of order when senators only have five minutes to make their point.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought there was a general understanding that, once we had restricted the time to half an hour for a suspension, we could generally indicate why we do not regard this as important. The survey went on to state:

SPEECH.PARA: The majority view—
this is the majority view of business leaders—
is that a GST will be inflationary. . .
The Opposition is talking about jobs and so on, yet as a core part of its economic strategy it is proposing an inflationary measure which will lead to higher unemployment. The survey states:

One frequently expressed view was that the introduction of a GST would provide business generally with a mechanism and an opportunity to pad their margins, which have been squeezed over recent years; with the anticipated confusion from the introduction of the GST, simply blame an inflated price hike on the new tax.

In other words, industry would become less productive of jobs and employment. Again, this is the major alternative proposal that we are hearing from the Opposition. The next point that the survey states is:
There was general recognition that the Australian economy, and the eventual recovery, will be influenced by the international `big players'.

This does not have anything to do with the Australian economy at all. I stress that these are important issues, but they are not the sorts of issues that can be debated briefly this afternoon. They are probably the most important and fundamental issues that need to be debated in this place, but they should not be debated with the sorts of time constraints that have been imposed on us at this stage. Therefore, we will not support the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —We want a full debate on this issue. That is why I am supporting this very important motion. Nothing is more important to this nation than the welfare of its youth. When we have 34 per cent of our youth out of work—
—Forty-six in my State.

—and 46 per cent in some States, but 34 per cent overall—we have a national disgrace on our hands. What is the Government doing about it? What policies is the Government putting in place? One of its policies is an increasing superannuation levy. How many jobs is that going to give the youth of Australia? It is going to take another 45,000 jobs away from Australians. So that is a great policy to get youth back to work.

PARA.TAB: The training levy is another Government policy. Who is going to put on more people when he has to pay a training levy and then get another left-right cross with a superannuation levy? I ask people in the Senate: is that going to increase employment for our youth? The answer is no, it will not create one extra job.

What about the industrial relations legislation that we have just put through with the help of the Democrats, who have concertinaed all these major Bills into a very narrow time gap. I ask honourable senators: is putting 800,000 subcontractors into unions going to create any jobs? It will not create one job. How many jobs will it shed? How many jobs will be created by putting interest rates up to 27 per cent?

We are seeing this Government putting policies through like they are in a sausage machine; policies which are going to take job after job away from Australians. We ought to be able to debate this issue. The Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) said that he was extremely concerned and wanted a full debate. It is in his hands. If he wants a full debate of an hour and a half, an hour, or however long it takes, he has only to show a bit of leadership in his party and we can have that debate: we can argue it out; the people will be able to decide whether they want these policies that the Government has produced in the last two weeks—these major issues that have been concertinaed by the Democrats by not allowing debate—and we can debate the policies fully.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is all your material available?

—I can go for half an hour if I have to. I have a personal interest in this because I have a son who, after trying to get a job for six months, has finally succeeded. I am terrified that the policies that those opposite have put through in the last two weeks will cost him that job for which he has battled for six months. He had been knocking on doors and coming back saying, `Is there something wrong with me?'. The policies that the Government is putting through are going to deny children like my son a job and I am very worried about it.

PARA.TAB: We have the most expensive childminding service in Australia. We have hundreds of thousands of children in school that want a job. We have them locked up in TAFE colleges, but they want a job. They want to get out there and be part of the productive sector. But the Government is not providing any opportunities. We have children in all sorts of training programs who get a job for six months and then go on the dole. I have had them working in my office. All they want is a chance to get into the productive work sector. The Government has denied them that chance with the policies that it has put through and jammed into two weeks.

How many jobs has the Government cost Australia with its superannuation levy, its training levy, its industrial relations levy and its 27 per cent interest rates? The Government has cost this nation plenty; it has cost the children of this nation plenty. Those opposite do not deserve to be in government, and they will be out of government as soon as there is an election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is synthetic anger, an example of artificial outrage, by the Opposition. The Government offered leave to those opposite to debate this matter which would have meant a debate of 45 minutes. They have chosen this route which means a debate on a suspension of Standing Orders motion that goes for 30 minutes. If the outrage that is being expressed and the passion that is being brought to this debate by the Opposition were true, and not synthetic or artificial, one would have expected that the offer by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, for a debate would have been accepted. But it was not, and we now have the situation in which we are debating a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, which is being used as a pretext to talk about unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Government has chosen the high road to reform the Australian labour market. We have chosen the high road of high skills, of training and of workplace flexibility. We have made a commitment to those as the essentials to create an economy in which we have a highly skilled work force, an increase in school retention rates, increases in university and training populations, an increase in the population in TAFE and a spread and flexibility in the TAFE courses that are offered. We want to make our economy world competitive, based on high skills. That is the commitment we have made.

We are in a world economic recession. We are experiencing a collapse of prices for our trading commodities and, it has to be fairly said, monetary policy may have been squeezed too hard for too long. We are in that situation, but we are not in a bleak situation. The Government's One Nation statement provided the blueprint for us to come back into recovery.

Most accepted leading indicators at present show positive growth. The trend in motor vehicle registrations continued to improve in April; dwelling approvals went up by 9.7 per cent in April; the ANZ vacancies index went up by 1.4 per cent in April and 0.9 per cent in May; the CES unfilled vacancies went up by 2 1/2 per cent for the March quarter; ABS vacancies went up by 3 per cent in the March quarter; ABS overtime went up by 6 per cent for the same period; and the DEET skills vacancies survey has risen steadily since May 1991. They are indicators that are important to the outcome of employment prospects for all Australians and, in particular, young Australians.

This Government has foreshadowed a youth meeting to focus on the problems of young people in Australia. The essential ingredient of that approach has to be to find the high road to better skills and training. That is not something that is without recognition in our performance. We have an Opposition talking about intention. Our performance is that we have doubled school retention rates during our period of office; we have increased the number of university places to 113,000, and almost doubled the tertiary participation rate since 1983; and we have created, as I said in Question Time, the equivalent of 17 new universities in Australia since 1983.

In addition, $13 billion is being provided for higher education in the 1992-95 triennium. In the One Nation statement $720m has been provided to TAFE to create a higher status, better resourced vocational education and training sector. In the first 10 months of 1991-92, almost 75,000 young people have been involved in vocational education and training. We will develop a more flexible entry level training system to build on the best features of the apprenticeship system.

That should be compared with what the Opposition is proposing under its consumption tax package. There is nothing in the consumption tax package for young Australians. The Opposition does not really care about training. This was admitted by Mr Howard on 7 March when he talked about dead-end jobs and when he asked why we could not hark back to the romance of the 1950s when people could get—he said it—dead-end jobs. There will be no unemployment benefit after nine months. People will just be thrown onto the unemployment scrap heap.

The abolition of the CES and youth access centres is a feature of the Fightback package, as is the downgrading of TAFE. University fees will be introduced so that only the rich can go to universities, with the poor fending for themselves on the basis that somehow that is fair. That is the Opposition's alternative: to destroy the labour market support mechanisms necessary to ensure a highly skilled, flexible work force in Australia, able to adapt to new technology in changing international economic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion to suspend Standing Orders. I think it is absolutely vital that this issue is discussed and that it is discussed today. I commence by referring to some remarks made by Senator Coulter—they were offered as an explanation, but did not amount to an explanation—as to why the Australian Democrats do not want to support this motion. It basically comes down to not much more than a childish tit for tat: You didn't support me when I wanted it, so I won't support you now.

PARA.TAB: But it was worse than that. Senator Coulter went on to say, `This is just one question to one Minister', but it is a vital question. One of the most vital questions facing Australia today is: what will this Government do about youth unemployment? The question was not addressed to any old Minister; it was addressed to the Minister responsible for unemployment. It was the most vital question addressed to one of the most responsible Ministers on that issue.

Let us not dismiss this matter, as Senator Coulter would have us dismiss it, as being something that is just a desire to debate one question to one Minister. It is the most vital question to one of the most responsible Ministers, the Minister responsible for unemployment. Therefore, Senator Coulter's explanation as to why he will not support the suspension of Standing Orders is totally unsatisfactory. He says, `This is an important issue'—guffaw, guffaw—`we can discuss this another day'. That is typical of the Democrats—put it off somewhere else. It is a bit like the Marshall Islands inquiry. They said that was a political issue. God spare us if we ever have a political issue in the Parliament! Heavens no! Let us foist it off to another body, another day, another place. Let me come here, sit, take my salary, pretend to be a member of parliament and take no responsibility. That is what the fairies at the end of the garden are about.

Let us dismiss the Democrats' attempt at an explanation and look at why we should discuss this issue, apart from the fact that it is the most vital issue facing Australia today. The reason we should discuss it today is simply this: the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook), the Minister responsible for unemployment, is purporting to support what his Prime Minister (Mr Keating) is trying to do—rewrite the statistics. The Minister is trying to say that if someone says youth unemployment in Australia is 33 or 34 per cent—in my State it is 46 per cent—

TALK.START.PARA: —It isn't.
—That is right—exactly what the Minister says—it is not.
—It isn't, so you're lying about it.
—The Minister says that I am lying. Mr Acting Deputy President, do not bother picking him up, because we all know how much notice anyone takes of him.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! The Minister will withdraw that remark.

TALK.START.PARA: —I withdraw the word `lying' and substitute the word `untruth'.
—You cannot get away with that either, you dope.
—I withdraw the word `lying' unequivocally.
—The Minister will apologise. He will withdraw both words. The words `untruth' and `lying' are not acceptable to the Chair.
—I apologise, Mr Acting Deputy President. I withdraw the word `lying' and the word `untruth'. I think it is fair to say that Senator Vanstone has misrepresented the facts.

—The point we need to make today is this—the Minister has come up with it again—the Minister says that it is an untruth to say that the unemployment rate is 33 1/2 per cent. He wants us to say, `Out of all the young Australians, 33 1/2 per cent are not unemployed'. Let the Minister answer this question when he gets a chance to speak: what would be the national unemployment rate if we expressed the number of people looking for work as a percentage of all Australians?'. If we included babies, primary and secondary school students, retired people—if we included everyone, even though they were not looking for work—does the Minister know what our unemployment rate would be? It would be less than 2 per cent. He should go to the supermarkets and the butcher shops and try to sell the fact that we have an unemployment rate of less than 2 per cent and see what happens. He would be laughed out of town. That is what is happening with youth unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is that 33 1/2 per cent of young Australians who are looking for work—that is the normal expression in an unemployment rate—cannot find it. Forty-six per cent of young people who are looking for work in my State cannot find it. It is irrelevant that some of them are still at school. It is only relevant to the extent that a lot of them are still at school because they cannot get a job.

Most countries do not express any other employment rate as a percentage of the whole population, as I understand it. It is the percentage of people looking for work who cannot get a job as a percentage of those who are looking for work. That is not telling a lie; that is telling the truth. One-third of young Australians who want a job cannot get it and the Minister is trying to con Australia into believing that it is one in 10. It is the most deceitful, disgusting and disgraceful exercise that his Government has ever entered into. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the motion to suspend Standing Orders we have seen the Opposition, offered by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) an opportunity to discuss the substantive issue of youth unemployment for 45 minutes, reject that offer and opt for a debate—including no-hopers such as Senator Vanstone—on procedural matters for 30 minutes only. That sums up members of this Opposition: they are carping, negative critics. They have been given the opportunity to be positive and to make a substantive contribution; they know that they have no contribution to make so they opt for a procedural debate and put forward speakers, such as Senator Vanstone, who are not capable of putting a case and who do not understand the substantive issues before the Chair. They have made gooses of themselves again.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—Order! The time allotted for this debate has expired.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Senator Short—Mr President, I seek leave to move a motion that the Senate take note of an answer by Senator Cook during Question Time today to a question by Senator Sherry on youth unemployment.
Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the contingent notice of motion in Senator Hill's name, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to provide for the consideration of matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to take note of an answer to a question without notice.

SPEECH.PARA: All Australians will be appalled at what has happened in this chamber in the last half hour. The Government and its acolytes, the Australian Democrats, have stifled debate on the most serious, urgent and tragic problem facing all Australians today, which is unemployment. The problem is not just youth unemployment—although that is the important focus of what we have been talking about—but also the unemployment of two million Australians who either cannot find work or are unable to find satisfying work in terms of the number of hours they want to work.

PARA.TAB: All Australians would be appalled not only at the refusal by the Government and the Democrats to allow this matter of great national urgency to be debated, but also, if they had been watching Question Time today, at the disgraceful display—I can say it in no other words—that Senator Button gave in response to a question from Senator Hill on this matter, and at the response that Senator Cook gave to a question by Senator Sherry.

Senator Button had the incredible arrogance to say that the coalition should not get, to quote his words, `overexcited about this situation'. Every Australian is pretty excited about this situation because not one Australian home or family is not touched in some way—most of them are affected directly—by the scourge of unemployment that Senator Button and his Government and its policies have produced. They are policies that the Government deliberately produced; which the now Prime Minister (Mr Keating), through his eight or nine years as Treasurer, deliberately pursued; and which have led to the greatest cost, hardship and recession that Australia has had since the 1930s.

Last night the Prime Minister said that the youth unemployment figures were, `a distortion of, in fact, the position'. He tried to tell Australians, including kids in his own electorate—which he would have had the greatest trouble finding, no doubt, because it is years since he has been there—that the youth unemployment figures were distorted and that, far from youth unemployment being 34 per cent, it was only about 10 per cent. I cannot think of a more disgraceful attitude and action that any Prime Minister could take at a time like this in our nation. He knows that that is simply untrue.

The Government's official statistical agency is the Australian Bureau of Statistics. The Australian Bureau of Statistics has an official definition of unemployment and official measures of the rate of unemployment. The Government's own statistical agency, the Bureau, says that the unemployment rate amongst 15- to 19-year-olds in Australia is 34 per cent. That figure is quite appalling. In my own State it is 46 per cent. In South Australia it is 46 per cent. If the Government does not believe those figures, it ought to tell its own official agency that it does not believe them and that they are wrong.

I will quote to the Senate the official agency's figures—the Government's own statistics—over the last two or three years. We now have 34.1 per cent youth unemployment in this country. Two years ago that rate was 15.8 per cent. When this Government took office in 1983, there were approximately 457,000 15- to 19-year-olds in full time employment. Today there are 253,000 15- to 19-year-olds in full time employment. In other words, during the period of this Government, full time youth employment has virtually halved; it has fallen by more than 200,000. There were 457,000 youth employed when we left Government in 1983; there are now only 253,000 full time employed.
Today, Julian Disney said that the Government had followed false policies; that is absolutely right. It is a disgrace that this matter cannot be debated. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, we are debating a motion that Standing Orders be suspended to take note of an answer by Senator Cook. Senator Short put forward an argument very much like the one raised in regard to a previous motion to suspend Standing Orders in respect of an answer by Senator Button.

PARA.TAB: This debate has centred around the issue of unemployment. Much argument is taking place as to the figures which represent the true level of youth unemployment in Australia. I would have thought that any level of unemployment was a tragedy. The people who have been listening to the debates we have had—one has already taken place in respect of an answer given by Senator Button in Question Time, as well as the present one—would be concerned about the way that we, as senators in this august chamber, and I say that most seriously, are carrying on.

I think what Senator Coulter said in respect of the first debate is absolutely correct: there are particular mechanisms which our predecessors in this chamber set up to enable debate. I think—and I am probably in accord with most people in this chamber—that there ought to be debate, and very serious debate, about the issue of unemployment, whether it be amongst youth or older people. I think that debate should be informed and structured so that the people who listen to us have a purchase on the sorts of solutions that we put forward.

The point about having an urgency motion or raising a matter of public importance is that it can be prepared. I think this is what Senator Coulter was saying. The procedures of this chamber are set up so that debate about very serious matters can take place in a very serious way, rather than somebody simply getting up at the end of Question Time and saying, `Look, a Minister has given a particular answer to a particular question; now let us have a debate'. This matter is one of the most essential matters that faces us as parliamentarians; it is one of the most essential issues that faces the Government and the community. It is wrong that that sort of debate should take place in an almost casual, ad hoc and unprepared way.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only because you are preventing the debate.

—Senator Short says that we are preventing that debate. If that is so, there are proper procedures, such as an urgency motion or a matter of public importance, which will enable us to debate the matter here. I am prepared to embrace those sorts of procedures and have a general debate about this. Let us extend the sittings of this chamber into July. My offer would be to put aside the first and second weeks of July to debate this matter.

PARA.TAB: A program has been set down by the Senate. Those opposite have tried to overcome the strictures that they see arising from that program. As a result of that, we are seeing proceedings which are very disruptive to a proper debate about unemployment. I think that we, as a Senate, must call ourselves to order and start treating this issue not as an adversarial procedure whereby we can throw insults at each other across the chamber but start facing it squarely in the interests of those people in Australia, particularly our youth, who are suffering most grievously.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make three points as we debate the motion to suspend Standing Orders. Firstly, I want to put on the record the fact that this is obviously a major problem facing this country; one that, no doubt from listening to Senator Cooney and previous Opposition speakers, everyone is aware of, concerned about and determined to do something about. However, when we look through the Hansard record for this year so far, we can see that in 31 sitting days we have already had 212 debates on this issue. The issue of unemployment has come up 212 times. It has been discussed and debated. One really wonders what we are achieving doing it yet another time in this very ineffective and inefficient way.

PARA.TAB: I can only go back over some of what Senator Cooney has already said about urgency motions and MPIs where we do have an opportunity to prepare formal speeches and to put the matter back on the agenda. At this point I must remind Opposition senators that they are the ones who are complaining about the shortage of time; they are the ones who are complaining that we have had to restrict the amount of time we spend on each piece of legislation. Yet here we are now, one hour and five minutes after Question Time, and still we are nowhere near the stage of considering any legislation.

That brings me to how we can actually achieve something in this place. It is not by yelling at each other, by throwing insults backwards and forwards across the chamber and debating ad nauseam. We can actually achieve something in this place by voting on legislation. When we eventually do get back to legislation today there is an excellent opportunity for Opposition senators to prove that they really are interested in young unemployed. They can do that by not supporting the Government, which is cutting yet again the amount that young unemployed people are able to receive by removing the access to a training allowance for under-21s. Opposition senators come in here and say, at length, that they are concerned, but when it actually comes to doing something, we are very close to calling them hypocrites.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am supporting the motion to suspend the Standing Orders so that we can have debate on this matter of urgency. Senator Lees has just put the most outrageous proposition to us. We have discussed youth unemployment at previous times, and now it seems we are being told that if we do not think about it the whole problem might just go away. That is totally unacceptable.

PARA.TAB: We are seeking to take note of the answer that was given today in the Senate by Senator Cook because there is obviously a concerted campaign which was begun by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) this morning. He knows that he cannot defend his record on unemployment, so he sets out to rewrite the figures; just as he set out to rewrite the history of Australia because he has a chip on his shoulder about our origins and about our flag. So now he wants to rewrite the official figures.

Senator Vanstone set out very clearly what we are discussing; that is, 34.5 per cent of youth looking for work cannot find that work. That is a pretty simple definition. For the Prime Minister to have the temerity to come out and say, `Oh, it is not really all that bad; it is really only two in 10', is just a nonsense. To have Question Time used in a dishonest way with, firstly, Senator Button reiterating the statement and, secondly, a dorothy dixer designed so that Senator Cook could do likewise simply cannot be allowed to pass without being objected to.

This is something totally different from Senator Cooney's concept of wanting a structured, contrived debate, where the likes of Senator Coulter can send away for a speech from his speech writer and stand up and read it. That is one of the reasons why he is not agreeing to this suspension of Standing Orders; he was not ready to debate it because he had not had somebody else do the work for him. There are a lot of people here who get outraged and insensitive when people on the other side deliberately try to mislead the Australian people, and that is precisely what happened today. It is a well-known technique; it was well used by Goebbels. Perhaps we ought to call Senator Cook Senator Goebbels-Cook, the Minister for disinformation, to go with his title of the Minister for unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McCarthy-Bishop.

—Senator Button wants to try to be a smart alec by coming across with some other epithet. He is a great one for epithets. The bottom line is that there is a distinct and deliberate campaign of disinformation coming out of this Government. The line of disinformation is: ignore the young; they really do not matter at all; let us pretend that they are not unemployed; let us pretend that the next generation is not to be cared for at all.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Button that there are a lot of people in this Parliament who have children of their own who would like to see that they have a future, not people who think that the problem can be solved by pretending that the figures are inaccurate and really that the Government's record is somehow worthy of upholding. In fact, the Government's record is deplorable: one million are unemployed and, of those one million, 34.5 per cent of young Australians seeking work are disbarred from working.

That is with the concurrence of these Democrats over here who apply the guillotine. That is with the concurrence and active participation of Senator Cheryl Kernot, who went around initially making all the right noises of concern about the superannuation legislation. But at the end of the day it was not a matter of if the Democrats would agree with the Government; it was a matter of when.

The real question to be asked is: what was the deal struck in order that it would occur? I am not talking about the deal that we see that brought the levy down from 5 per cent to 4 per cent. What was the deal done that we are not told about? What was the coercion? It was not a question of if they agreed; it was a question of when.

We now have, courtesy of the Democrats and the Australian Labor Party, new legislation which will force a minimum of 45,000 Australians out of work. That is the figure that Senator Alston rightly used today; that is the figure that the Government and the Democrats pretended they were not agreeing with earlier. Now they say, `Let's not debate the issue here because it's even more embarrassing'.

Let us look at the merits of the case. The Government attempted to put out a line. Senator Button was the first advocate; Senator Cook was the second advocate; the Democrats were the backup team. Well, it is not good enough; and that is why we have had two motions for the suspension of Standing Orders—so that the truth can be put on the record.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again we have to dispel the myths that have been perpetrated by the Opposition. Opposition senators want to spend time discussing issues that they do not have facts for. They do not use the correct premises. As we have seen with the superannuation figures, they are again using false premises.

PARA.TAB: I would like to take Opposition senators back to 1983—a very good year. How many youth were unemployed? How many 15- to 19-year-olds were unemployed when the Opposition was last in power? Let me tell Opposition senators that there were a heck of a lot more. We have actually dropped the figure quite drastically. A reduction of about 21 per cent has occurred since we have been in power. These are the sorts of things that those opposite choose to overlook and neglect to mention. They should take more care with things like numbers. When those opposite lost power there were 157,600 unemployed teenagers. I am sorry that those opposite do not care to take note of this or believe these facts.

The shadow Treasurer (Mr Reith) keeps saying that nearly one-third of teenagers are unemployed. He does not seem to be able to understand that not all teenagers are actually out looking for work. A large number are still at school. In fact, there has been about a 100 per cent increase in the number of students staying on at school to improve their education; to actually use their education to gain experience and training and to broaden their range of scope, activities and opportunities for later on in life. It is now apparent that about 10 per cent of the youth are unemployed. That is in fact a lower figure than the general unemployment figure—something that those opposite do not seem to be able to comprehend. However, that is their problem.

Our figure of slightly less than 10 per cent of youth unemployed compares with the previous government's figure in April of 1983 of 12.4 per cent of youth unemployed. Even those opposite should be able to understand those statistics. They are not terribly good at understanding statistics, but surely they can comprehend those statistics well enough to know that we have actually been able to do something about this particular issue. That is obviously not the case, though; they are rather slow learners.

I think that we should in fact look at the Fightback program and what that is going to offer to youth. It is a whole 664 pages. The only attempt in it to address the needs of the at risk young people is a hollow statement about helping young people to make the transition from school to further training. There would of course be full fees at university, so no families on AWE or less would have any chance of their children actually being able to gain access—none at all. Instead of creating a new expanded system for vocational education and training as we are, those opposite are offering a one-off increase of $75m in 1993-94 for that area, and nothing else; nothing else for TAFE. They just want to discard it completely. That is not even enough to cover demographic growth.

Those opposite, of course, are the same people who will abolish the dole after nine months and expect people to live on fresh air and water—they probably will not even be able to live on the water because that will be charged for as well through the 15 per cent GST as part of local government charges. A part of Fightback would slash spending for the labour market program area by $140m. A great help to the youth that would be. Those opposite would cut Jobstart wage subsidies by $62m—a further great start. They would abolish the self-employment assistance program. Wonderful people! They would amalgamate CES and DSS and contract out job placement services at commercial rates. Really and truly, how do they expect us to believe that they really care or have any real concerns about this particular issue? They are just here grandstanding.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion moved by Senator James Short for the suspension of Standing Orders to consider a response by Senator Cook to a question relating to youth unemployment. It is important, I believe, for the Senate to debate that particular answer because that answer attempts, unfortunately, in my view, to hide the real problem of youth unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Whatever we do, whatever action we take, must be based on the facts—must be based on the truth of the matter. The truth of the matter, clearly, is that we have record youth unemployment in this country despite the number of young people who are hidden away in TAFE colleges, universities and, indeed, secondary schools who would otherwise very vigorously desire to be in the paid work force. So we do have to look at this situation.

It is all very well for the Democrats to say, `We have debated this time and time again'. I make no apology for getting up here time and time again and raising this question—not just recently, but over a number of years, as honourable senators will realise. In fact, I did warn of the enormous social disruption and dislocation that would occur if policies were not put in place which would give the youth of this country a fair go. Unfortunately, that situation has not arrived.I ask whether all honourable senators remember Priority One.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes!

—Oh, yes. Priority One was about youth and youth employment. That is buried now. I have not heard of Priority One for a long time. I see Senator Button smiling there at the table. I have asked the honourable senator on a number of occasions whether this Government, and indeed other governments around the country, considered youth as priority one in their employment approach. Time and time again I got up here and proved conclusively that they did not consider youth to be priority one and that, in fact, the employment of youth in the Public Service was declining dramatically.

PARA.TAB: I believe it is important that we do debate these things. I was very attracted to Senator Cooney's suggestion that we meet in the first two weeks of July to consider all of those questions. I am prepared to put down a notice of motion to that effect tomorrow. I pause now for any support, and to ask Senator Cooney whether he and his colleagues will support that motion. There is dead silence. I did not think they would be prepared to do that, but it would be an enormous benefit if they did. I will support the motion for suspension of Standing Orders to consider the answer by Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to express my disgust at the completely inadequate attempt by the Government to address the circumstances of youth unemployment in this country today. The appalling attitude of the Government was displayed vividly in Question Time today by Senator Button, and also last night by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in his response to what was happening in Bankstown. The Prime Minister, and Senator Cook in Question Time today, had to hide and try to play down the problem and declare that only 10 per cent of youths were unemployed. This was a crude distortion by Mr Keating of devastating statistics in an attempt to run away from the problem rather than addressing and correcting it. The stark reality is that only two out of 10 young Australians actually have a job.

PARA.TAB: Youth unemployment was measured by the Australian Bureau of Statistics in May at 34.1 per cent. Quite clearly, this means that, of all the teenagers looking for work, more than one in three are unable to find a job. This is indisputable, despite the fact that Senator Cook wishes to twist the interpretation of the ABS figures. However, this 34.1 per cent does not include the youths that are underemployed and those that have enrolled in training or education programs because they have no alternative but to apply for the Job Search allowance. It also does not apply to those who despair of ever finding a job and, therefore, are not even able to declare themselves as looking for work.

From this, it can be seen that youth unemployment is even higher than the ABS is able to determine. According to the ABS, 14,500 Australian teenagers have stated that they are discouraged job seekers. This statistic is from September last year. Since then, we have had an entire year of school leavers enter the job market, and we do not know how many of these are going to end up in a situation where they despair of ever finding work.

Therefore, in reality, youth unemployment is higher than 34 per cent. The problem of youth unemployment is not something that has suddenly occurred; the problem has been around for quite a while. But, while the Keating Government was intent on engineering the recession that we had to have, the youth unemployment figures exploded. In 1989-90, the youth unemployment figure was 15.8 per cent. In 1990-91, it had grown to 23.1 per cent and it now sits—conservatively—at 34.1 per cent.

It is disgraceful that this Government can ignore the plight of our youth; the future of the country. It is a bit like Nero fiddling while Rome burns, and this Government should be condemned for it. The Government has not yet come up with a suitable response to the youth unemployment problem. That was completely obvious from the pathetic attempt by Senator Button to answer the question that Senator Hill asked of him during Question Time today. Senator Button did not even attempt to answer the question.

What is the Government planning to do? Well, there has been a vague suggestion that there should be a youth summit; a belated attempt to address this issue. However, to date, the Government's major response has been to shunt our youth off into training programs and higher education institutions. The result of this action has not been very helpful. Our universities and vocational education centres are already overcrowded and underfunded. Squeezing more students into them without injecting corresponding funds only serves to lower the standards of higher education and vocational education in Australia. The other problem is that the Australian economy has been destroyed to the extent that this Government cannot provide the jobs that are needed for our youth.(Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Order! The time allotted for the debate has expired.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Short's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the Government's response to the interim report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: Hon. Peter Staples MP
Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services
20 March 1992
Senator A O Zakharov
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Olive
I am writing in response to the interim report on the implementation of pharmacy restructuring measures, handed down on 19 December 1991 by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs.
The interim report has focused on a number of specific issues. Broader policy issues arising from the interim report have been addressed by the Government in the course of the inquiry.
Eligibility Criteria for Essential Pharmacy Allowance (EPA)

The committee found the EPA administrative arrangements unnecessarily complex, disadvantaging some early applicants seeking the allowance. The Government has acted on this finding, to simplify administrative procedures by removing the requirement for an annual application for EPA, and providing early applicants who were disadvantaged with retrospective payments.

The removal of the annual application for EPA has provided additional security for the small business owner. Instead of the annual application, the onus will be on pharmacists themselves to advise the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) of changes in their eligibility status for the allowance.

Applicants who applied for EPA before 30 June 1991 may have been disadvantaged by early administrative processing delays. This occurred despite the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority (PRA) holding extra meetings to cope with the large volume of applications. The Government has provided retrospective payments from 1 January 1991 to applicants who were disadvantaged. Administrative arrangements were improved from 30 June 1991 and no applicants seeking EPA have been disadvantaged by administrative delays from that date.
Unmet Public Need

The Committee raised concerns that applications for pharmacy approvals involving claims of unmet public need should be more definitive, in particular it was felt that a set of criteria should be established for applicants to meet in order to be recommended for a new pharmacy approval.
The Government met with the Pharmacy Guild on a number of occasions in an attempt to develop more definitive criteria that might be used by the PRA in assessing applications claiming unmet need.

Despite attempts to develop more definitive criteria, these were considered unsatisfactory as they tended to be so liberal as to potentially qualify every applicant for a new pharmacy or alternatively would be so strict that it would be extremely difficult for any applicant to meet the criteria. There was agreement, moreover, that the only way in which criteria could be developed which would be sensitive to the individual circumstances of particular towns or locations would be to investigate every potential pharmacy location in Australia, document the particular circumstances which influence patient access to prescription medicine and somehow incorporate these into a definite set of criteria. This is clearly not a practical option.

The paramount consideration in considering applications for unmet public need should be whether the absence of a pharmacy in a particular location creates intolerable problems of access by patients to the extent that health outcomes may be compromised.

On the basis of these discussions I wrote to the Guild and the Chair of the PRA reaffirming the principles of pharmacy restructuring and supporting the existing PRA Guidelines for assessing unmet public need. The Guidelines do not take the form of `hard and fast' criteria which the applicant has to meet but rather are a number of indicative questions, which encompass a range of considerations which influence whether there is a demonstrated unmet public need.
Lack of Appeals Mechanism to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal
When the PRA was set up, no internal appeal mechanism was developed as it was envisaged that normal appeal mechanisms would operate including:
lodging appeals with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal;
challenging the decision in the Federal court of Australia; and
appealing to the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

Following an appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, the tribunal ruled that it had no jurisdiction in the area because of the wording in the Act. The Government moved to immediately amend the National Health Act 1953 to allow aggrieved applicants access to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The amendment was made retrospective to the date the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority commenced operation.

In concluding I would just like to reiterate that the initial administrative problems and processing delays occurring with the introduction of the Pharmacy Restructuring Authority have been addressed. The administrative processes are now measurably better and there are no longer delays in processing pharmacy applications. In addition, any significant policy issues which have emerged throughout your inquiry have been expeditiously addressed.
I await the tabling of your final report due I believe on 28 April 1992.
Yours sincerely
Peter Staples

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —As yet, I have not actually seen the report of the Standing Committee on Community Affairs on the implementation of pharmaceutical restructuring measures. Since I was responsible for moving the motion which led to the establishment of the inquiry by this Committee, I want to say a number of things. I thank my colleagues on the Committee and I pay tribute to the staff of the Committee who worked enormously long hours on a report which actually grew as time went on.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tate said at the time that such an inquiry was unnecessary. The Committee found a large number of problems associated with pharmacy restructuring. A significant problem was that pharmacy restructuring was based on a press release. No guidelines were given to the officers responsible for implementing the pharmacy restructuring. So it was not clear what was meant by `prior financial arrangement'.

The pharmacy restructuring program sought to reduce the number of pharmacists. There were limitations on when a pharmacist could get a provider number. If it had been established that a pharmacist had entered into a financial agreement with, say, a developer of a large shopping block before a certain date, that was taken as evidence that an arrangement had been entered into and the person would be given a provider number. Following a date which I cannot remember, people were limited and maybe not able to do that.

The Committee uncovered some not-so-proper interactions or exchanges of documentation. It also found that a number of people had been disadvantaged financially; in fact, some of their livelihoods were threatened. It was also found that the implementation of this had not been terribly well thought through. For example, the officers were operating on a press release and not on guidelines, which was totally unacceptable.

This is a warning to every other profession which gets into bed with the Government and wants an arrangement made to have that profession restructured—radiologists, pathologists and other groups. The lesson is that there are inherent dangers in the Government trying to plan with, for example, the restriction that a pharmacy cannot open within a certain distance of another. Senator Walters brought up the case of a pharmacy in her State which wanted to open up, but the 30 kilometres was down a very long, winding road. Thirty kilometres in a hilly area in Tasmania might be very different from 30 kilometres in another area.

The issues that this Committee has been looking at are very broad. I remind honourable senators that it was implied by the other side that this was totally unnecessary, and that this Committee has had to have an extension of time to investigate and look at these issues. As I said before, it is a warning to professions. If they want the Government to organise things, they might find themselves in the pickle many pharmacies found themselves in as a result of pharmacy restructuring. I look forward to the presentation of the full report, as this is only an interim one, and will speak at more length then.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
