SPEECH.PARA: I would like to speak briefly to Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No. 8: Managing Risk in Procurement put out by the Department of Administrative Services with regard to managing risks in procurement. One of the basic attributes of any business is its ability to purchase. The Federal Government in fact spends some $10 billion on goods and services each year, and just a plus or minus 10 per cent movement in that figure means a plus or minus $1 billion in either savings or additional expenditure.

PARA.TAB: One of the observations I have made in the shadow portfolio of administrative services at the various forums I have been to is that probably the best purchasers that the world has seen for many years are the Japanese. It is a lesson to go to Japan to see how they carry out their purchases. They carry them out effectively without an awful lot of nonsense or bureaucracy. Their purchasing system is a cooperative effort. They like to see a big spread of suppliers, even to the extent where, in some instances, additional moneys are paid for commodities to keep the number of suppliers large, rather than limited to a few, so that they do not end up being caught in the pincers of a monopoly or duopoly or whatever.

One of the things that have happened in recent times within the Government concerns risk management. The chart on page 20 is a little horrifying, because it indicates that there will be an incredible increase in the bureaucracy of various departments. One of the things this Government has done is to go into financial management improvement programs, which I believe is absolutely correct in principle. I think it falls down, however, in the purchasing area. In both the public sector and the private sector—and it does not matter which we are talking about—good purchasing people are a very rare commodity. The Government has split these people up so that the central purchasing group within DASET—and I am no centralist by a long shot—has to a large degree been decimated. I think it is a big mistake. I think we need to have a central purchasing group which should comprise, de facto, a member of each department, so that it can coordinate purchasing.

In the time left to me I would like to refer briefly to common use contracts, which have been basically destroyed. They are of no useful purpose to anyone these days. To a large extent, this has been caused by the Minister who intervened in the famous Nashua case. Honourable senators might recall that a limited list of people was prepared for common use contracts in the computer consumables area. The Minister intervened and put one of the unsuccessful tenderers back on the list. The only way the Department could get the Minister off the hook was to go from six or seven people, who were initially successful, and put 22 people on the list. This is absolutely ludicrous.

If the Government wants to go down the route of having acceptable tenderers, that is fine. But the way it sits at the moment, being on the successful list in respect of a common use contract guarantees nothing. All it means is that one is on a list and one can then negotiate with the various departments and sell one's wares. People who have tendered under these conditions have said to me that it is an absolute waste of time and energy because they are quoting twice. They say that it is not workable.

The other issue that should be drawn to the Senate's attention is this ongoing pain in the neck of unlimited liability in regard to IT purchases. The One Nation package made reference to this matter. But this reference was very woolly. We were not told which way the Government was going to go, only that it would be looked on an item by item basis. Of course, because of the Government's buying power, unlimited liability conceivably could mean that the suppliers of a $100 item could find themselves defending an action by the Commonwealth for tens of millions of dollars. That is utterly unsustainable. It does not occur in the private sector. I believe that the Government must look at this matter fairly quickly.

I want to refer to another matter that is totally unacceptable. I know that the Government believes it can put up Chinese walls. The Department itself is going into partnership with other private sector people. It will be quoting to itself. It believes that it can put up so-called Chinese walls and divorce itself from the tendering processes as against the decision making processes, and that every effort will be made to be at arm's length. No-one in the community will believe that, if the combination of the Government and a private sector group is successful, the decision will be above board. I believe that the Department should not be involved in this sort of thing; it should get right out of it altogether. I think things like propriety and probity are more important to the Government in its role of purchasing essential goods and services. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The document, Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No. 8: Managing Risk in Procurement, is not really significant in terms of content. Without being unkind, it is rather light and inconsequential from that point of view. But the interesting thing is that the Government feels it is necessary to reinforce some of the principles that we have had for years with respect to tender assessments and the procurement of goods and services by the Government. There certainly is a very great need for that because the Commonwealth, particularly under this Government, has slipped badly with respect to guaranteeing the integrity of the process.

PARA.TAB: We are dealing here with not only the expenditure of public funds but with all the things that precede it—things such as the calling of the tenders, the registration of interests and the assessment of those bids to ensure that the process has been fair and accurate. The Government must guarantee to the limits of its ability that there is absolute honesty and integrity in this process. It must be like Caesar's wife—it must be beyond suspicion.

There are two fundamental reasons for this. We live in a democratic society and we live by a rule of law. The community observes that rule of law on a voluntary basis. In a democracy we are not compelled to obey the law; we do so out of respect for the common good. It therefore follows that the public must respect the administering authority—that is, the Parliament. Particularly in relation to funds, the Parliament is given the right by the community to tax and to levy charges from the community. The other side of the privilege, if it could be called that, of levying taxes is that the Government must be beyond reproach in the disbursement of those funds. That point must always be emphasised.

There is another aspect to the whole business of tendering. Companies dealing with the Commonwealth are often involved in tenders that run into hundreds of millions of dollars, and even larger at times. They invest man years of work in the preparation of those tender documents and, for a major contract running into $200m or $300m, the cost of preparation of a tender by a company might well be of the order of $1m. That is big money. The expenditure of the money does not guarantee the right to win the contract, but it should carry with it the right to a professional assessment. That should go without saying.

There are occasions in the past, and currently before this Government, where that professional assessment has not been made. As I said earlier, there has been a slipping of the processes which have been set in place for the last 30 years in this country for the assessment of major contracts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have anything particular in mind, Senator?
—The Minister can laugh about it.
—Forgive me; I am not laughing at you.

—Forgive me; I should not have said the Minister was laughing about it. We have gone down a path and developed processes. I am putting to the Minister that at present those principles are not being applied as assiduously as they might. Under these principles there is no guarantee that we get the right result, but at least we can say that we got there by an honest and defensible path.

PARA.TAB: There are a couple of contributing factors to this. One has been the change in the Public Service; the appointment of people from outside who have not served all their lives in the Public Service and do not understand the practices that have been involved. The second has been the growth of the statutory authorities, principally government business enterprises. Quite frankly, government business enterprises are now out of control and irresponsible. I am pleased that we will get rid of them when we are in government. There is a bunch of people there, often with no commercial experience at all, who believe that they are answerable to no-one. Of course, they are not.

There is a major conflict at present over the way the Civil Aviation Authority selected an air space contract, but it would be very wrong to regard the CAA's activities in relation to the TAATS contract as its only breach of protocol. At the end of my speech I will seek leave to incorporate a flight calibration of navigation aids tender that was put out by the Department. The Department advised people to tender and then said it would compete against them. Senator Parer talked about Chinese walls. How can an authority defend the intellectual property of a tenderer, respect the confidence of a tenderer and yet at the same time be competing in that tender? I seek leave to incorporate the document entitled `Invitation to Register Interest' in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: INVITATION TO REGISTER INTEREST
FLIGHT CALIBRATION OF NAVIGATION AIDS
CLOSING—CANBERRA, 31 JANUARY 1992
1.INTRODUCTION

The Civil Aviation Authority is restructuring its operations with a view to offering its services on the most efficient and cost effective basis possible. As part of this process the Authority is considering the best means to satisfy its flight calibration requirements, and the operations of the Authority's Flying Unit, which presently provides this service, are under review.
The Authority hereby invites Registrations of Interest from Government and private organisations interested at a later date in:
A)participation in a joint venture with the Authority to undertake flight calibration of navigation aids, and/or
B)provision and operation of a service to undertake flight calibration of navigation aids on behalf of the Authority.

All registrants should note, that while interest may be expressed in one or both proposals, the Authority has a preference for participating in a joint venture and registrants responding to Proposal A will receive first consideration.
All registrants should also note that the Authority's Flying Unit will be responding to this Invitation as if it was an organisation separate from the Authority.
Registrations submitted must consist of written statements of all information required to be submitted by Section 7 of this Invitation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I am also glad that Senator Button is in the chamber during this debate on Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No. 8: Managing Risk in Procurement. I have expressed these views to Senator Button in the chamber before. When this Government entered into its corporatisation program—which was a program designed to take certain business functions of the Government out of the control of the Public Service wage structure—it failed to address the other areas of safety which had been built into Public Service procedures over many years.

PARA.TAB: I have pointed out that those safety measures were adopted by Liberal-National Party governments over the 1960s and 1970s, no doubt at the very strong pressure of the Labor Party Opposition which would have been complaining about the nature of contracts that government departments were entering into. In order to demonstrate that government departments were entering into contracts on a fair, proper and reasonable basis, over a period procedures were developed to ensure that safety precautions were built into the procedures.

This Commonwealth procurement guideline is another similar safety precaution. As my colleague Senator MacGibbon has pointed out, what should have been statutory authorities, but which are now statutory corporations, have been taken out of the control not only of the Commonwealth Public Service wages structure, but also out of these procurement guidelines and such safety measures as the Auditor-General has in relation to government departmental procurement arrangements.

The Civil Aviation Authority is a perfect example of the way that these sorts of things have gone wrong as a result of the Government's corporatisation program. The Government should have privatised the various business arrangements rather than simply corporatise them.

There was an article in the Canberra Times on Monday, 15 June about the use of personal computers within the Commonwealth Public Service. What bothers me about a guideline such as this one that we are debating here today is that it does not cover what is happening currently. It talks about checking up on things after they have happened. This article says:
In Australia, the public service is moving to the position where there is a PC—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, a personal computer—
on everybody's desk. At the same time the Commonwealth has embarked upon a policy of no specialisation—all officers are to become generalists.

PARA.TAB: Typing pools have disappeared, the stenographer has vanished, everyone has a PC and more than 90 per cent of those Pcs are used mainly for the written word.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask Senator Button to address this matter and to come back some time in the fairly near future and tell the Senate whether the Public Service has adopted this procedure. If it has, it is a total waste of money for everyone to have a PC sitting on his or her desk. The Public Service ought to be using much more efficient methods; for example, a small typing pool with a very good word processing system which is able to take dictation from those people who need to express themselves in writing.

PARA.TAB: This article goes on to say:
Last year one particular department had $10 million of my (OK and your) money to spend, and in its feeding frenzy it spent it all on Pcs (or if you prefer, workstations).
This year that same department is upgrading its machines.

SPEECH.PARA: So a word processor, say, a 286, is put on everyone's desk, and then the people complain that they use it for only about 5 per cent of their working week. Then they complain that it is very slow, so now they want a 386; next year they will want a 486; the following year they will want a 586; and it will soon be a 786. What happens is that these second-hand machines are then sold—in effect, they are dumped back onto the market—because the Public Service of Australia has not been properly using them. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHORT
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I also want to make a couple of remarks about this document entitled Commonwealth Procurement Guideline No. 8: Managing Risk in Procurement. I do not want to go into detail about the contents of the guideline. It is one of a series of guidelines on procurement policy and professional practice which have been issued by the authority of the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) under finance regulation No. 42. The guideline in this case outlines the philosophy, principles and practices for managing procurement risk.

PARA.TAB: I want to endorse some of the remarks made by my colleagues Senator Parer, Senator MacGibbon and Senator Lewis. This whole area of government procurement is very important. Over the last few years, there have been major changes associated with the development of corporatisation of many functions of government and also with the introduction of the financial management information program. The whole theory has been to allow managers to manage within the public sector better than they have been able to before. In the process of moving away from the fairly rigid centralised controls that existed before over various areas of management activity—in particular, procurement—we have lost some of the checks and balances that did formerly exist.

It is clear that a number of serious concerns have been expressed about developments in recent years. Let me hasten to say that I am not arguing against the movement that has occurred in management practice. I think it is going in the right direction. But, in that movement, some of the checks and balances that previously existed have been lost. I am not sure that there is a lot of confidence out there—particularly in the private sector which might be supplying to government, seeking to sell product to government—that the new procedures and the new controls of checks and balances are adequate.

I think that is a matter, as Senator Lewis said to Senator Button—I hope Senator Button will respond in due course—of which we need to take greater account than we have in the past. Some examples which have caused concern come readily to mind. There was the Nashua issue of a year or so ago when Senator Bolkus, as the Minister for Administrative Services—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Facom issue; remember that one?

—There were several, including the Nashua issue when Senator Bolkus, as the Minister for Administrative Services, was involved in the tender process. There is also the matter that has attracted a lot of attention in recent days in this chamber and outside, and that is the deal that has been done in relation to the construction of the new building of the Australian Labor Party which will be the site for the headquarters of the Australian National Audit Office, opposite the National Press Club. An exceptionally good deal appears to have been worked out there so far as the Labor Party is concerned. That is a matter that, quite rightly, has raised several very serious concerns, not just on this side of politics, but more generally.We have had the complete shambles, at best, in relation to the CAA-Thomson air traffic system contract, and so on.

PARA.TAB: In relation to all of that I just want to make the point that the key elements in any procurement system must, first, include accountability. We are talking about taxpayers' money so, secondly, there should be value for the taxpayers' dollar. We must have open, transparent and clearly defined processes which are not able to be manipulated or distorted, so that the potential avenue for any fraud and dishonesty can be eliminated. Of course, the bottom line is efficiency, effectiveness and integrity. I am not suggesting that those things are not there at the moment, but the changes that have occurred in recent years have given us cause, or need, to look at those systems of procurement again. I hope the Government will do that. The coalition, on coming to government in a few months time, will certainly give that a high priority.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, on behalf of the President I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Audit Report No. 40 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Department of Social Security: Systems for the Detection of Overpayments and the Investigation of Fraud.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: This report, entitled Audit Report No. 40 1991-92—Efficiency Audit—Department of Social Security: Systems for the Detection of Overpayments and the Investigation of Fraud, is 165-odd pages long. Since it was only available during lunchtime, about two hours ago, one cannot always do justice to such a report.

PARA.TAB: However, I felt it necessary to speak on the report today because it deals with an efficiency audit of the systems for the detection of overpayments and the investigation of fraud within the Department of Social Security. In defence of the Department of Social Security, the Australian National Audit Office has found that on the whole considerable efforts have been made by the DSS to address the problems associated with its accountability activities. It also needs to be pointed out that data-matching, which the Department considers to be a very important mechanism in identifying fraud and incorrect payments, was not fully operating at the time of this particular audit.

In this report the Audit Office has seen fit to make a number of disturbing observations about the fraud control systems and procedures of the Department of Social Security. First, it was found that the DSS fraud control plan and the draft of the revised plan had been prepared without the benefit of a comprehensive statistical analysis of the incidence of incorrect payments and fraud. The Auditor recommended that high priority be given to developing a revised fraud control plan based upon a comprehensive, statistically based risk assessment.

Secondly, the Auditor found that DSS does not have a comprehensive program of random sampling by which benchmarks can be established for the incidence of incorrect payment, and risk based review work can be assessed. The Auditor recommended that the DSS develop benchmarks of the incidence of incorrect payment, by which the outcomes of risk based review work can be assessed. In its comments, the Department refused to accept this recommendation on the grounds of the strategic impact that data-matching will have with regard to random sampling. From my knowledge of the auditing and statistical analysis procedures entailed in DSS data-matching, it would appear that the Department's response in relation to this matter is understandable. I hope that the data-matching process will result in the establishment of accurate benchmarks.

Thirdly, the Auditor found that DSS management information systems are not utilised effectively for the management of fraud prevention, detection and prosecution. In particular, it was found that DSS management information systems and management practices do not ensure consistency in accountability between regions. The Auditor recommends in his report that DSS utilise its management information systems to ensure consistency in accountability activities between regions. In responding to the Auditor, the Department has claimed that it has long been committed to developing management information systems and an effective overpayment review system, and has replaced the suspected overpayment facility. In addition, a new debt management and information system is also being developed.

Fourthly—and I consider this to be probably the most important point—the Auditor found that there were large variations in accountability between regions and that there is no adequate management investigation to establish the reasons for such variations. These large variations in accountability outcomes include measures such as the proportion of reviews undertaken, the proportion of downward adjustments made as a result of reviews, the average amounts of overpayments identified, the proportion and amount of debts written off and the average amount of overpayment for cases referred for prosecution. In order to overcome this problem, the Auditor recommends that DSS management information systems be used to ensure consistency in accountability activities between regions.

It is vitally important that recipients of DSS benefits receive equitable treatment no matter where they reside in Australia. The charter of the Department of Social Security is `to deliver social security entitlements with fairness, courtesy and efficiency'. Adherence to the principles of fairness and efficiency must apply to all the Department's operations, including the collection of overpayments, the writing off of debts and the conduct of reviews.The Auditor has found that the number of overpayments recorded was proportionately smaller in the larger States—1.3 per cent in New South Wales, compared with 2.9 per cent in South Australia. The Auditor also found that the average value of recorded payments tended to be larger in the larger States—$1,084 in New South Wales, compared with $594 in South Australia.

I think most of my colleagues in this chamber would agree that it seems hardly fair that a person in one State is able to escape repaying an overpayment for a longer period than a person in another State; nor is it fair that DSS would place greater emphasis on chasing larger overpayments in certain States and not in others. Not only is it not fair, but also those people who accumulate a large overpayment, sometimes through no fault of their own—not through fraud—are then faced with a very large debt. If it is followed up earlier in one State than in another that means that some people face debts that accumulate over a longer period of time. There are two ways of looking at whether this is fair. I am arguing that there should not be regional differences; that, as far as possible, the processes of the Department ought to operate so that people are treated equally across the States and regions.

In its response to the particular finding of the differences across regions, the Department has claimed that the variations in accountability outcomes are not as significant as portrayed by the Auditor and that there is no evidence to conclude that external variables are not responsible. I believe that the matter of DSS recipients receiving equitable treatment, regardless of their place or State of residence, is one that cannot be so easily cast aside by the Department.

The Auditor found that had DSS reviewed the same proportion of beneficiaries in the larger States as in the smaller States, an additional 200,000 reviews would have occurred resulting in additional savings to the taxpayer. This is a significant variation that I believe cannot be attributed solely to external factors. I trust that the Department will give due recognition to this important finding from the Audit Office.

Finally, the Auditor found that DSS had no comprehensive program of quality assurance checks by which the appropriateness and method of discretionary decisions in accountability work can be assessed. It was recommended that a national system of randomly selected quality assurance checks be introduced throughout the DSS accountability process. The Department has responded that regional office assurance processes are in place and that the work is proceeding on the enhancement of these processes, as well as their extension to area office accountability processes.

I commend this Audit report to the Senate. I look forward to the Department of Social Security promptly addressing the deficiencies in the accountability processes which have been identified by the Australian National Audit Office, particularly those which refer to differences across regions and States.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992SOCIAL SECURITY (FAMILY PAYMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —I was speaking on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 before lunch. When I was interrupted I was making my third point that the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill will amend the eligibility criteria for Job Search and Newstart allowees to ensure that new arrivals are not eligible for support where a sponsor is willing to provide the applicant with support, it is reasonable for the applicant to accept that support, but he or she elects not to do so. The coalition supports this amendment which will reduce the administrative costs entailed in the assurance of support system.

PARA.TAB: In relation to new arrivals, this Bill will ensure that only New Zealanders who intend to stay in Australia permanently can receive special benefits. Again the coalition approves of this change, particularly in light of the fact that there has been an 82 per cent increase in special beneficiaries over the last five years.

Another change contained in this Bill is a decision formally to remove the training component of Job Search allowance for beneficiaries aged under 21. Earlier this year, the Social Security Appeals Tribunal found that allowees aged under 21 were eligible for the FTA. The SSAT decision was confirmed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in May this year, resulting in a situation whereby up to 50,000 young people may have been eligible to reclaim their unpaid training component. This Bill will reinforce the Government's policy of not paying the training allowance to under 21-year-olds on the grounds that it acts as a disincentive to undertaking secondary and tertiary education—and the coalition is supporting this initiative.

The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill contains a number of other minor amendments, including the attribution of a $2,000 income-free area for deeming; an extension of the pensioner assets test to sale or lease-back arrangements, mainly in relation to nursing homes and retirement villages; provision for the lodgment of some reviews at CES offices; and the inclusion in the Social Security Act of the common law right of privilege against self-incrimination. All of these changes are minor and are supported by the Opposition.

Finally, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill provides for a number of changes to social security data matching, the most important of which is the introduction of what is referred to by the Department of Social Security as `positive data matching'. In layman's terms, this means that the Government will be able to use its data matching facility to identify people who are eligible for but who have not claimed benefits. Those who remember the data matching legislation in 1990 will realise that this positive data matching has a quite different objective to that originally put forward by the Government for its extended use of the tax file number; that is, the prevention of fraud and the rorting of the public purse. I will speak further about this matter at the committee stage of the Bill.

The second Bill being debated is the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill will restructure the payments made by the Department of Social Security to families with children. While the coalition supports these changes, as they will reduce some of the poverty traps faced by sole parents and low income families, it needs to be pointed out that they are largely cosmetic and certainly nowhere as comprehensive and far-reaching as the family assistance measures contained in the Fightback package.

As a result of this Bill, family allowance will become the family payment, and the family allowance supplement will become the additional family payment. The components of income support paid to DSS recipients in respect of children will be separated from the pension or benefit and integrated with the family payment. To provide a more even spread of income support, the family payment will be paid during the alternate week to that of the fortnightly payment of pension or benefit. All child add-on payments will now be paid to the primary care-giver. Rent assistance will become part of the family payment. Guardian allowance will be extended to low income sole parents receiving the additional family payment, thus providing greater incentive for sole parents to return to the work force. The child add-on component of a pension or benefit will now be subject to the more generous family income test rather than the pension or benefit income test. The maintenance income test will apply only to the additional family payment.

Students still at secondary school who are over 16 and ineligible for Austudy will continue to get the family payment until they leave school or turn 18. DSS beneficiaries who return to the work force will automatically receive an application for the additional family payment. Finally, the additional family payment will continue to be paid during non-payment periods, such as benefit waiting periods.

In stark contrast to what I said have been largely cosmetic changes, a coalition government will substantially reduce the burden borne by millions of Australian families under Labor. When we win government, the Liberal and National parties will implement the largest ever tax cuts in this country's history, with taxpayers paying, on average, 30 per cent less in income tax. That is a point that is always forgotten when people mention the GST. Family allowance will be doubled for families with combined incomes under $30,000 per annum, while families with combined incomes between $30,000 and $40,000 per annum will have their family allowance increased by 50 per cent.

A coalition government will increase the dependent spouse rebate by $300 per annum for eligible families with children and with incomes under $50,000 per annum. A coalition government will also provide an additional $90m for increased child-care support, while an additional $50m will be given to voluntary agencies to the benefit of many families currently suffering financial and social hardship under Labor.

In the area of housing, the first home owners scheme will be reintroduced, and first home owners with incomes under $40,000 a year will be eligible for $2,000 assistance. In addition, the coalition will allow young Australians under 35 to withdraw up to 75 per cent of their superannuation savings to be put against the purchase of a home. A coalition government will also introduce a tax-free savings scheme whereby the first $1,000 in new savings income will receive a 30c in the dollar tax rebate. People will also be able to make rebateable superannuation contributions on behalf of a working spouse. These are only some of the substantial benefits which Australian families will derive from the coalition's Fightback package. While the initiatives contained in the family payment Bill are unarguably a step in the right direction, it is easy to argue that they are negligible in comparison to the massive benefits for all Australian families which will occur under, and which are contained in, Fightback.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend to the Senate the speeches by my colleagues Senator Newman and Senator Patterson. I believe that they have covered more than adequately the very significant legislative changes that have been enshrined in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill, the Social Security (Family Payment) Amendment Bill and the Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment Bill. Therefore, the only reason that I rise to speak at this point is to formally move the amendment circulated in the name of the Opposition by way of a second reading amendment, which draws formal attention to the matters just canvassed by my colleague Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: As she stated, the measures that will restructure and rename the family allowance and family allowance supplements are a step in the right direction; we acknowledge that. We recognise the greater degree of equity and balance that will arise from that restructuring. Nonetheless, we think it is essential that the Australian community be made very much aware of the derisory One Nation, pre-Wills by-election gimmick of a one-off payment which went out, as I recall, under the name of the Department of Social Security with all sorts of gratuitous references to the generosity of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). We have since discovered from surveys that it was simply dissipated to many families struggling to make ends meet in the way that one would expect.

That is the contrast that the Australian electorate has between the Government's token gesture and our very substantial $1 billion family package, which offers a doubling of family allowances for families with incomes up to $30,000 and a 50 per cent increase for families with incomes up to $40,000. We are also offering a whole range of other taxation incentives and payments, particularly a massive one-third reduction in personal taxation arrangements totalling about $13 billion.

This Government, which used to like to pride itself on somehow genuflecting in the direction of lower and middle income earners, seems to take the view these days that the old constituency does not matter any more. The Government is only interested in the fast end of town. As we recall with age pensions in the One Nation statement, the Government was not even prepared to offer tax cuts for those on incomes of less than $20,700. At the moment, those people are on a marginal tax rate of 20c in the dollar. Under the Fightback proposals, that rate will come down to 16.2c.

What explanation did the likes of Senator Richardson offer to the Senate? The answer was basically, `That mob had it pretty good during the 1980s. It is about time we moved on and tried to find some votes elsewhere'. That is the sort of callousness that underlies the Government's approach to families and low income earners. It is in stark contrast to the galaxy of initiatives that are contained in the Fightback package. I am delighted that the Senate will now have them encompassed in a second reading amendment, which I now move:

At the end of motion, add ", but while the Senate supports the restructuring of family payments, it notes and endorses the Liberal and National Parties' Fightback! package which contains very comprehensive measures of assistance for families, including: the largest ever cuts in personal income tax; the doubling of family allowance (or as it will become, family payment) for families with incomes below $30,000 per annum; a $300 per annum increase in the Dependent Spouse Rebate for families with children who are on incomes of up to $50,000 per annum; an additional $90 million in assistance for child care; the re-introduction of an improved First Home Owners' Scheme; and generous tax credits for low and middle income earners who take out private health insurance".
Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
Clause 1.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) a couple of general questions about the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill. Firstly, in view of the problems that people are having trying to interpret this Bill, as part of my speech during the second reading stage, I asked the Minister whether or not he would consider allowing the Australian Government Publishing Service to consolidate the Social Security Act annually. I asked also whether there should be only two start-up dates for all of the various changes that are foreshadowed and will actually pass through this place—for example, 1 July and 1 February.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the first point, I am told that a consolidation of the Act will be coming through in the next few months. That should, of course, make it much easier for people, as Senator Lees contends. In respect of the second point, I think it is fair to say that it would be very difficult to set two starting dates when sometimes we amend legislation which has immediate impact, depending on the circumstances. On the first point the honourable senator raised, she should derive some satisfaction from the fact that there will be some consolidation in the next few months.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for his answer. Perhaps I could rephrase my question and ask him to have two start-up dates as a general principle—unless something comes up as a matter of urgency, for example the recent statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). I will reword that slightly. I ask the Minister to try, as a matter of principle, to have only two start-up dates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will elaborate a bit more on the point I made earlier. Applying that sort of proposition as a general principle will lead to mechanical problems in administration. As I said earlier, there might be emergency situations. I will pass on Senator Lees's suggestion to the Minister as I am not in a position to either endorse it or reject it at the moment. On the face of it, there are some mechanical problems; but the suggestion will be passed on to the Minister.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to another matter relating to the section of this Bill that deals with third party consent, I seek the Minister's assurance that he will have stated very clearly in the guidelines relating to this provision the fact that the Department will at no time pressure or require spouses to agree to a deduction from their payments in order to pay for their partners' debts.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —We can give Senator Lees that assurance. I also indicate to her that the consent that may be obtained can be withdrawn at any time. I know the problem Senator Lees has, and I understand the reason why she would raise it at this time. I give her the assurance that she seeks.

PARA.TAB: I take this opportunity to table a supplementary explanatory memorandum and a further supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the amendments and new clause to be moved on behalf of the Government to the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill 1992.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My final question relates to the self-incrimination section in the Bill. I ask the Minister for his assurance that it is not his intention that the Government will be using the Crimes Act to prosecute the majority of social security recipients whose fraudulent activities could perhaps best be described as crimes of poverty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that we use the Crimes Act only in the most serious circumstances where multiple fraud is involved. In other circumstances the Social Security Act would be used.

2.Clause 43, page 38, subclause (b), proposed subsection 644(3), lines 22 and 23, omit the section.

I briefly explain that if these amendments are passed they will make sure that young adults who are unemployed will receive the same benefits as older adults. There is absolutely no merit in the argument that we may in any way encourage people out of full time, meaningful courses if we pass this amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does oppose these amendments. Without going into the reasons in any great depth at this stage, I indicate that our position on this matter has been seriously considered after the Depenbroeck decision in the AAT. The advice I have is that there is great potential for expenditure of some $4m as a consequence of the amendments that have just been moved by the Democrats. The Department of Employment, Education and Training is concerned to closely align the level of support available under what was the formal training allowance with Austudy provisions, and as part of the keenness to ensure that alignment we do not support the Democrats' amendments.

PARA.TAB: I also indicate that there is discretion to pay under-21s under the legislation and, in exercising that discretion, the Secretary of the Department is required to have regard to the expenses of the person undertaking the training. So there is in fact a mechanism available for protection of the most serious cases which might concern Senator Lees. I do not think I need to go into a long exposition as to why we are opposing these amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Lees's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is most unfortunate that we have only five minutes left for this whole debate. I certainly would have liked to ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus)—and receive his response—how these measures, which in effect will deny young people certain amounts for the training component, the living away from home component and so forth, will impinge upon the proposals, for example in Victoria, for numbers of young people to be engaged in a training program.

PARA.TAB: I fear that Senator Bolkus will have to come back to this chamber sooner or later and remedy that particular problem. He may tell me that an 18-year-old is going to require less than an adult to live away from home, but we do know what 18-year olds require to live on. The other thing is that, as far as training is concerned, why differentiate between the requirement for the adult component as compared with juniors?

TALK.START.PARA: —They are adults, aren't they?
—That is right. Senator Bolkus need not waste time now; he can give it to me in writing at some time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOLKUS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take up that invitation. I could, in fact, go through some of the initiatives in this package which do assist and also some safety net measures which are in place, but I think that the best way to do this is to take up Senator Harradine's invitation, provide the response in writing and also incorporate it in Hansard at some later stage.

PARA.TAB: Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill—by leave—taken as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very little time to raise an issue that I think is of basic importance and ought to be raised. In 1990 we saw an amendment to the Social Security Act. This brought in the use of data-matching and the extended use of the tax file number, which Mr Keating had promised us would not be used for any other purpose than taxation. The tax file number was extended and that was justified on the basis that welfare cheats and rorters on the public purse would be caught, and over $300m would be saved each year through data-matching.

PARA.TAB: In that situation, we were damned if we did and damned if we did not. We had a huge inquiry into data-matching. I remember that people on the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—and even I—asked, `What is going to happen? The Government will come to us and say that it has yet another reason for extending the use of the tax file number'. Here we have it in this Bill. Again, we are damned if we do and damned if we do not. We are now data-matching to find people who are eligible for a benefit but are not in receipt of that benefit. It is going to cost the taxpayers to the tune of $100m a year.

I have no objection to people who are entitled to a benefit getting it, but it is this slow chipping away at the stone of the extension of the tax file number for what appear to be very justifiable reasons that I object to. Of course, we are in a situation where we cannot disagree with it; we have to abide by it.I bring to the attention of the Australian public the fact that the use of the tax file number is now being extended again.

The other thing that concerned me was that the Department of Social Security intimated that it did not need to amend the Act to do these positive data-matches. I directed a question to the officers of the Department—and they got legal advice from the Attorney-General's Department—as to whether amendments were required. The answer was equivocal. The Attorney-General's Department said that while it may appear that the legislation that is currently drafted permits the data-matching program for positive aspects, the issue is not free from doubt. Its advice, therefore, was that the proposed amendments to the Data-Matching Program (Assistance and Tax) Act to allow positive data-matching should proceed.

That is quite different from the advice that I received. Earlier in the debate I asked Senator Tate whether I could have leave to table the legal advice I received, and he gave that permission. If Senator Bolkus could extend that to me, I would appreciate it. The legal advice I got on data-matching was definitely that the Act specifically said that it was negative for those people who are rorting the system, not for those people who are entitled to a benefit. My concern is that the Department had what I call a soft interpretation of the Act—that, yes, it could do the data-matching for positive effects. That is the risk.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you seeking leave to—
—I seek the indulgence of the Senate to continue for a couple of minutes.
—I am asking whether you are seeking leave to table some documents.
—Yes. I thought you were going to stop me. Yes, I seek leave to table the documents. (Time expired)

-After Schedule 2, page 119, add the following Schedule:

INTERJECT.PARA: NEW SCHEDULE TO SOCIAL SECURITY ACT 1991
AUSTRALIA AND THE REPUBLIC OF AUSTRIA,

PARA.TAB: Wishing to strengthen the existing friendly relations between the two countries, and
Resolved to co-operate in the field of social security;
(a)"national" means, in relation to Australia, an Australian citizen; and, in relation to Austria, an Austrian citizen;

(b)"legislation" means, in relation to Australia, the law specified in subparagraph 1(a) of Article 2; and, in relation to Austria, the laws, regulations and statutory instruments which relate to the branches of social security specified in subparagraph 1(b) of Article 2;

(c)"competent authority" means in relation to Australia, the Secretary to the Department of Social Security; and, in relation to Austria, the Federal Minister responsible for the application of the legislation specified in subparagraph 1(b) of Article 2;
(d)"institution" means, in relation to Australia, the Department of Social Security; and, in relation to Austria, the institution responsible for the application of the Austrian legislation;

(e)"competent institution" means, in relation to Australia, the Department of Social Security; and, in relation to Austria, the institution competent under the Austrian legislation to deal with the matter in question;

(f)"period of Australian working life residence", in relation to a person, means a period defined as such in the legislation of Australia but does not include any period deemed pursuant to Article 6 to be a period in which that person was an Australian resident;
(g)"period of insurance in Austria" means a period of insurance defined as such in the Austrian legislation;

(h)"benefit" means, in relation to a Party, a benefit, pension or allowance for which provision is made in the legislation of that Party, and includes any additional amount, increase or supplement that is payable, in addition to that benefit, pension or allowance;
(i)"carer pension" means, in relation to Australia, a carer pension payable to a partner under the legislation of Australia;
(j)"widowed person" means, in relation to Australia, a person who:

TAB.TAB: (i)stops being a married person or becomes a single person because of the death of the person's husband or wife; or
(ii)is a class B widow because of the death of her husband or because she is a dependent female,
but does not include a person who has a new partner;

PARA.TAB: (k)"refugee" means a person defined as a refugee in Article 1 of the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees, dated 28 July 1951, and the Protocol to that Convention, dated 31 January 1967;
(l)"stateless person" means a person defined as a stateless person in Article 1 of the Convention relating to the Status of Stateless Persons, dated 28 September 1954.
2.In the application of this Agreement, any term not defined in this Article shall, unless the context otherwise requires, have the meaning assigned to it by the legislation of either Party.
1.Subject to paragraph 2, this Agreement shall apply to:
(a)in relation to Australia: the Social Security Act 1991 insofar as the Act provides for, applies to or affects:

TAB.TAB: (i)age pensions,
(ii)invalid pensions,
(iii)wife pensions,
(iv)carer pensions, and
(v)benefits payable to widowed persons; and

PARA.TAB: (b)in relation to Austria the legislation concerning pension insurance with the exception of the insurance for notaries.

2.Except as otherwise provided in paragraph 3 this Agreement shall also apply to any legislation which supersedes, replaces, amends, supplements or consolidates the legislation specified in paragraph 1.
3.Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph 1:

(a)the legislation of Australia shall not include any laws made, whether before or after the date of signature of this Agreement, for the purpose of giving effect to any agreement on social security; and

(b)this Agreement shall not affect any other agreement on social security which Austria has concluded with a third State, except as it contains provisions relating to the apportionment of insurance burdens.
This Agreement shall apply without any restriction based on nationality to any person who:
(a)is or has been an Australian resident; or
(b)is or has been subject to the Austrian legislation,

INTERJECT.PARA: and where applicable, to any other person with respect to the rights he or she derives from such a person described in subparagraph (a) or (b).

PARA.TAB: 1.Unless otherwise provided in this Agreement, nationals of one Party shall, in the application of the legislation of the other Party, receive equal treatment with the nationals of that other Party.

2.Benefits under the legislation of one Party shall be granted to nationals of the other Party resident outside the territories of both Parties, under the same conditions and to the same extent as they are granted to the nationals of the first Party who reside outside the territories of the Parties.
3.Paragraph 1 shall not apply to the provisions of the Austrian legislation concerning:
(a)the participation of insured persons and employers in the administration of institutions and associations as well as adjudication in the field of social security;
(b)the apportionment of insurance burdens resulting from agreements with third States; or
(c)the insurance of persons employed at a diplomatic mission or consular post of Austria in a third State or by a member of such a mission or post.

4.Paragraph 1 shall apply with regard to the provisions of Austrian legislation concerning the taking into account of periods of war service and periods considered as such only to Australian nationals who were Austrian nationals immediately before 13 March 1938.

1.Unless otherwise provided in this Agreement any provision of the legislation of a Party under which qualification for or payment of a benefit is dependent on a person being a resident of, and/or present in the territory of that Party shall not apply to nationals of either Party, refugees or stateless persons, or other persons who derive rights from the foregoing, who are resident in the territory of either Party and present in the territory of either Party.
2.Benefits of a Party are payable at the request of the beneficiary in the territory of the other Party.

3.Where the legislation of a Party provides that a benefit is payable outside the territory of that Party, then that benefit, when payable by virtue of this Agreement, is also payable outside the territories of both Parties.
4.In relation to Australia:
(a)Paragraph 1 shall apply without regard to nationality.
(b)Paragraph 1 shall not apply to a claimant for a wife pension or carer pension who has never been an Australian resident or to rental allowance.
(c)Where qualification for an Australian benefit is subject to limitations as to time, then references to Australia in those limitations shall be read also as references to the territory of Austria.

(d)Where a person would be qualified under the legislation of Australia or by virtue of this Agreement for an Australian benefit except for not being an Australian resident and in Australia on the date on which the claim for that benefit is lodged but:

TAB.TAB: (i)is an Australian resident or residing in the territory of Austria or a third State with which Australia has concluded an agreement on social security that includes provisions for cooperation in the assessment and determination of claims for benefits; and
(ii)is in Australia, or in the territory of Austria or that third State,

PARA.TAB: that person shall be deemed, for the purposes of lodging that claim, to be an Australian resident and in Australia on that date.
5.As regards the Austrian legislation, paragraph 1 shall not apply to the compensatory supplement (Ausgleichszulage).
1.Where a person to whom this Agreement applies has claimed an Australian benefit under this Agreement and has, without the application of this Agreement, accumulated:
(a)a period as an Australian resident that is less than the period required to qualify him or her, on that ground, under the legislation of Australia for a benefit; and
(b)a period of Australian working life residence equal to or greater than the minimum period identified in accordance with paragraph 4 for that person

INTERJECT.PARA: and has accumulated a period of insurance in Austria, then for the purposes of a claim for that Australian benefit, that period of insurance in Austria shall be deemed, only for the purposes of this Article for meeting any period required for qualification for that benefit set out in the legislation of Australia, to be a period in which that person was an Australian resident.

PARA.TAB: 2.For the purposes of paragraph 1, where a person:
(a)has been an Australian resident for a continuous period which is less than the minimum continuous period required by the legislation of Australia for entitlement of that person to a benefit; and
(b)has accumulated a period of insurance in Austria in two or more separate periods that equals or exceeds in total the minimum period referred to in subparagraph (a),
the total of the periods of insurance in Austria shall be deemed to be one continuous period.

3.For all purposes of this Article, where a period by a person as an Australian resident and a period of insurance in Austria coincide, the period of coincidence shall be taken into account once only by Australia as a period as an Australian resident.
4.The minimum period of residence in Australia to be taken into account for the purposes of paragraph 1 shall be as follows:

(a)for the purposes of an Australian benefit that is payable to a person who is not an Australian resident, the minimum period shall be twelve months of which at least six months must be continuous; and
(b)for the purposes of an Australian benefit that is payable to an Australian resident, no minimum.

5.For the purposes of a claim by a person for a pension payable to a widowed person, that person shall be deemed to have accumulated a period of insurance in Austria for any period for which his or her partner accumulated a period of insurance in Austria but any period during which the person and his or her partner both accumulated a period of insurance in Austria shall be taken into account once only.

1.Subject to paragraph 2, where an Australian benefit is payable whether by virtue of this Agreement or otherwise to a person who is outside the territory of Australia, the rate of that benefit shall be determined according to the legislation of Australia but when assessing the income of that person for the purposes of calculating the rate of the Australian benefit only a proportion of any Austrian benefit which is received by that person shall be regarded as income. That proportion shall be calculated by multiplying the number of whole months accumulated by that person in a period of Australian working life residence (not exceeding 300) by the amount of that Austrian benefit and dividing that product by 300.

2.A person referred to in paragraph 1 shall only be entitled to receive the concessional assessment of income described in that paragraph for any period during which the rate of that person's Australian benefit is proportionalised under the legislation of Australia.

3.Where an Australian benefit is payable by virtue of this Agreement or otherwise to a person who is in Austria, any compensatory supplement or social assistance and similar means-tested payment paid by Austria to that person shall be disregarded by Australia in computing that person's income for the purposes of the legislation of Australia or the application of this Agreement.
4.Subject to the provisions of paragraph 5, where an Australian benefit is payable only by virtue of this Agreement to a person who is in Australia, the rate of that benefit shall be determined by:
(a)calculating that person's income according to the legislation of Australia but disregarding in that calculation the Austrian benefit received by that person;
(b)deducting the amount of the Austrian benefit received by that person from the maximum rate of that Australian benefit; and

(c)applying to the remaining benefit obtained under subparagraph (b) the relevant rate calculation set out in the legislation of Australia, using as the person's income the amount calculated under subparagraph (a).

5.Where the rate of a benefit calculated in accordance with paragraph 4 is less than the rate of that benefit which would be payable under paragraphs 1, 2 and 3 if the person concerned were outside Australia, the first-mentioned rate shall be increased to an amount equivalent to the second-mentioned rate.

6.Where a married person is, or both that person and his or her partner are, in receipt of an Austrian benefit or benefits, each of them shall be deemed, for the purposes of paragraph 4 and for the legislation of Australia, to be in receipt of one half of either the amount of that benefit or total of both of those benefits, as the case may be.
7.For the purposes of paragraph 5, a comparison of the rates of the benefits shall be made as at:
(a)the date of the first pension pay day occurring after the date from which the benefit is payable; and
(b)each anniversary of that pension pay day for so long as the person concerned is entitled to the benefit;

INTERJECT.PARA: using, in that comparison, the number of months of the period of Australian working life residence accumulated by the person at the date as at which the comparison is made.

PARA.TAB: A person who receives from Australia an Australian benefit due to the fact that the partner of that person receives, by virtue of this Agreement, another Australian benefit shall, for the purposes of this Agreement, be deemed to receive that first-mentioned benefit by virtue of this Agreement.

If a person has completed periods of insurance in Austria and periods of Australian working life residence, those periods, insofar as they do not overlap, shall be added together for the purpose of qualification for an Austrian benefit.

1.If a person who has completed periods of insurance in Austria and periods of Australian working life residence, or the survivor of such a person, is claiming a benefit, the competent institution for Austria shall determine the amount of the benefit in the following manner:
(a)the institution shall determine, in accordance with the Austrian legislation, whether the person concerned has an entitlement to a benefit by adding together the periods as provided in Article 9;

(b)if entitlement to a benefit is determined to exist, the institution shall first calculate the theoretical amount of the benefit which would be payable if all the periods completed under the legislation of both Parties had been completed exclusively under the Austrian legislation; in cases where the amount of the benefit is independent of the duration of the period of insurance, this amount shall be taken to be the theoretical amount; and

(c)the institution shall then calculate the partial benefit payable on the basis of the amount calculated in accordance with the provisions of subparagraph (b) in proportion to the ratio between the duration of the periods of insurance to be taken into consideration under the Austrian legislation and the total duration of the periods to be taken into consideration under the legislation of both Parties.

2.Where the periods of insurance to be taken into consideration under the Austrian legislation for the purpose of calculating the amount of a benefit are in aggregate less than twelve months, no benefit under that legislation shall be paid. However, the preceding sentence shall not apply if the entitlement to that benefit has been acquired under the Austrian legislation exclusively on the basis of periods of insurance completed under that legislation.
The competent Austrian institution shall apply Articles 9 and 10 according to the following rules:
1.In determining the institution responsible for paying a benefit, only periods of insurance in Austria shall be taken into consideration.
2.Periods of Australian working life residence, during which the person concerned was employed or self-employed, shall be treated as periods of contributions.
3.Articles 9 and 10 shall apply neither to the conditions of entitlement to nor to the payment of the miners' long service allowance under the miners' pension insurance.
4.For the application of paragraph 1 of Article 10, the following shall apply:
(a)periods during which the insured person has been entitled to an age pension or invalid pension under the legislation of Australia shall be treated as if they were neutral periods;
(b)the basis of assessment shall be determined exclusively on periods of insurance in Austria;
(c)the contributions for supplementary insurance as well as the miners' supplementary benefit, the helpless person's allowance and the compensatory supplement shall be disregarded.
5.For the application of subparagraphs 1(b) and (c) of Article 10, overlapping periods under the legislation of the two Parties shall be taken into consideration as if they did not overlap.

6.If, for the application of subparagraph 1(c) of Article 10, the total duration of the periods to be taken into consideration under the legislation of both Parties exceeds the maximum number of months of insurance specified under the Austrian legislation for the calculation of the rate of increments, the partial pension payable shall be calculated in proportion to the ratio between the duration of the periods of insurance to be taken into consideration under the Austrian legislation and the above-mentioned maximum number of months of insurance.
7.For the calculation of the helpless person's allowance, subparagraphs 1(b) and (c) of Article 10 shall apply; Article 13 shall apply accordingly.

8.The amount calculated according to subparagraph 1(c) of Article 10 shall be increased, where applicable, by the increments for contributions for supplementary insurance as well as the miners' supplementary benefit, the helpless person's allowance and the compensatory supplement.

9.If the award of benefits under the miners' pension insurance depends on the completion of essentially mining activities, within the meaning of the Austrian legislation, in specific undertakings, then only those periods of Australian working life residence during which the person was employed in a similar occupation in similar undertakings shall be taken into consideration.
10.The special payments shall be payable in the same amount as the Austrian partial benefit; Article 13 shall apply accordingly.

1.Where entitlement to a benefit exists under the Austrian legislation without the application of Article 9, the competent Austrian institution shall pay the pension which would be payable exclusively on the basis of the periods of insurance to be taken into consideration under that legislation, provided there is no entitlement to a corresponding benefit under the legislation of Australia.

2.The pension determined in accordance with paragraph 1 shall be recalculated in accordance with the provisions of Article 10 as soon as entitlement arises to a corresponding benefit under the legislation of Australia. This recalculation shall have effect from the date on which the benefit under the legislation of Australia becomes payable. The irrevocability of previous decisions shall not prevent this recalculation.

If a person is entitled to a benefit under the Austrian legislation without the application of Article 9, and if such a benefit would be greater than the total of the Austrian benefit calculated in accordance with subparagraph 1(c) of Article 10 and the corresponding Australian benefit, the competent Austrian institution shall pay, as the partial benefit, its benefit so calculated increased by the difference between such total and the benefit which would be payable if the Austrian legislation alone were applied.

1.The date on which a claim, notice or appeal concerning the determination or payment of a benefit under the legislation of a Party is lodged with an authority, institution or other competent body of the other Party shall be treated, for all purposes concerning the matter to which it relates, as the date of lodgement of that document with an authority, institution or other competent body of the first Party.

2.Any claim for a benefit under the legislation of a Party shall be considered to be a claim for the corresponding benefit under the legislation of the other Party for which the applicant may be qualified if the applicant provides information at the time of claim indicating that the person on whose record benefits are claimed has completed relevant periods of residence or of insurance under the legislation of the other Party and:
(a)the claim is lodged with the institution of the other Party; or

(b)the claim is lodged with the institution of the first Party and that institution sends the claim within three months of its lodgement with that institution to the competent institution of the other Party.

INTERJECT.PARA: 3.In the cases to which paragraphs 1 and 2 of this Article apply, the body to which the submission has been made shall forward the claim, notice or appeal without delay to the corresponding competent body of the other Party.

PARA.TAB: 1.Where an Austrian institution has made an advance payment to a person for any period and arrears of a corresponding benefit become payable for the same period under the legislation of Australia, the competent institution of Australia shall deduct from those arrears the amount paid by way of advance payment and shall transfer the amount so deducted to the Austrian institution. Where an Austrian institution has overpaid a benefit for any period for which the competent institution of Australia afterwards becomes liable to pay a corresponding benefit, the overpayment shall be regarded, for the purpose of the first sentence, as an advance payment.
2.Where
(a)an Austrian benefit is paid or payable to a person in respect of a past period;
(b)for all or part of that period, an Australian benefit has been paid to that person; and
(c)the amount of the Australian benefit would have been reduced had the Austrian benefit been paid during that period;
then

(d)the amount of the Australian benefit that would not have been paid had the Austrian benefit described in subparagraph (a) been paid on a periodical basis throughout that past period, shall be a debt due by that person to the Commonwealth of Australia; and
(e)Australia may determine according to the legislation of Australia that the amount or any part of that debt may be deducted from future payments of Australian benefit payable to that person.

INTERJECT.PARA: 3.Where an Austrian institution has not yet paid the benefit described in subparagraph 2(a) to the person:

PARA.TAB: (a)the Austrian institution shall, at the request of the competent authority of Australia pay the amount of the benefit necessary to meet the debt described in subparagraph 2(d) to the competent institution of Australia and shall pay any excess to the person; and
(b)any shortfall may be recovered by the competent authority of Australia under subparagraph 2(e).
1.The benefit-paying institution of a Party may discharge its obligations under this Agreement in the national currency of that Party.
2.A benefit payable by a Party by virtue of this Agreement shall be paid by that Party without deduction for administrative fees and charges.

INTERJECT.PARA: 1.The competent authorities of the Parties shall, by means of an Arrangement, establish the administrative measures necessary for the application of this Agreement.

PARA.TAB: 2.The competent authorities shall inform each other of laws that amend, supplement or replace the legislation of their respective Parties.

3.The competent authorities and institutions of the Parties shall assist each other, including by the communication of any information, in applying the legislation specified in Article 2 and this Agreement, as if they were applying their own legislation. With the exception of cash expenditures relating thereto, such assistance shall be provided free of charge.

4.The laws of a Party concerning confidentiality shall apply to any information about an individual which is transmitted in accordance with this Agreement to that Party by the other Party. Such information shall be used only for purposes of applying this Agreement or the legislation of a Party.

5.The competent authorities of the Parties shall, in order to facilitate the application of this Agreement, particularly for the creation of a simple and fast liaison between the institutions concerned, establish liaison agencies.

6.The institutions and the competent authority of one Party may not reject claims or other documents submitted to them by reason only of the fact that they are written in an official language of the other Party.

7.If the competent institution of one Party requires an applicant or beneficiary who lives in the territory of the other Party to undergo a medical examination, such examination shall, at the request of that institution, be arranged or carried out by the institution of the latter Party at its expense.

2.Documents and certificates of any kind which must be submitted for the application of this Agreement shall not require authentication.
