DEBATE.TITLE: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992TELECOMMUNICATIONS (PUBLIC MOBILE LICENCE CHARGE) BILL 1992TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992AVIATION FUEL REVENUES (SPECIAL APPROPRIATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 25 March, 1 June, 1 June and 27 May respectively, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a package of four sizeable Bills: the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992; the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992; the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992; and the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill 1992. It is outrageous that the Parliament, particularly the Senate, the House of review which picks up so many of the mistakes that the electoral college—the other place, the House of Representatives—makes in legislation, is denied its basic function because of the incompetence of this Government to manage its affairs.

PARA.TAB: I notice the Labor Party Whip is smirking because he has the security of the guillotine to drive his legislation through per courtesy of the Australian Democrats, those great custodians of public morality—the people who get up when I go to lectures in Brisbane, to universities and things like that and nauseatingly carry on about how they support the Senate because it is the House of review and it works in the interests of the people of Australia. How can we work as a House of review when the Democrats, the far left of the Labor Party, are bought off to support a guillotine? Without exception, every session we have had since this Government has been in power, they have sold out the legislative rights of the Senate in order to satisfy the need for the Government to get up by a specific time.

When we started this session, as you would remember, Mr Acting Deputy President, we just made work for weeks and weeks because the Government was so incompetent in organising its legislative load that we had nothing to do. Now we have something like 38 or 40 Bills to put through in two weeks—driven through without any due deliberation, any fairness or any review, which was supposed to apply to that legislation, purely because the Government and the Democrats think that is the way to govern Australia in the best interests of the community. No wonder the Parliament is held in contempt and parliamentarians are the lowest in social standing when behaviour like that goes on.

We have four major Bills before us this afternoon. None of us have time to go through them in the detail that they demand. The first Bill that I want to deal with is the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992, which deals with shipping and maritime amendments. In essence, these non-contentious amendments concern the extension of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority services, a change to the schedule of hazardous substances, the implementation of the MARPOL Convention requirements for the disposal of untreated sewage, oil, chemicals and garbage in the Antarctic area and the correction of some drafting errors—errors that had the Senate had time would probably have been picked up on earlier occasions when the Bills were first presented. The two areas of pollution in the Antarctic and, indeed, the matter of AMSA's capacity to do its job with the resources currently at its disposal should be the subject of concern in this chamber because of the international implications that are attached to that. They certainly should be the subject of greater debate.

There are also some communications amendments. The amendments made under the Transport and Communications Amendment Bill to the Broadcasting Act of 1942 and the Radio Licence Fees Act of 1964 are contained in parts 3 and 4 of the Bill. The amendments do not relate to the future of the industry in policy changes or as a response to technological advancement. Rather, they involve a correction of errors and anomalies which have occurred because of amending legislation moved through this Parliament in the immediate past.

The amendments seek to recognise the radio warrant for an AM commercial radio service and can either authorise medium frequency transmission only or medium frequency coupled with high frequency. The effect is to ensure that licensees of non-metropolitan AM commercial radio who have FM translators will be able to apply under subsection 89D of the Act for a conversion to an FM licence.

The amendments to the Radio Licence Fees Act 1964 are contained in part 4, clauses 21 to 25, and are all concerned with licence fees. Again, these amendments concern correcting a drafting error in an amending Bill passed last year. The current licence fee ceiling of 6.5 per cent for licensees with revenues greater than $10m should in the 1991 amending legislation have been reduced by 50 per cent or to 3.25 per cent. That was the Government's original intention.

The Bill also contains the mechanism to ensure that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal refunds to affected licensees the difference between the amount which was paid and the amount which should have been paid. The Opposition will be moving an amendment to this Bill.

The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) also amends communications Acts, specifically the Telecommunications Act of 1991. The amendment is to allow exception to the rule which prevents a carrier which dominates a market from discriminating between customers to enable AOTC to implement its decision to offer a concession to low income and other disadvantaged customers. Secondly, this Bill seeks to allow exceptions to the rule which requires all basic carriage services to be set out in a tariff. The effect of this will be to allow some confidentiality of information.

The third telecommunications related Bill is the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992, the purpose of which is to provide clarification on a couple of matters in relation to a third national mobile telephone system. These matters concern the licence charging regime, which cannot be construed as a tax, and enable the third mobile operator to provide such a service on the same terms as MobileNet and Optus, which are the two existing operators. The Bill also provides that in the future, where further licences are allocated, the charge is to be in accord with regulations and not necessarily by tender, as is the case with the issue of the third licence. The issue of a third mobile licence is in accord with independent advice to the Government from Austel, and is also in accord with the Opposition's policy of providing greater competition in this field.

The other amendments I wish to deal with concern the aviation measures in this package of legislation. The three Bills propose amendments to, first, the Air Navigation Act of 1920, the Federal Airports Corporation Act of 1986, the Civil Aviation Act of 1988 and the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriations) Act of 1988. The final Act in this group is amended by the changes to the aviation fuel excise levy. The Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriations) Amendment Bill attempts to reconstruct the formula under which a portion of the revenue received by the Government from excise and customs tariff duties on aviation gasoline is appropriated to the Civil Aviation Authority. The Bill will reduce the excise by 1c a litre immediately, with a further 1c reduction to apply when the number of Commonwealth airports is reduced to 100. The full sum will be reduced with the termination of the aerodrome local ownership plan in June 1993.

When the Government announced its intention to transfer the remaining Commonwealth owned aerodromes to full local ownership, the original date for the phasing out of the plan was 1994. However, an additional $25m was provided under the One Nation statement to bring the phasing out date forward to 1993. This Bill allows for a reduction in the rate of excise to correspond with the reduction in Government outlays for the ALOP. The Opposition will not be opposing this Bill.

Nor will the Opposition be opposing the amendments contained in the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. In essence, this Bill replaces the existing general offence provisions in section 22 of the Act with specific offence provisions and penalties; clarifies the position relating to international airline licences, permissions and approvals; amends the regulation making powers of section 26 to enable regulations to be made enabling on the spot fines for specific offences; and removes the power to prescribe a term of imprisonment in the regulations. These changes are all contained in clauses 3 through 15 and are, in the main, just administrative changes. The Australian Democrats have proposed an amendment to this Bill and the Opposition will be opposing that.

The third transport related Bill in this package is the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), which amends 10 Acts three of which fall within the aviation area. These amendments enable ratification of two new protocols amending the Chicago Convention on International Civil Aviation to increase the size of the Council of the International Civil Aviation Organisation and the Air Navigation Commission. Secondly, it specifies that the CAA and FAC cannot be reimbursed for financial detriment as a result of complying with ministerial directions relating to its environmental functions. Thirdly, it clarifies the priority of the CAA's statutory liens and, finally, it ensures that the FAC has the power to enter into a number of financial management risk or hedging transactions.

The Opposition will not be opposing the second reading of this Bill. However, it will be opposing clause 15, which seeks to amend clause 78 of the Act to ensure that liens over aircraft have priority over other financial security interests, including pre-existing mortgages. Our opposition to this attempt to gain priority over other creditors is based on the belief that, firstly, the CAA already has sufficient power to recover debts and, secondly, it certainly has more than enough power over the aviation industry without this sort of nonsense. There is a possibility that leasing charges will be increased if the priority of the CAA to recover debts is strengthened.

Finally, I would like to say something about the airport local ownership plan and the consequences of the user pays doctrine that this Government has applied to the aviation industry but to no other transport industry. I was very interested to see about four weeks ago that the Canberra bus service had lost something like $2.7m. I phoned up the ACT Administration and got the full account. I found out that the $2.7m was the loss after it had had a subsidy of something like $54m or $56m. Then I found there was an Auditor-General's report saying that the ACT Government's accounting processes were a bit shonky. I totted up a loss of something like $58m-odd for the bus service in this little tin-pot town. Where is the user pays principle in that? Why are we driving the aviation industry, which is of major significance to the Australian economy, to a cost recovery, user pays system, yet we have something like the bus service in this town losing over $50m a year? It is absolutely nonsensical. In my city of Brisbane something like $22m a year is lost on the urban bus service. I could not quantify what the railways lose; it would run into hundreds of millions a year, maybe thousands of millions a year.

But somehow or other this Government has locked the aviation industry into a user pays, full cost recovery doctrine. An awful lot of penalties come from that program. I would argue quite strongly, as I have over many years, that there is a public interest component in the aviation industry. The community benefits. It not only benefits through the tourism industry with all the people that that employs and all the money that it brings into the country from tourists and people moving around the country, but also little communities—the isolated townships in rural Australia—have got an airfield somewhere. These have been supported in the past out of the consolidated revenue paid by the community.

Now that the local ownership plan has been tightened up, a lot of those shires and small townships which entered into the scheme, most of them somewhat reluctantly, find that they cannot maintain the airports. We are not talking about anything grandiose here. We are talking about maybe a sealed strip and a little wooden hut as a passenger terminal, but those airports provide a very effective facility for those rural people. During floods and fires and all the other vicissitudes of the bush aircraft are able to go in and provide relief supplies. A lot of those places find that they simply cannot afford an airport. I would argue that there is a community interest. We are one country; we are one nation. I think that we ought to provide a basic level of benefits across the country, and that is very relevant with respect to aviation services.

The other matter I would like to comment on briefly is the mess that the aviation industry is now in as a consequence of the Civil Aviation Authority. I spoke earlier this afternoon on accountability in relation to the tendering documents on procurements that were laid down in the Parliament today by the Department of Administrative Services. We now have a Civil Aviation Authority which is almost totally devoid of the professional competence that is needed to run its business.

When I woke up this morning I heard on one of the news reports on Radio National an allegation that the Civil Aviation Authority had said that all the light aircraft in this country were dangerous or something like that because maintenance was not being kept up. The President of AOPA, Mr Peter Petroni, said that was nonsense. There was a direct quote from him. Of course it is nonsense. I do not know what the statement was from the Civil Aviation Authority that initiated all this, but the maintenance of aircraft is very tightly covered by the Civil Aviation Authority. If there is any shortcoming there, it is as a consequence of maladministration within the Authority itself. It is not the fault of the industry. The industry operates to maintenance schedules that have been in place ever since aircraft were introduced into Australia.

There have been some changes recently in the system where the Authority has gone to manufacturers recommendations and things such as that. But for an authority to make such a claim, which can only alarm the public, I find quite nonsensical and irresponsible. In the fullness of time, I will research that statement and find out where it came from.

It is indicative of the low level of professional competence there now is in the Civil Aviation Authority. A large part of that stems from the contract basis where people are brought in who have no experience or knowledge of the industry at all. They are put into senior positions on contracts of two, three or four years tenure and told to save money. These people not only have no knowledge of the industry; they have no commitment to it and, least of all, no commitment to Australia and the industry within Australia. I sense that Senator Collins will interject here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wrong.

—I have been a very long term critic of the Civil Aviation Authority and its predecessors. It has been inefficient, but cuts are now being made without any respect to effectiveness and the relation of those cuts to the welfare of the industry. It is very easy to put someone on a short term contract, tell him to get his overheads down and have half the staff fired. In a year's time the chief executive gets on a fast plane out of the country and retires to the south of France, or wherever he wants to go.

PARA.TAB: That does not leave those of us in Australia who will live on here and be involved in the industry in a very secure position, because we have to clean up the mess and the wreckage that is left. By all means, let us move to get a more efficient and cost effective regulatory service in the form of the CAA, but let us do it in an intelligent and relevant way. That is not happening at present. With those few words, I close my contribution to the debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have a package of four Bills before us today: the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill, the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill, the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill. I will be brief on each of those Bills, beginning with the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill encompasses amendments to each of the following Acts: the Air Navigation Act, the Broadcasting Act and the Radio Licence Fees Act.

PARA.TAB: In the context of those amendments, the Australian Democrats acknowledge the basic administrative nature of most of the tidying up and questions of interpretation and clarification that exist with regard to the amendments to the Broadcasting Act and the Radio Licence Fees Act. We support those sections of the Bill as they are before us today.

However, we do have something to say about that section of the Bill which deals with the Air Navigation Act, and we will be moving amendments during the committee stage in respect of that section. The amendments in the Bill before us replace the general offence provision with specific offence provisions and penalties. The area that really concerns the Democrats is the proposed amendments to section 19 of the Act covering the carriage of munitions. In basic terms, our concern arose with regard to the fines and penalties that are provided for by these amendments. I propose to go through our reasons for the amendments and the nature of the amendments in this second reading debate so as not to delay the chamber in committee.

We have proposed that increases be made to the fines and penalties that are in this amending legislation. In discussions with the Government over our proposed amendments, which basically tighten up the penalties and fines with regard to the carriage of munitions, we ascertained that it was the intention of the Government at some point in the future to deal with what it saw itself as some inadequacies in this legislation. We persisted with our concerns. We came to agreement on the basis that we support the intention, but believe that this is the time that we should bring the penalties and the code of offences to a better and more appropriate standard.

We believe that the amendments that we are moving embody a very important principle of justice: that the punishment must fit the crime. We believe that the criminal offences defined in the Act must be liable to terms of imprisonment and fines which give a clear signal of the Government's intent to pursue regulatory control of aviation, particularly with regard to munitions trafficking, which we consider to be very serious indeed. I note that a major review of the legislation is planned with regard to public safety and breach of licence issues, and look forward to those future proposals. But in regard to the carriage of munitions, we felt that it was important to have the ability to impose criminal penalties, and we have persisted with those amendments.

I understand that an amendment will also be moved by the Government to that section of the Bill that deals with the Broadcasting Act, which relates to the Government's legislation on political advertising. The Democrats will be supporting that Government amendment.

The second Bill before us is the Telecommunications (Public Mobile Licence Charge) Bill 1992. This Bill embodies provisions for the new allocation system, including consideration of Australian equity and industry development commitments. We certainly acknowledge and support this move; in fact, the Government gets brownie points for this one. However, I wonder whether the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) will be advising the Senate, as a matter of course, about prospective bidders. How wide will his information gathering about the bona fides of the prospects in this area be? We understand that under this legislation the new system will be designed to cut government administrative costs and provide government income from a presently low taxed source, without which it may be possible for local fixed phone revenue to subsidise call rates for mobile phones.

As to the process for the third licence, it is worth noting that all licences are up for review in 1995. Procedures for bidding and allocation terms and conditions will be revised then. The Government's idea is to let the market settle as we move into competition in this area, and then assess the new needs. I suppose the whole industry, and the Government legislation that surrounds it, is on trial, so to speak, at this time. The Democrats support this legislation.

The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is again an omnibus Bill dealing with a wide range of issues. Part 9 involves substantive reform in the business of tidying up the house, which most of these omnibus Bills do. I note that part 2, relating to the Air Navigation Act, ratifies the Chicago Convention.

Part 9, which follows on from part 8 dealing with the Protection of the Sea (Powers of Intervention) Act and incorporating resolutions of the Maritime Environment Protection Committee as part of a pollution control protocol, embodies new requirements for emergency procedures—shipboard oil emergency plans, which we believe are excellent. The Government is to be commended for these guidelines which will go part of the way towards helping to prevent another Kirki incident, we believe, where major problems were involved—as have already been discussed in this chamber, and no doubt will be again in the future in that situation—including delay in requests for help and lack of emergency procedures to ensure speedy redress.

The Bill provides for foreign ships to be presented to port authorities on entrance and the need for alignment with standards mandated for Australian ships. The Australian Parliament—not this chamber but the other place—is embarking on a committee inquiry into the question of ship safety. I believe that inquiry will make a major contribution in this area internationally. Those of us who have an interest in this area will watch with keen interest the work of that committee which has already called for submissions, which submissions have attracted international attention and interest.

I also note that in part 10 of this legislation copyright protection is being provided for the Austel name and symbol. A good deal of this legislation clarifies the corporatisation and general changes that have taken place in transport and communications under this Government. For instance, part 5 deals with the corporatisation process of the Civil Aviation Authority, its liability to pay tax, and the CAA to be considered as an entity under tax law. The Australian Democrats have no amendments to this Bill and support its passage.

The fourth Bill before us is the Aviation Fuel Revenues (Special Appropriation) Amendment Bill. This Bill reduces excise but preserves the revenue entitlement of the CAA. As Senator MacGibbon has already noted, the Bill relates to the local ownership scheme and to the tightening up of that scheme for locally owned airports. The revenue forgone is the revenue used to fund the previously Commonwealth owned aerodromes. The transfer of ownership of local aerodromes occurred in August 1990 by regulation. Through this legislation we are passing on the savings to the Government.

I take this opportunity to make the point that local aerodromes are of major significance to local communities and to note, with some surprise and almost incredulity, Senator MacGibbon's protest about the application of user pays in the area of aviation. I find that extraordinary from a proponent, presumably, of the Fightback program.

Senator MacGibbon did say something with which I heartily agree: that we as a community through Consolidated Revenue should provide a basic level of services to those in far flung places in this one nation of ours. Having come from a small country town whose aerodrome was a focal point—it was an air base during the Second World War, which I can barely remember, of course, having been born halfway through it—I know how important those airports are to local communities. As a senator representing the whole State, I very often find myself landing and taking off from some of these very basic air facilities.

A matter of great concern to the Democrats is the application of this deregulatory process and the Government getting out of one service or another to the community. It has been a feature of this Labor Government which is avidly supported by the Opposition, whose only complaint, until I heard Senator MacGibbon just now, seems to have been that the Government has not done enough soon enough, and that more will be done when Fightback becomes government policy after the next election, should the coalition win office.

Local aerodromes in rural communities are more than simply somewhere for fly-boys to land their planes and for senators to visit. There are important safety and access issues involved for local people, from local disasters or problems that relate to individuals or single families, right through to major bushfires, floods or whatever. Equal access for rural people is important in a social justice sense. Anything that any government does should do nothing to add to the disadvantages that already exist for those living in rural and remote Australian areas.

I note that government intentions are stated and that some action is already under way to upgrade the airports—in many cases, they are already completed—before hand-over or commitments to those upgrades. That is a plus. The acknowledgment of that social responsibility is maintenance grants from the Government and an ability, as part of the One Nation statement, for the local bodies to apply for funds under a social benefits funding scheme. My only concern is how long all of that will last, particularly if there is a change of government.

Should there be a change of government—when local communities will feel isolated as a result of a user pays program, which I am sure will become absolutely brutal should such a thing happen—I look forward to hearing from Senator MacGibbon in defence of those local communities as avidly as we have today. In that event, I will refer any correspondence I get to Senator MacGibbon. Perhaps he will be the Minister for aviation support at the time. No doubt he hopes he will be.

The Democrats have no amendment to that legislation either and will support its passage. We will merely move amendments to the first Bill dealing with the penalties involved in the carriage of munitions in air transport.

TALK.START.PARA: —While Senator Powell is still in the chamber, may I assure her—as I think she knows—that I have continually pointed out the problems of remote airports in Australia. If Senator Powell finds the small airports in Victoria a bit funny to fly into, she ought to try those in the Kimberley where one is really sitting on the edge of the seat when taking off. I take Senator Powell up on her use of sexist language in this place when she said that local aerodromes are not only for the fly-boys to land in. I can assure her that there is a very good woman pilot in Western Australia who flies me around and is very capable.
—Send her a copy of your speech.

—Yes, I will. I will not spend too much time speaking on the Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill. I intend to be finished by 6.30 p.m. The main purpose of this Bill relates to the Broadcasting Act. The Bill makes it possible to ensure that the licensees of non-metropolitan AM stations and commercial radio services which have FM translators will be able to apply for conversion to FM. The other main change relates to radio licence fees. The full benefit of early arrangements made by the Government—the reduction in fees for the radio industry itself—will flow on to where it is needed.

PARA.TAB: The Senate does not need me to tell it that radio is having a bad time around Australia, particularly in regional and remote areas, so any flow-on of a reduction in fees will be very much appreciated. The reduction of fees may save some bases. However, if some do not amalgamate, they will see the end before very long, especially if the recession lasts much longer.

In the few minutes left before dinner, I would like to address the issue of fees for two-way radio licences. There has been a reduction in AM licence fees in regional areas but, for two-way radio licences, the fees seem to have been going the other way. In fact, the fees for HF two-way radio licences were fairly static until about 1987 when so much was paid for a base and so much for a mobile. When Senator Evans was the Minister for Transport and Communications in 1988 it was decided that an FM transmitter on a base should be licensed according to the number of channels, which more than doubled the radio licence fee of a base. The Government increased the licence fees on HF mobiles as well.

For a base that had three or four mobiles the bill for one year went from about $300 or $400 to over $1,000. That might have been all right in 1988 when the recession was not as deep as it is now. However, I would like the bases to be treated the same as the broadcast radio stations in rural and regional areas, which have had a big reduction in their licence fees. Previously, if a base had a flying doctor network in its HF channel it was able to avoid sales tax on the set. That provision was also eliminated in 1988. It made the cost of communication, and safety, in rural and remote areas much higher. I believe it is an oversight by the Government that it did something for the broadcasting sector of radio for regional areas but did nothing for two-way radios, which are very important in terms of safety. I would like the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) to take this on board and see what he can do about reducing licence fees.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Transport and Communications Legislation Amendment Bill 1992 deals with changes in radio licence fees for country FM radio licences. It is interesting that the Government should attempt to involve itself further in the FM radio licences after the unusual circumstances surrounding the granting of FM radio licences in the northern New South Wales town of Lismore. I think the Senate will agree that the Government must be questioned on its ability to handle even minor issues in this area after hearing the points that I wish to raise tonight.

PARA.TAB: I would like to bring to the attention of the Senate the issue of the granting of an FM radio licence to serve the northern New South Wales town of Lismore. I do this so that the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) may provide answers to some very important questions. Over four years ago the Government announced a plan to introduce a new commercial FM radio service in Lismore. The then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Evans, said at the time that Lismore could look forward to receiving a new, independent FM radio service by early 1990. The Minister went on to say that Lismore was in the market such that he would `dismiss any supplementary licence applications'.

Hearings commenced for the granting of the licence with two applicants for it and the current AM radio station, 2LM, being able to cross-examine and offer a submission as an interested party. After waiting for relevant decisions from the Federal Court, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal decided that the licence should be awarded to a syndicate named Northern New South Wales FM Pty Ltd in December 1989. A legal challenge was then mounted asking for a re-hearing of the case. This was eventually granted. After further legal proceedings, the re-hearing was set down for 9 March 1992—almost 2 1/2 years later. Before the re-hearing the ABT member had to satisfy himself that the Lismore market could support an independent licence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we were debating in a cognate manner a number of transport and communications Bills. Part of one of these Bills makes reference to radio licensing. I was discussing a rather unusual position in the town of Lismore and the way in which FM radio licences hearings have been conducted over several years. I was pointing out that it had taken almost four years for this matter to come to its final stages—or so we thought. Then some very unusual interventions seemed to lead to a position where a whole new ball game was opened up. After we had legal proceedings and re-hearings, a date was set down for 9 March 1992, almost 2 1/2 years after this matter got under way.

PARA.TAB: Before the re-hearing, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal members had to satisfy themselves that the Lismore market could support an independent licence. This was found to be the case on 17 December 1991. The local AM holder, 2LM, objected, for the second time, on an allegation of apprehended bias, but this was thrown out of the Federal Court on 6 March 1992. On the same day, and only three days before the final hearing of this four-year saga, the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, told the ABT that an application for a supplementary licence was coming and asked whether, if possible, the ABT would hear the application simultaneously with the current proceedings. As an editorial in the Lismore Echo of 22 May 1992 put it:

SPEECH.PARA: In other words, 2LM was allowed to apply after all. Suddenly someone had moved the goal posts.

The supplementary licence was lodged by 2LM but, for some unexplained reason, the then Minister, Senator Richardson, never passed it on to the ABT which said that it would have to consider it if it received it. As the ABT had not received the application by 9 March 1992, the ABT hearing went ahead. On 13 May 1992, the Tribunal decided that it was, in fact, non-viable to have another independent radio licence in Lismore. This was despite two decisions to the contrary, one only five months previously.

PARA.TAB: It is the duty of the ABT to issue further licences wherever possible, unless it considers that the current service would not remain adequate. The report of the Tribunal on its decision gives no satisfactory reason why the ABT should change its mind between December and May. Only nine days later, the ABT announced that it was commencing hearings on the granting of a supplementary FM radio licence. It had received an application from 2LM on 19 May 1992 on a referral from the then Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, only six days after the ABT had rejected the granting of an independent licence.

The circumstances surrounding the granting of an FM radio licence in Lismore have been extraordinary, to say the least. On 5 May in this place I questioned the then Minister, Senator Richardson, on his involvement in this issue. I received a most unsatisfactory answer. He stated that because of the way the Act was drafted, there was almost no chance of a supplementary licence getting up, but that once the Australian Broadcasting Authority was established by legislation which was then before the Senate, supplementary licences would be much more common. He also stated that he feared for the economics of country radio. I remind the Senate that the ABT had ruled twice that in Lismore the market was able to support two radio licences.

The ABT cites television aggregation as a new factor that affects the viability of radio in Lismore. Television aggregation has been expected for at least two years. How is it, then, that the ABT, only now, after four years of hearings, decides to take this into consideration?

The new Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Collins, must clear the air unequivocally and investigate this matter. I would like the Minister to provide answers to several questions surrounding this whole issue of the granting of licences for FM radio in Lismore. I should like to know why the former Minister intervened in the way that he did; specifically what circumstances changed between December 1991 and May 1992 to make the ABT change its mind on viability; whether Senator Richardson's correspondence with Mr Westerway, Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, was one of those factors; why 2LM's application for a supplementary licence was held up for so long in the former Minister's office; and why the ABT has called for submissions to the new hearing into supplementary licences without waiting 28 days for the appeal period on the last decision to lapse. The ABT has not been expeditious to date, so why is it endeavouring to be so now?

Many questions can be, and are being, raised about Lismore FM licence proceedings. Minister Collins should answer all these questions and give the matter a full and impartial review immediately. While this brawl continues, the people of Lismore are being deprived of a technology that has been serving the rest of the world for 40 years. I, like them, want some answers now.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am afraid that I will have to disappoint Senator Tierney. I am familiar with the matter that he has raised; there has been some press about it. I am afraid that it is not the conspiracy that Senator Tierney is alleging. The difficulty is that the matter he raises has absolutely nothing whatever to do with the legislation currently before the Senate, and I am sure Senator Tierney would acknowledge that. Because of the operation of the guillotine tonight and the fact that there are a number of amendments—
—Radio licence fees are in it.

—Yes, they certainly are. Senator Tierney knows full well that this matter has nothing to do with the legislation. Because the Opposition has to move a number of amendments, as do the Democrats and indeed the Government, I can say to Senator Tierney that I will address the concerns he raised in the debate tonight, which he used as a platform for this matter. I will respond to him either in the Senate at an appropriate time or by way of correspondence.
—I have placed the questions on notice.

—That is fine. If Senator Tierney is happy to do that, I will respond by way of providing answers to those questions on notice. I will quickly address some of the matters raised by Senator MacGibbon and Senator Powell during the debate. I thank both honourable senators for their general support of the legislation. As far as ALOP is concerned, I am well aware—and I commented on this in Question Time today—that Senator MacGibbon has his own views on the matter of aviation. He has certainly been a maverick in the past in taking positions that were profoundly different from those of his Leader and his Party and in terms of the strong convictions he had about the desirability of continuing things such as the two-airline agreement.

PARA.TAB: I was interested to hear Senator MacGibbon's comments today about ALOP and airstrips in the bush. I substantially agree with them. What he said is utterly and absolutely 180 degrees at odds with the policy of his Party as expounded in Fightback. I do not have time tonight, but I will certainly take the opportunity at some future time in the Senate to canvass just how at odds it is with the Fightback policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you have a copy?

—Yes, I actually have a copy of the relevant section from Fightback with me. In respect of the recovery of the safety levy and the regulatory charges—that is, in terms of Senator MacGibbon's general comments about cost recovery and how inappropriate it is to apply that with a blowtorch, and the cost recovery policies of `this Government'—the Fightback document boasts very loudly that the Opposition rejects out of hand a phased in approach, which we deliberately instituted to make the impact on the industry easier. The Opposition claims that, by implementing all this cost recovery instantly without any phase-in period, it will recover for the public revenue an additional $20m costed in. I direct honourable senators to that section of Fightback.

PARA.TAB: As far as ALOP is concerned, we have taken into consideration—and I thank Senator MacGibbon for acknowledging this during the debate—the social concerns of people who depend on those bush strips. That has been costed by us to the tune of $63m. Senator Powell also alluded to the fact that we are putting in substantial capital upgrading of those airports at no cost at all to the industry or those local communities. We achieved some significant additional funding for that in the One Nation statement, as was referred to by Senator MacGibbon, at a total cost of $63m. Those social concerns of the communities involved can be taken account of.

I have no difficulty in saying that I think the move the Government made in respect of ALOP was a necessary and sensible one. I will give one quick example of why that is so. When I first came to this portfolio there were some 27—I do not want to be held to the actual figure because it was several years ago now, but I think that is right—airstrips on privately owned pastoral properties scattered all around Australia that were being maintained at public expense by the Commonwealth in the Budget, for no better reason that I could discover than they had simply been there the year before and they just kept being funded recurrently.

As to how they got on the list originally, I was not interested enough to inquire. But one does not have to be too smart to work out how privately owned cattle station airstrips received public funding. I thought that was totally inequitable and could not be sustained. I support the Government's move, but that Government move has been tempered by the concerns that Senator MacGibbon raised and it has been funded to the tune of $63m to help alleviate the situation for those people in the bush.

We will be supporting in committee the Democrat amendments in terms of the concerns they have raised with us about the inadequacy of the penalties provided. We think those concerns are reasonably based and we will support those amendments. We will be rejecting the Opposition amendment in respect of liens on aircraft for a very substantial reason. I must say that I certainly expect an amendment from Senator MacGibbon in respect of anything the CAA does.

The difficulty with the amendment is this: the CAA has to have this kind of control. It is in a position that none of the other people with whom airline owners operate are in. For example, if a fuel company has a difficulty collecting its bills from an aircraft company, it simply discontinues supply of the product. That has happened, as Senator MacGibbon knows, and it happened recently in the case of a major national airline. It is a very obvious thing for a company to do if another company is not paying its bills. The same thing applies with lease payments to aircraft owners and so on.

The CAA cannot do that because the CAA provides a safety service. The CAA cannot withdraw the services of its air traffic controllers; it cannot withdraw the services of all of the people it employs to ensure that an aircraft is in a safe condition to fly. It is simply not in a position to exercise those same controls over bad debts, which can in fact pile up to an amazing degree in a very short time if they are not paid.

Fortunately, the majority of aircraft operators in Australia are responsible about those charges and pay them promptly. The difficulty is that if they are avoided it simply leaves all of the honest and scrupulous operators in the industry who do pay their bills to foot the cost of carrying the people who have defaulted on their payments. So the imposition of these liens is reasonable in terms of collecting debts for an organisation that is not in a position to simply withhold its services if people do not pay for them.

That has always been the situation in respect of the position of liens. Some doubt has been raised in some legal circles—although not in the majority of cases—as to the position of these liens. These amendments are required simply to put the matter beyond any doubt. They do not change the current position on liens. They are there for a very sensible reason. We will be opposing that Opposition amendment and supporting the Democrat amendments. We will also be opposing, for both technical and philosophical reasons, the amendments circulated by the Opposition in respect of precluding political parties having radio licences.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: These are mechanical amendments that are consequent upon the substantial amendment circulated to clause 19 of the Bill which I will move at the appropriate time, but I will speak to these amendments now. The amendments are a consequence of a review of the definition of `commercial viability' as a result of a submission received from the Law Council of Australia. They will remove any potential uncertainty associated with the present definition. They will clarify the period the Tribunal must take into account when considering the commercial viability of existing overlapping licences during an inquiry into the grant of a new licence. The present definition limits the Tribunal's consideration of commercial viability to the time of expiry of the existing licence which, in some cases, could be only a few months. Complexities could also arise when the Tribunal is considering several overlapping services with different expiry dates.

PARA.TAB: We propose that the definition of `commercial viability' be amended to allow the Tribunal to consider whether, on the balance of probabilities, an overlapping service will continue to be provided under the existing licence for a period of five years from the date the Tribunal decides to grant an additional commercial radio licence. The five-year period is comparable to the period for which licences are granted and the definition is capable of being administered with certainty. I conclude by saying that the amendments are a positive response to the submissions made by the Law Council of Australia and I seek the support of the chamber for the amendments.
