DEBATE.TITLE: WOOL TAX (Nos 1-5) AMENDMENT BILLS 1992WOOL TAX (ADMINISTRATION) AMENDMENT BILL 1992PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 27 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That these Bills be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to rise to speak on the Wool Tax (Nos 1-5) Amendment Bills, the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), particularly the Wool Tax (Nos 1-5) Amendment Bills and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2). These Bills provide a mechanism for distributing surplus Australian Wool Realisation Commission funds, collected as wool tax from growers, back to woolgrowers in the form of lower tax and introduce more flexibility into the current debt reduction arrangements. There are also minor amendments to the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act 1977 and to the Snowy Mountains Hydro-electric Power Act 1949.

PARA.TAB: This is a repeat of a very similar situation 12 months ago when, in the dying stages of sittings, we had a guillotine debate, similar to tonight—a very restricted time available for debate on one of the great Australian industries, the wool industry, at a time of particular difficulty for that industry. I accept that it is the greatest Australian industry in the history of this country and that a tax was to be imposed on it. It was also the baptism of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, to primary industry. I think he had reason then to question some of the legislative and administrative problems that he had inherited from the industry.

In the wool industry at that time there was a stockpile of over 4.6 million bales, basically a year's production, and a debt of $2.8 billion. There was a debate as to what level of tax would apply to woolgrowers of Australia who were looking forward to a significant reduction in their income because of the removal of the reserve price. They were suffering because of the drought that was then covering much of the wool growing area.

The Government was originally proposing a 15 per cent tax. The Opposition said that a 10 per cent tax was adequate to cover the situation. Eventually the Democrats voted with the Government and a 12 per cent compromise was reached in the Senate. While the industry agreed to 12 per cent, it believed that 3.5 per cent would be used for promotion, 0.5 per cent for research and development and 8 per cent for debt repayment. However, some of the participants from the industry and the Australian Democrats were not aware that the Minister was going to reduce the promotion levy from 3 1/2 per cent of that 12 per cent to 2 1/2 per cent, which in turn has now caused problems with finance for wool promotion.

At that time there was a very severe drought across much of Australia which, as was known at the time, had led to reduced production either directly because of the drought or indirectly because it was no longer of cost benefit to purchase the supplementary feed necessary to keep many of the sheep alive and producing. So for this financial year we have a production of somewhere between 744 and 750 million kilograms of wool. That is well down from the record production of earlier times.

There was also a situation where the wool textile pipeline—the wool going through the wool processing system—was basically empty because of the uncertainty that the wool textile industry was facing with regard to price and availability. Since that time there has been a better than anticipated clearance from the stockpile of about 100 million kilograms of wool.

The debt reduction from the original $2.8 billion will certainly be under $2.4 billion by the end of this financial year. The auction price has moved up and is very close to 600c a kilogram. I commend the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for the way it has handled with its policy the disposal of the stockpile in that time.

We now have the forecasts from the Australian Wool Corporation for the coming year. It is saying that production will continue to fall to about 730 million kilograms and is anticipating that sales from the stockpile could be 50 per cent higher, that is, up to about 150 million kilograms of wool from about 100 million kilograms for this current year. It is even estimating that the price will be slightly higher at about 620c a kilogram clean.

All of this means that, basically, the operating costs of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for storage, interest charges and all other charges of some $374m have been covered. The $20m initial debt repayment has been covered and there is about $300m left. In addition to that, in looking forward, the total costs will fall from $374m for the current year to about $260m next year. So if there is only a 2 per cent reduction in the total tax, which will cost about $54m, the Wool Realisation Commission already has enough to meet its costs for the coming year and it is already below the debt reduction requirement for 12 months time which was $2.559 billion.

First, there had to be greater flexibility in the debt repayment schedule so that the earlier than anticipated debt reduction could be credited against later years; otherwise the industry would be faced with the second best proposition of investing its surplus at a lower interest rate than it had been forced to pay through the outstanding debt. The Minister's response came through the One Nation statement of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, in which the Government indicated it had agreed to flexibility in the debt repayment schedule. I commend the Minister and the Government for that.

Secondly, both the industry and the coalition were quick to point out that at a cost of several million dollars it would be costly to administer; it would be a clumsy system. Anybody who has been involved with these systems before, whether in the wool industry, the horticultural industry or any other industry, knows that it would not be a clean thing administratively. When one considers that every one per cent reduction in that wool tax is worth about $1,000 to an average wool grower with about 5,000 sheep, one can see that it is a significant factor in survival. Wool growers this financial year, according to the Bureau of Agriculture and Resource Economics, will have a loss of $46,000—their worst year in the history of this country.

My colleague the shadow Minister for primary industry, Bruce Lloyd, has put it to the Minister that there is absolutely no reason why the tax for the forthcoming year has to be any higher than 9 per cent because of those figures that have already been indicated, and because all the costs necessary for this coming year have already been covered. When one takes into account the projections of the Wool Corporation for the coming year, one realises that even 9 per cent is a very safe and conservative figure, and that an even lower figure would be responsible. Some of the views put forward by members of the wool industry have certainly indicated that much.

I point out to the Government and to the woolgrowers of Australia that if reducing costs is the most fundamental way of ensuring survival, the coalition's Fightback package is of value. Even the Minister has not disagreed with the Treasury calculation of savings of over $1 billion a year to Australia's farmers. The figures we got from the Department are far more accurate than the Minister's off-the-cuff figures. There will be an average saving of over $8,000 per year per farmer, a tremendous saving to people who are hard pressed. The Treasury document, which is the Government's own document—it is not the Opposition's—shows that there would be further savings of $177m a year in the textile industry and $139m a year in the clothing and footwear industry.

The other part of this legislation makes some amendments—there are some other factors, but this is an important one—to the arrangements for the annual meeting. I acknowledge that the Minister had this Bill under way ahead of the meeting in early May, which indicates once again some of the unhappy legacies that he had to deal with and a recognition that it was not going to be the most successful annual general meeting that could take place. That has been proven to be the case, which is unfortunate. I believe that the new Wool Corporation has been doing a good job in restoring confidence in the industry. This has been an unfortunate and unnecessary blow to that rebuilding of credibility and confidence with regard to the peak industry organisational body.

I note that the changes are to allow registration for a three-year period. That seems to me to be sensible, because there were real problems with timing for the first AGM, when I think about 8,000 out of a potential 60,000 woolgrowers actually registered. There will be the opportunity for broader accountability in future AGMs beyond the restrictions to no confidence motions concerning the AWC and debate on the level of the wool tax. More general items to provide that broader accountability will be allowed. That seems to me to be sensible.

The coalition will be supporting this legislation. However, I question the cost benefit of the big PR-type annual meeting which has been best, or worst, exemplified in the meat industry with the AMLC meeting. Although the wool meeting has not cost as much as that, there are claims that it has cost $400,000.One should not be forcing some sort of overall model on all industries. I question whether what is being maintained in this legislation—that is, the single AGM-type meeting—is the best way to have accountability in the wool industry. There are a number of other ways of doing it.

One way that seems worth investigating further—my colleague Bruce Lloyd has had some discussions with the industry, and we presume the Minister is having discussions with the industry also—is that if we have only one meeting per year somewhere in Australia, because of the size of Australia we will have real problems in having an equitable spread of membership attending that meeting. Therefore, we will have great proxy battles. Smaller, less costly meetings in two or three geographical parts of Australia would seem to me to be an alternative that is at least worth exploring.

I would like to conclude with a few brief remarks regarding the amendments to the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Bill 1992. The first amendment affects the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act 1977, and will allow the evidence of analysts to be given in certificate forms to courts. Currently, the certificate fails to establish that the substances which have been analysed were those found in possession of the accused, seized and passed on to the analyst for analysis. This means that the analyst has to attend court to give evidence in support of other witnesses.

The second amendment affects the Snowy Mountains Hydro-Electric Power Act 1949, which is to increase the value of contracts that the Authority can enter into without prior Ministerial approval from $500,000 to $2m. I commend the legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is welcomed by the Wool Council and by those many growers who appreciate the administrative elegance of this method of reducing their tax liability. There are many reasons to be optimistic about the future of the Australian wool industry. In the past we based our optimism on our competitive advantage, which meant our unique climate, the geography, land tenure and farming techniques here in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We have learned, however, that our natural advantage is not enough. In future we must take full advantage of our initiatives in breeding, pest control, productivity research, infrastructure efficiencies, processing and marketing. Obviously, the wool market is one which discriminates between classes and even traditions of wool. There is room within Australia's great industry to encourage the development of a range of production, processing and marketing models. This can only be to the advantage of the industry.

The carpet wool sector, in which Senator Bell has taken a close interest, has successfully developed a niche for producers who have recognised the unique breeding and producing requirements of the strong wool breeds. This sector has also developed a unique cooperative marketing system. We believe Australia would be well served by an expansion of this system of producer-owned cooperatives, which would encourage local ownership, local loyalties and local buying. Niche markets would be far better catered for. These Bills definitely improve conditions for Australia's woolgrowers and the Democrats will be fully supporting them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the Democrats' interest, and the interest expressed by Senator Lees on behalf of Senator Bell, I expected them to speak for much longer. Here we are once again with a wool Bill before the Senate, as is usual at this time of the year. It has happened every year since I have been a member of this Parliament, and probably as long as Senator Ray has been in this Parliament.

PARA.TAB: I am in a position to say, `I told you so last year'. Half a dozen of my colleagues said they could tell the Government so last year when we were debating whether the maximum rate of wool tax would be the 12, 13 or 15 per cent that the Government wanted. We told the Government time and time again that, because of the way the wool was flowing out of the stockpile, there was no need for anywhere near that 15 per cent tax rate; that rate would send every woolgrower to the wall.

This Government has neglected the wool industry. When Mr Kerin was Minister for Primary Industries and Energy he ran around the world telling people about the wool scheme, or whatever it was called. It is so long ago that I have almost forgotten the name of it. He ran around and told the rest of the world that the price of $900 was ironclad. The Australian Wool Corporation kept buying and buying. What annoyed me was that the benefit of all that buying at high prices was not going to the average woolgrower, the grower producing the 21 micron wool. The very fine wool was bought from places like Tasmania for 1,100c or 1,200c. This wool could have gone onto the market but it did not, and we finished up with a stockpile of very fine wool. The broad wool was being grown in areas where they should have run cattle.

The system went broke and we were left with $4m worth of debt. Therefore, we had to restructure the industry. We said that we could do without that 15 per cent tax; 12 per cent was ample. We did the figures, but Senator Cook, who was representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Industry (Mr Crean) in this place, would not listen and we finished up with a compromise situation. The Australian Democrats caved in. That is nothing unusual for them at this time of the year. They cave in every time the Government puts the pressure on. However, what the Government did not tell the Democrats, and it did not tell us—we would be the last ones it would tell—or the woolgrowers, was that by decreasing the tax from 15 per cent to 10 or 12 per cent, it was robbing 1 1/2c from the promotion side of the industry, which of course suffered.

The International Wool Secretariat started jumping up and down about that because it could see that its funds were being cut. I am generally in agreement with my colleague in the other place Wilson Tuckey, the distinguished member for O'Connor. He has always said that the IWS has been a little over-funded and a bit too smug about its position, and that it could cut a bit of its own fat off its operations. For example, it had 1,000 people working in one building in Melbourne who never handled one bale of wool. We expected the fire to come up from the IWS. It kept going on its own merry way in relation to spending, and now it can see its funds running down. That is why it is very concerned. That was the deal that the Government did with the Democrats, but it did not tell them that it was taking funds away from promotion. So the Democrats were sold a pup like the rest of the country.

We are now in the position that we said last year would happen, with production coming down. Normal production in the high days of the late 1980s got up to about 900 million kilos around Australia. The reason it was that high was that this wool reserve price scheme was holding up wool where it should not be. It did not send out market signals to stop production, and so on it went. That put the pressure on. As soon as the reserve price scheme was done away with, production came down. Production also came down because of the unfortunate drought in the eastern States last year—in New South Wales, Queensland, Victoria—and parts of South Australia.

That brought production down to around 720 million kilos of wool for the year, which was a drastic reduction. No-one really knew how many sheep there were in Australia, but it was between 180 million and 200 million. I believe it is now down to 150 million. As I said, production came down because of the price and the drought. It also came down because the traditional beef growing areas on the edge of the wool areas, which became involved with sheep because it was profitable as the reserve price scheme held wool prices up too high, have gone back to their cattle, or growing coarse grain or something like that.

Last year we put the Government in the picture about the way to go. Unfortunately, neither the Government nor the Democrats have much experience in the wool growing game, except for Senator West, whose brother drives a truck carting wool which gives her the right to speak on wool. She may know something about the game, but we on this side of the chamber do know about it. Senator Cook knows very little about it, and Mr Crean unfortunately comes from near Melbourne port rather than the wool growing areas.

Last year we reckoned that a 10 per cent wool tax was enough. Our figures have proved, production has proved and the prices have proved that that was ample. We are now in a different situation. Having done better last year with prices and clearances, we can now afford a wool tax of less than 10 per cent. I believe that it could be in the 8 to 9 per cent range to give the average woolgrower a little more profit margin. Last year woolgrowers had a negative income, but with a certain reduction in wool tax, they could at least break even.

Senator Reynolds may like to hear that as it may help woolgrowers in Queensland. I believe that with these results a wool tax of 8 or 9 per cent would be sufficient. The reduction in production and the increase in prices and clearances means that, basically, the $374m operating costs of the Australian Wool Realisation Commission for storage, interest charges and all other charges have already been covered. Senator Tambling did mention those figures in his opening remarks.

The $20m initial debt repayment has been covered, leaving about $300m remaining. That means that expenses for a whole year are covered. Looking forward, we see that the total cost will fall from $374m, because there is less wool on hand for this current year, to $260m next year. If there is only a 2 per cent reduction in the total taxable cost, about $54m, the Wool Realisation Commission will have enough money to meet its costs for the coming year. In other words, as well as having the funds to meet its costs for the coming year, the Wool Realisation Commission will also receive funds from the wool tax. That amount is already below the debt reduction requirement for the following 12 months of $2.559 billion.

Those brief figures show the present position of the Wool Realisation Commission. Some of those benefits should be passed back to the farmers. They have cut their production by running fewer sheep as a result of the drought and the non-producers have been culled—in other words, production is now cheaper. I believe the benefits should be passed back to the farmers to help them return to having positive incomes. So much for figures, and so much for telling the Government where it went wrong. By its silence, the Government has admitted it is wrong.

Let us look to the future. Although we have progressed part way down the track from where we were last year, there is still a long way to go. We have to recover from the damage done by Mr Kerin and the greedy section of the industry through having kept the reserve price scheme for far too long. We now have to go the other way. This stockpile will not disappear overnight. I can see it lasting for at least five years, on the best estimates available now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely not.

—Yes, if not a little longer. I can tell you, Mr Acting Deputy President, this will be the last time in our lives that there will be such a stockpile of wool in the world. It can be turned into an asset for forward sales. As well as selling it, we can teach the rest of the world the lesson that the reserve price scheme is not the way to market wool.

PARA.TAB: As I said, we have a long way to go. When I was in eastern Europe last year I could see there was a market for a massive amount of our wool which could be used in the outdated wool mills there. With a tripartite deal with Australia producing the wool, Poland and Czechoslovakia providing the person power, and Japan or Italy with the know-how and high technology providing the machinery, woollen garments could be manufactured in eastern Europe.

As we are short of time, I will conclude by saying that we support these Bills. After all, the main thrust of the Bill is only to increase the maximum rate of tax for carpet wool from 4 to 6 per cent. Honourable senators will remember that last year carpet wool producers in Tasmania were given a special deal. Let me remind the Government and the Democrats of the blunder they made last year when they did not agree to the 10 per cent rate. Although they did not do it then, they should at least take the opportunity this year to return something to the growers by setting the rate at between 8 per cent and 9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —If ever there was legislation that need not have been brought into and gagged through the Senate this week, it is this package of legislation consisting of the Wool Tax (Nos 1-5) Amendment Bills, the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill. If only the Government had listened to us when we were debating the wool levy legislation this time last year, there would be no need for this legislation. At that time, the Government was pushing for the woolgrowers to pay a 15 per cent levy. We went through the dreadful debacle of the then Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, facing a crisis and wimping out.

PARA.TAB: The Minister told the international markets that the floor price would remain at 870c a kilogram clean. He then reneged on that promise. He went overseas and told all the markets that Australia would maintain the floor price but would bring it down to 700c. He went through Europe and Japan and gave his word as a Minister of this Government that the floor price would remain and that it would not go below 700c. Meanwhile, the Opposition was saying that the floor price had to go. Because the Minister had already diddled the market and broken his promise to the market, the buyers really did not trust him. Some of the buyers were forced to buy wool at 700c, but those who did not have to, who had enough stockpile, hung off because they did not trust the Minister. After all, he had just told them that the floor price had stayed at 870c a kilo. When he changed it to 700c, those who had been forced to buy at the highest figure were the Japanese because they had got rid of their stockpile and were being forced to keep their mills going.

When Mr Kerin once again broke his word and got rid of the floor price altogether, the Japanese buyers in particular demanded compensation. They said that they had trusted the Minister's word; after all, he was a Minister of the Government of Australia, and surely his word could be trusted. When he broke that word, the Japanese buyers yelled foul and wanted compensation. But, of course, the Government would not give compensation. We could not have afforded it anyway. But we certainly lost our credibility both overseas and domestically, and I do not believe it has been fully regained yet.

What happened at that stage? The Government had put up the price of the levy to 20 per cent, then 30 per cent. We all remember the stupid situation where the Government made it a 30 per cent levy with a 20 per cent surcharge—the surcharge going towards the cost of the slaughter levy. We had the Government saying that the woolgrowers would not only give up 50 per cent of their wool cheque but also face a quota.

Of course, the Opposition was opposing this all the way along because we had done our figures—figures that were never queried by anyone. Not even the Government queried them with any sincerity at all. We said that there was no need for any of this nonsense and that, yes, we would have a commercial slaughter price but that the levy should be maintained at 10 per cent. The Government was frightened that a 10 per cent levy might not pay it back every cent that it was determined to get, and it struck the levy at 15 per cent.

Unfortunately, the Democrats, in their usual way—while they would not question our figures—would not go along with us. They went, as they usually do, for the happy medium, as they called it—a 12 per cent levy. As my colleague has already said today, every one cent difference is $1,000 to the woolgrower. The average woolgrower in Australia has only around 3,800 sheep, not 4,000 sheep, so the price of the levy was critical to him. Because this Government would not listen to reason, the woolgrowers have been faced with a levy 2 per cent higher than is necessary.

Our figures were very conservative. They pointed to the need for a 9.1 per cent levy. That was on the very low 447c a kilo clean wool. There was a cushioning effect in our 10 per cent proposition of 0.9 per cent, but the Government still would not accept our position. I remember that we were still debating the wool levy Bill at 2 o'clock and 3 o'clock in the morning. We now know that the floor price is above 447c a kilo clean. We could have brought the levy down to our alternative figure if a 475c price clean had been used. On that assumption, we decided that we needed an 8.7 per cent levy.

The Government has wasted money and the time of the Senate. It had additional Bills drafted and there were costs associated with that. It deprived the woolgrowers of thousands and thousands of dollars because it would not listen to reason. The Government is not alone; the Democrats supported it. Let us not take all the responsibility off the Democrats and give it to the Government. While the Government was stupid enough to say that a 15 per cent levy was the lowest it could possibly put up, the Democrats would not look at our figures with any commonsense. They said that they would make it 12 per cent.

We were right: there was no need for anything above 10 per cent. Indeed, we were being very conservative: we could have had a 9 per cent levy. The Government is still being so cautious that it will not go beyond that. I suppose it is with some gratification that we can look at the balance sheet that we proposed just 12 months ago and say that it was spot on. There was never any need for a 15 per cent levy; there was never any need for a 12 per cent levy. I do not know what the Department was on about advising the Government on figures such as that. It is about time the Department learnt a lesson too. There was never a need for anything above a 10 per cent levy.

The Opposition supports this legislation, but the Government should understand that it has deprived the industry of any sort of income. I refer to the ABARE National Agricultural and Resources Outlook Conference 1992. ABARE says that farm business profit in the sheep industry will be minus $45,200 this year. In part, that is due not only to the drought but also to the Government's handling of this levy and this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The main purpose of the Wool Tax (Nos 1-5) Amendment Bills 1992, the Wool Tax (Administration) Amendment Bill 1992 and the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1992 is to place the administrative part in legislation to allow the tax to take place. This was brought about last year by the upheaval in the wool marketing arrangements and there is now a need to finetune the legislation.

PARA.TAB: We can all remember the debate last year wherein the Democrats said that they would support the Opposition. They continued to do so and we said that together we would stick with a rate of 10 per cent. We went right out on a limb and the Democrats came along with us. Of course, as normally happens, the Democrats folded and the wool industry was hit with a tax of 12 per cent. We told the Government that that was in excess, but it became worse than that.

The ink was hardly dry on the agreement when the Government knocked off another one per cent from the promotional levy. The wool industry then was expected to get rid of 4.6 million bales while reducing the promotion. That was an underhand trick which did not have the support of the Parliament, the Democrats or anyone else. Instead of supporting Australia's great wool industry, the Government once again panicked, just as it had the time before, and reduced the wool industry's ability to get out and promote its wonderful product.
For the benefit of the Senate, I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a schedule of the table of repayments for the wool industry.
Leave granted.
The schedule read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: TABLE OF REPAYMENTS FOR THE WOOL INDUSTRY
SCHEDULE:
YEAR 1—91/92—$20 MILLION
YEAR 2—92/93—$300 MILLION
YEAR 3—93/94—$400 MILLION
YEAR 4—94/95—$500 MILLION
YEAR 5—95/96—$550 MILLION
YEAR 6—96/97—$550 MILLION
YEAR 7—97/98—RESIDUAL

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the terms dictated by the Government, there was no provision to carry forward surplus proceeds from one year against program reductions in subsequent years of the stockpile debt.

PARA.TAB: Again the wool industry has come back. It has confounded its critics since 1970 when it was down to a very low level. The gloom and doom merchants have always predicted the demise of the wool industry, and each time it has bounced back better than ever. Last Friday the wool stockpile stood at 4,070,000 bales—down 535,000 bales from its peak of 4,600,000 bales a little over 12 months ago. At the close of the season's sales at the end of next week, the debt against the stockpile will be between $2.3 billion and $2.4 billion. Twelve months ago it was $2.8 billion. Expectations in the first year were for sales of 350,000 bales from the stockpile, which were exceeded and 550,000 bales were eventually removed. The Wool Realisation Commission has now enough to meet its costs for the next 12 months and still be below the debt reduction required of $2.559 billion at this time next year.

In recent weeks, as a response to higher projected wool production estimates for the remainder of this season, we have seen the indicator fall about 15c. However, while the stockpile remains at the current level or any significant level, it casts a long shadow over the prospects of any major further price recovery. The Government, which did so much to undermine confidence in the wool industry, should now take the lead in solving the problem.

A classic case in point is the $270m debt owing by the former Soviet Union to the Australian Government. In 1988-89 Australia exported $869m worth of wool to the Soviet Union, representing in excess of 600,000 bales. The current crisis in the now Commonwealth of Independent States has had a major impact on the repayment of this debt. As a consequence of their debt, they are now out of the wool market, their main priority being to purchase food for their needs; purchasing wool for their factories is a secondary priority.

The wool industry generally believes that, to rank in the top category for debt repayment, the facility to the Russians needs to be extended from the present 240 days to 360 days. If the Government wants to really get behind the wool industry, it needs to have a very close look at this, because this is what the wool industry requires. The present Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Mr Kerin) played a large part in undermining the confidence of the wool industry. It is now up to the present Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) to get right behind the wool industry and give it the support it needs.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable senators for their contributions.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time, and passed through their remaining stages without amendment or debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN NUCLEAR SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY ORGANISATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 May, on motion by Senator Collins:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill 1992. Firstly, I acknowledge all the cheerios, messages, requests and demands that I have received from people all over Australia who have concerns about this measure. Many of those concerns are imaginary and many of them are very real, but I respect them very much for whatever they are.

PARA.TAB: It is only reasonable that I should mention that Lucas Heights was built about 30 kilometres out of Sydney. I believe that everyone who lives in the area now and who has expressed concern has moved into the area since ANSTO, or the AEC as it was, was established. Every piece of subdivision that has brought the City of Sydney to the boundaries of ANSTO has been approved by either the State or local government. Everybody who is there has, for one reason or another, chosen to live there. Of course, that includes many people who work at Lucas Heights.

I am not saying that this means that people should not demonstrate their concerns. They have every right to do so, and I believe that it is only right that they should. However, I am told that these concerns do not appear to be reflected in the property prices of the area, but I am not any expert on Sydney values these days.

The Bill provides for an enlargement of the objectives of the organisation and the sale of goods and services. The reason it is being dealt with now is mainly the legal decision that caused the trouble with the judgment as to what those involved could or could not do about the transfer of materials in or out of the premises. That is the real purpose of the Bill.

The two deals that were involved were the transfer of low grade radioactive material from Fishermans Bend in Victoria and the transfer of an amount from St Marys in the Sydney area. The Bill provides for the conditioning, managing and storing of radioactive materials and it provides immunity to the organisation from various State and local government matters. That, in itself, has caused quite a bit of concern.

It has caused concern because it has been so badly handled. There was never really any need for this to become a major issue, but it did because the whole thing was rushed. It looked as though it was a means of trying to get around what had been a legal decision. The Commonwealth saw that in order to operate effectively it required the ability to override some of the decisions that would otherwise have affected it. So be it; that is the way it is. That is the source of the difference of opinion between the organisation and the Government, as the representative of the organisation—or the other way around—and the people who have these various concerns.

The Shire of Sutherland has been very active and very vocal in its concerns. Its representatives came along and gave evidence, as did many other people, to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology and we listened to their evidence very keenly. They are concerned about the possibility of an accident of any sort and about a possible build-up of the material that is stored there. They particularly do not want Lucas Heights to become a national repository. The Minister came along to the Senate Committee hearing. He gave undertakings that this would not be the case under his jurisdiction and, ultimately, we were able to get the Government to amend the Bill which is before us to that effect. I give notice that we will be supporting that amendment when it comes along.

The witnesses were also concerned about the increase in activity. As I have mentioned, one of the main points in the amendments is the fact that the objectives of the organisation have been enlarged to some extent. Of course, this enlargement will give rise to added amounts of nuclear waste. This concerns them also.

I have already said that the Government has handled the issue badly. It is always dicey to rush things through without adequate discussion. There will always be an element which will object and wonder why things have been rushed through and covered up. This is a case of a very sensitive issue which could have been handled much better.

The witnesses who appeared before us were unanimously united about the possible difficulties and particularly about the fact that they were left with the perception of an increased risk. While I notice that Senator Richardson was reported recently as having made the comment that we do not have to worry about fear, that it can be an excellent weapon—or words to that effect—it is a very bad thing when something is left in limbo and, as a result, people cannot be put at ease in due course.

The public relations of the Government, and in this case ANSTO, have been quite inadequate. I do not think the legislation is adequate to put people at ease yet, but it will certainly help in some ways. It is now up to the Government to make the required adequate provisions for the future. The date of 5 January 1995 has been laid down for the establishment of a new repository. The Government has to get this under way so that the people of the area can settle down and so that the people of Australia will be able to see that the nuclear industry still has a future and a good one.

We have to retain and improve our nuclear industry. There are so many areas where Australia has done well in this field. Our great atomic scientists have given Australia great service and they must go on doing so and further the application of this science in industry, agriculture and health. As a result of the Senate Committee inquiry there is not only an assurance but also now the amendment, as I have mentioned, that there will now not be a nuclear repository at Lucas Heights. It is up to the Government to get on with finalising the arrangements. The Opposition will support the Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill. The Senate is debating a Bill that has been a source of much controversy in my home State of New South Wales, particularly in the Sutherland Shire which is where the Lucas Heights reactor is located. It is well known that the residents of the Sutherland Shire Council area and the Council itself are implacably opposed to this Bill. So is the New South Wales Government and Labor, Democrat and Independent members of State Parliament. Environment groups, such as the Sutherland Shire Environment Centre and Greenpeace, have also voiced their strong opposition. Moreover, the general public is extremely concerned about the ramifications of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: This led the Senate to agree to refer the Bill to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. The Committee held a public hearing on 25 May to listen to these concerns. A number of local groups, along with the New South Wales State Government, were able to put their problems on the table. This was an extremely valuable exercise in helping to clarify the issues at stake and allowing members of the community to have their say.

As outlined in my minority report, the Australian Democrats agree substantially with the conclusions reached by the Committee. The Committee found that there is real concern that ANSTO will be empowered to transport nuclear waste not produced as a result of ANSTO's activities at Lucas Heights to Lucas Heights for indefinite storage, establishing a de facto nuclear waste dump and removing the urgency of identifying and establishing a permanent, safe nuclear waste repository.

The Committee considered that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Free) could do much to allay community concerns by giving legislative effect to his assurances concerning Lucas Heights not being used as a national permanent nuclear waste repository. We are pleased to see that the Government has distributed an amendment which goes some way to giving this assurance, but not far enough. I will be moving an amendment which strengthens the weak assurance given by the Minister.

The Bill adds to ANSTO's functions by stating that it will condition, manage and store radioactive materials and radioactive waste. This section has caused alarm and justifiable concern which should be addressed by this chamber. The Committee also considered that the Minister could further allay concerns by giving legislative effect to his assurances concerning the effects of commercialisation of ANSTO and the Government's commitment to the establishment of a permanent nuclear waste repository by 1995. The Minister has patently failed to do so. In fact, the Government has done nothing to allay genuine fears in the community that this Bill will cause a serious erosion of people's rights and possibly lead to the importation of nuclear waste into Australia.

This Bill, if passed in its present form, will exempt ANSTO from State environmental and planning legislation. ANSTO will be subject only to Commonwealth law; however, the Commonwealth has no parallel environmental and planning laws. This is totally unjustifiable. The Bill effectively puts ANSTO above State and Territory environment laws. The Commonwealth is riding roughshod over the local Sutherland Shire community and the rights of all citizens, not only in New South Wales but in all States and Territories of Australia.

The Minister in his second reading speech claimed that ANSTO was established under Commonwealth legislation to undertake specified activities in the national interest in accordance with the policies of the Commonwealth Government, and that the Government had never intended that ANSTO be subject to State laws. Here is a conflict between the national interest and local and State interests. The Government has not sought in any way to accommodate local and State interests. It has simply adopted commando control tactics which completely disregard the rights and concerns of ordinary citizens.

It is the view of the Democrats that this part of the Bill is a total abrogation of the intergovernmental agreement on the environment, a memorandum of understanding which seeks greater cooperation amongst the States on environmental issues. The Commonwealth must have broad agreement amongst the States if we are to fight some of the major environmental issues facing this country, such as land degradation, coastal management and waste disposal. Indeed, agreement of the States will be necessary if the whole issue of a national nuclear waste repository is to be resolved. One would hope that somewhat more consultation will take place on that question than has been the case on the ANSTO Amendment Bill.

In the words of my minority report, this Bill will erode confidence in the process of cooperation with the States on environmental matters. However, the Minister has deemed cooperation and consultation with the States as unnecessary. He has cited the so-called national interest. Certainly, during the public hearing it became evident that ANSTO did in fact need certain powers to deal with particular issues of waste storage and waste management. The case of isotope packages broken at Mascot airport was raised as an example, and we would agree that provision should be made for waste management of this nature at Lucas Heights. However, it is unnecessary to give ANSTO the wide powers contained in this Bill to deal with those occurrences. To that extent, and when the proposed management activities are combined with ANSTO's commercial activities and the potential for expansion, community concern about this legislation is fully justified.

But our objections do not stop here. The Government proposes to make the immunity in proposed new section 7A retrospective so that ANSTO will be taken to have never been subject to State and Territory laws. This smacks of a government hastily cobbling together a piece of legislation to overcome the difficulties posed by the New South Wales Land and Environment Court decision. The Government makes a concession to the order by Justice Cribbs that ANSTO must remove the 2,000 cubic metres of radioactively contaminated soil from Fishermans Bend in Victoria. This is a concession, however, that we had to have. It would have been completely untenable for the Government to have breached this order.

Another unacceptable aspect to this Bill is that the immunity provisions are extended to those organisations in which ANSTO has a controlling interest. Private companies in which ANSTO has or has had a controlling interest should not be allowed privileges of immunity to State laws. All private companies should be subject to State laws regardless.

The provisions of this Bill would potentially make ANSTO one of the only commercial organisations in Australia exempt from any State planning and environment laws. I will be moving an amendment to that whole clause relating to immunity so that it may be omitted from the Bill and replaced with an assurance that ANSTO is subject to Commonwealth law and to State and Territory law. This should ensure that maximum safeguards are in place on the activities of ANSTO. It makes sense to apply State laws as an extra safeguard and that more than one level of government have control over safety standards set in a nuclear facility.

Another concern expressed by those at the public hearing was that this Bill could lead to the importation by ANSTO of radioactive waste. I will refer back to these two issues later on. The Minister did, however, to his credit give assurances that Australia will not engage in the importation of radioactive waste. He was quite explicit about this in his evidence to the Committee. However, I would ask the Senate whether we can simply rely on his assurances. His and our presence in this chamber is but a flash in the pan in the context of the longevity of radioactive waste.

As the Committee report recommended, the Minister's assurances should be enshrined within the Bill before us. This will bind ANSTO to the spirit of the assurances given by the Minister. Accordingly, I will be moving an amendment to the Bill to ensure that ANSTO must not import radioactive waste. I have also included an assurance that this does not include the import or export of pharmaceutical isotopes—radioisotopes. This is a valid activity for ANSTO to be engaged in, and I have no wish to restrict its activities in this area.

To sum up, this is the Democrats' view: this legislation does nothing to enhance the public image of ANSTO, an organisation which has sought greater transparency of its activities over the last few years. The Bill has engendered a great deal of suspicion about the activities of ANSTO. I would agree with my Committee colleague Senator Archer in that this Bill in fact does nothing to allay those fears and will simply result in increased suspicion about what happens at Lucas Heights. It is vitally important that Lucas Heights be subject to the utmost public transparency so that any fears, whether they are justified or unjustified, can be dealt with and handled in a responsible and open fashion.

I know that there is considerable concern within the Labor Party about these proposals. The Government is certainly not united on this Bill. It is our view that the acceptance of the Democrats' amendments would go a long way to restoring the broken trust between ANSTO and the Sutherland Shire community, and I commend the amendments to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill 1992 for various reasons, which I will point out a little later. The purpose of this Bill is, firstly, to amend the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Act of 1987 to implement the Government's decision to include in the functions of ANSTO the conditioning, storage and management of radioactive materials and waste, and implement revisions which better reflect the Commonwealth's objective to commercialise ANSTO's activities; and, secondly, to provide for ANSTO's immunity from specified classes of State and Territory laws and regulations following advice that, although not intended by the Government, ANSTO may be fully subject to State and Territory laws. It is that aspect that worries me.

PARA.TAB: I believe that I can tell a good story of the situation in Western Australia. This Bill's coming in front of the Parliament this evening prompted a big article in this morning's West Australian—unfortunately, I do not have it with me tonight—again raising fears that we will have a national waste disposal system at Mount Walton in Western Australia.

Back in about 1985 when I was President of the Shire of Yilgarn in Western Australia, the State Government, led by none other than Mr Burke, tried to put a high temperature incinerator into Koolyanobbing, which is a small iron ore town right on the edge of the wheat belt, in which the mine had closed down. Unbeknown to anyone, the State Government had tried to slip one in there. The earliest we heard—it did not have the courtesy to let the local shire know; it could not do anything like that—was when one of the contractors who was working around the place saw some people filming a disused quarry. He pulled up and asked them what they were up to. I think it was Channel 7 from Perth that told him that this was the site of the new high temperature incinerator, so it was filming the site. That was the first indication we got.

When we made inquiries we found that the project was well down the track. The Government had a plan and a costing for it. It had a firm picked out, because it was going to be a commercial enterprise. It had that all picked out and was ready to build a high temperature incinerator there, I believe to get rid of about 1,000 tonnes of PCBs in Western Australia.

That is when the shire went into action and we were able to stop it moving into there. In exchange, we gave it a site at Mount Walton, some 70 kilometres north-east of Koolyanobbing in the pastoral and mining area, to create a storage dump to store the 1,000-odd tonnes of PCBs in Western Australia until a high temperature incinerator could be built, hopefully on a national scale.

The Shire of Yilgarn agreed with the State Government that we would have no objection to that under the right sorts of safety factors. Of course, we did agree at the time, subsequent to when I was in that Council, to let it store low level radioactive material in that place. I understand it has progressed so far down the track now that there is drilling to test the ground to ascertain whether it is suitable to bury the waste at a certain depth without getting into the water table or something like that.

Having got that far, according to an article in the West Australian this morning, Mr Crean, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, has set up an inquiry to look at three sites in Australia for a national disposal centre. He is looking at Mount Walton in Western Australia, Maralinga in South Australia and an as yet unnamed site in Queensland. I urge the people of Queensland to find out where that site is. They are the three sites that are being looked at, obviously for a national storage location.

I am on record as saying that we need a national incinerator or a national storage spot for these materials that require storage and that the materials that can be destroyed should be destroyed. When a site is found it has to be remote but reasonably accessible to transport—preferably rail. It has to be ensured that it is not in a viable mining area or a viable pastoral area. I have fears for Mount Walton, because an arrangement was made that our shire would store material at Mount Walton from the State of Western Australia and material was not to be brought there from other than Western Australia, particularly from overseas. That is my worry. That is the arrangement we came to.

I am sympathetic to what Senator Sowada had to say about Lucas Heights because it is near a residential area. I believe that this Parliament and, indeed, all Australia should support a proper national disposal centre or incinerator centre in a remote area. I am on the public record as saying that that area could be Maralinga, which is pretty near central Australia. It is in reasonable proximity to the standard gauge railway. One only has to go north of the trans-Australia line by road and west of the Ghan line that runs from Port Augusta up to Alice Springs. Unfortunately, the ground in that area is already desecrated as a result of other activities that were carried on.

I believe we should support a site at a central location, but certainly it should not take anything from beyond Australia. I spoke out on the public record in Western Australia about a contract that the State Government entered into for some of this PCB waste to be destroyed in Wales. I am a great believer that we should not take someone else's waste, nor do I believe that we should foist our waste onto any other country in the world, especially one with a high population such as Wales or the rest of Europe. So I believe that export is certainly out and I believe that we should not take anyone else's waste.

Basically, I go along with the thrust of this legislation, even though I am sympathetic to Senator Sowada's point of view. But it does worry me that we are giving the Commonwealth Government, including any subcontractors or private enterprise organisations it may employ, the right to transcend State laws. That certainly does worry me. Even by giving the Federal Government the right in this legislation to do this, no matter what State we might be looking at in which to build a national incinerator or national storage location, I believe the wishes of the State and the local governments close to the sites should be considered.

As I have told you, Mr Deputy President, I had the experience of being the President of the shire in Western Australia where it was attempted to locate an incinerator. I would bet London to a brick that if Mr Burke's Government had been able to build Koolyanobbing at the time, there would be a national incinerator there now. So, yes, we are going to support this legislation and the Federal Government will get these powers, but I certainly hope that it does not override the States; otherwise we will have a debate at some other time.

Clause 4 of the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill accords ANSTO the function of managing and storing nuclear waste arising from its own activities as a research organisation and the controller of the reactor. Under this legislation it has the capacity to manage that waste, but the intention is that it should not have any capacity to manage radioactive materials produced by third parties. The amendment provides that regulations must not have the effect of authorising ANSTO's Lucas Heights laboratories to become a national repository. I move:

"(da)by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsections:

`(1A) A regulation made for the purposes of subparagraph (1)(ba)(iv) must not have the effect of authorising the premises on which the Lucas Heights Research Laboratories are situated to become a national nuclear waste repository.

TAB.TAB: `(1B) In subsection (1A):

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition will be supporting the amendment as it is in line with an undertaking given by the Minister at the time of the Senate Committee hearing. The amendment tightens up that undertaking into a form that is acceptable to us.

As Senator Panizza has already outlined, there could be a situation where the Government decides to set up the waste repository in his shire, yet ANSTO would be exempt from those State planning and environment laws which would apply to the establishment of that facility. To that extent, we ask very strongly that the Government does engage in the kind of consultation that needs to happen on this issue and does not simply ride roughshod over the States, as it has done with the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Amendment Bill. I would also like to say that in our view this legislation is a fairly tardy attempt to shore up the position of the local member who has been severely embarrassed by this legislation and who came under tremendous fire in his electorate for his apparent support of this Bill when he voted for its passage through the House of Representatives.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Senator Cook:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill amends the Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Act 1989, which established the national industrial chemical notification and assessment scheme. The 1989 Act established a national system of notification assessment of industrial chemicals to protect people at work, the public and the environment from the harmful effects of industrial chemicals. The Bill is a progression from the 1989 Act, which was intended to remove an impediment to product development. It provides for the exclusion of chemicals which are being commercially evaluated from the elaborate and expensive assessment provisions of the Act.

PARA.TAB: The amendment is self-evidently beneficial. It is supported by the Opposition and the industry. The Bill introduces a new division 1A, which establishes a commercial evaluation permit system for new industrial chemicals and will allow for them to be manufactured or imported to determine their potential for commercial application. What usually happens now is that when a new industrial chemical is imported into or manufactured in Australia it must be subject to a full assessment under the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme, or NICNAS for short. The NICNAS regulations were a problem to industry as they restricted the introduction of new chemicals.

The main objective of the proposed commercial evaluation permit system is to bypass the assessment certificate system while ensuring that adequate safeguards are met where the introduction of new industrial chemicals is needed for the sole purpose of commercial evaluation. The new system will ensure that the maximum quantity of chemical that may be introduced is 2,000 kilograms for a maximum period of two years. There are a few qualifications to this.

Looking back to when the industrial chemicals Bill was debated in this place in December 1989, I notice that my former colleague Senator Puplick raised a concern that the Act would lead to undue delays and costs to the industry applicants for assessment. This is, of course, what happened and is the reason for the amendment we are currently debating. The Bill has been sought by industry, and the coalition supports this reduction of regulatory burden on industry while maintaining necessary safeguards. It is a forerunner to a number of changes to improve the scheme, and I understand that the industry is enthusiastic about further amendments expected later this year. As indicated earlier, the Opposition supports the Bill.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL CHEMICALS (NOTIFICATION AND ASSESSMENT) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Chemicals (Notification and Assessment) Amendment Bill 1992 seeks to amend the principal Act by implementing a new commercial evaluation permit system, where a company seeks to either import or manufacture a limited quantity of a new industrial chemical for commercial evaluation purposes.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats will be supporting this Bill, with one minor amendment which I will move at the committee stage. It is our view that this Bill will provide industry with a regulatory mechanism for new chemicals which will result in a far easier assessment process for products before they reach the commercial application stage. This move will particularly benefit the paint industry and those companies which require chemicals in large amounts for commercial testing.

Companies will be able to manufacture or import a maximum of 2,000 kilograms for a maximum of two years. Strict requirements will be placed upon an applicant who wishes to introduce a chemical in excess of 1,000 kilograms, or introduce it for more than one year, and an applicant will have to prove that the excess time and quantity are absolutely necessary for commercial evaluation purposes. The Director of the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme also retains strong powers to revoke a permit if the applicant has breached the terms and conditions under which it was issued.

The commercial evaluation permit procedures are, in our view, satisfactory. Industry will be required to prepare a material safety data sheet outlining health impacts, safety procedures and physical properties of the chemical, amongst other things. Further information may also be required by the Director of Chemicals Notification and Assessment, under clause 21F.

The Australian Democrats were initially concerned that the material safety data sheet did not include a statement of the environmental effects in respect of commercial evaluation permits. However, the Department of Industrial Relations has advised us that at various meetings with the chemical industry and the ACTU it was agreed that material specified as `other information' in the regulatory device under clause 21D(2)(b) would include material from the schedules to the Act that requires information on the environmental effects of the chemical.

It was also agreed that paragraphs 7 and 8 of part B of the schedule to the Act, which deals with environmental matters, would be information that would be prescribed under the proposed paragraph 21D(2)(b). This agreement has been endorsed by the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme tripartite advisory committee. I hope the Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Cook) will endorse this advice in the chamber. This Bill will not abrogate the national industrial chemicals notification and assessment scheme, as a chemical will still be subject to full assessment should an applicant desire to use the new chemical for commercial purposes.

This Bill will enable industry to effectively and quickly evaluate new chemicals without the red tape necessary for full commercial use. The commercial evaluation permit system, as outlined in this Bill, will help industry to respond to the current atmosphere of swift change, and produce development in manufacturing without compromising environmental standards. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—Yesterday and the day before, as Minister in this place presiding over the Industrial Relations Bill, I was faced with—dare I say it—hostile and sometimes raucous debate over the Bill. So it is my pleasant duty tonight to be met with a unanimity of approval for this Government measure. I acknowledge the contributions made by Senator Parer, on behalf of the Opposition, and Senator Sowada, on behalf of the Australian Democrats. They have accurately and fulsomely described the purpose of the Bill and applauded its merits. It is for me, therefore, to commend the Bill to the Senate and wish it a swift and happy passage.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The Bill.
Amendment (by Senator Sowada) proposed:
Clause 5, page 5, proposed section 21J, lines 7 to 12, omit the section, substitute the following section:

PROCTEXT.PARA: "`21J.If the Director grants a commercial evaluation permit the Director must publish in the Chemical Gazette a notice setting out particulars of the permit.".

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Liberal and National parties, I wish to indicate support for this amendment moved by the Australian Democrats. I point out that we did have some initial concern that perhaps the confidentiality of people whose names would be published in the Chemical Gazette may not be protected, but on further checking with both the Department and the industry we are assured that confidentiality will be protected and, therefore, we support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Let me complete the tripartite chorus of consensus. I accept the amendment on behalf of the Government and will vote for it. That means that this Bill will indeed have a swift and happy passage.

—I thank the Government and the Opposition for supporting our amendment. As Senator Parer has correctly pointed out, it will ensure that all permits granted under the commercial evaluation permit scheme will be published in the Chemical Gazette. Our concern on initially reading the Bill was that only those permits that specified quantities in excess of the prescribed amount would have to be noted in the Chemical Gazette. It was our belief that all permits given under the system should be noted in the Chemical Gazette. I am glad that the Government has accepted this amendment, as I am sure that this amendment will allay the fears of many environmental and health groups who may have felt that suspect chemicals were somehow creeping into Australia without adequate public scrutiny. I thank the Government and the Opposition for supporting this amendment and commend it to the Committee.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with an amendment; report adopted.
