SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to refer briefly to a matter I raised during Question Time today and to which I received an unsatisfactory answer. I remind the Senate that I asked Senator Button representing the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) about the declarations of interest of the Prime Minister, particularly relating to the Danpork joint venture. I referred the Minister to the Prime Minister's declaration to the Clerk of the House of Representatives that on 15 May last year, while Treasurer and Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Keating invested in `a company which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business' but that this did not constitute a controlling interest and that he was not a director.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button has continually claimed that `the Prime Minister's family company has invested in a joint venture company which is composed of Danpork and Brown and Hatton; the Prime Minister's returns and declarations of interest have been published in relation to that matter; and he has been absolutely diligent in declaring his interests'. I asked Senator Button:

SPEECH.PARA: Where in this allegedly full declaration by the Prime Minister is there any mention of Brown and Hatton, or Danpork, or any statement or even indication that he—
that is, Mr Keating—

has in reality a half interest in the pig investment company involved in this multi-million dollar, multinational, payroll tax exempted joint venture in pigs; that his nominee is on the board; and that the joint venture stands to gain considerably from decisions by his Government, such as FIRB approvals or exemptions?
Naturally, I did not get a coherent answer to that question. So I repeated it in a supplementary question. I also asked whether or not Senator Button agreed with the proposition that:
. . . where a conflict of interest with a member's public duty could foreseeably arise or be seen to arise, should be stated?
That comes from the House of Representatives declaration of interest requirements.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button's response was simply to abuse me personally. I do not mind; it does not bother me. I have been abused by experts, let alone amateurs such as Senator Button. As a result of his failure to answer that question, I believe there are some significant problems that now clearly arise. At the end of his response to me, Senator Button said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in terms of the Prime Minister's investment in his family company, the Prime Minister has done everything he is required to do by rules which this Government introduced and which those opposite do not support in the Senate at any time.

That was a very significant change of ground by Senator Button. Having first of all said that these matters were effectively fully detailed and that the Prime Minister's family company has invested in a joint venture company, et cetera, all those quotes from Senator Button have now magically disappeared and, instead, Senator Button is saying that the Prime Minister, in terms of investment in his family company, has done everything he is required to do. Apart from anything else, that demonstrates that the rules are absurd. His statement in relation to his family company hides the reality that he has a half interest in this matter; that he had a clear benefit to be obtained from Government decisions in relation to Danpork; and that the Prime Minister had by a device failed to indicate that he had the interest which has now been so clearly publicised as a result of my efforts.

PARA.TAB: What interests me particularly about this is that it is a breach of the spirit of the requirements of the House of Representatives. That leads to the inevitable question: how meaningful, how useful, are such declarations of interest if they can be so readily got around by someone with a mind to do it—such as the Prime Minister, who sought to hide the reality and the significance of his investments? With the normal and the old system, if one had a conflict or a potential for conflict, one was expected to get up in this place and reveal that conflict. That is what one was supposed to do. If one failed to reveal it, one had behaved dishonourably. Maybe there should be penalties for not so doing. But the present system clearly does not work. The present system does not reveal the potential for conflict of interest and the actual conflict of interest that took place in this case.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the Cabinet Handbook which says that Ministers should adopt a broad interpretation of the requirement, that they should take into account the interests of family members and all interests of their own when considering whether there is a conflict or a potential or apparent conflict which should be declared. If the Prime Minister is not covered by that, what on earth is he covered by? We have a situation where there is a clear conflict of interest. Government decisions have been made to the benefit of the Prime Minister. There has been a phoney facade of Government requirements to declare interest generated, behind which the Prime Minister hides because of a technicality. His henchman here, Senator Button, having first got up and said, `He has revealed all', then resiled from that dramatically in the last response to me today. He said, `In respect of his family company, he has technically met the requirements'.

I find this to be an absolute disgrace, and probably one of the best arguments to support the Opposition's proposition that these declarations of interest are a farce in the hands of someone who seeks to get around them, someone like the Prime Minister. Going back to the old system, we find that if a person had a conflict or a potential conflict of interest, that person would declare that conflict or potential conflict of interest. That is the proper way to conduct oneself. I hope that in subsequent discussions in this place on such a matter the Government will take into serious account the failure of its own legislation, its own rules, to require the Prime Minister to behave with propriety. He has not behaved properly; he has used a device to avoid revealing to the public the nature and extent of his interest in this multinational joint venture.

As I look forward to hearing the usual round-up speech by Senator Ray about members of the present Opposition or previous members of a coalition government having failed to reveal some interest in something, all I can say is this: those in the Government are claiming some special integrity and have legislated for it; they are claiming to have introduced rules that prevent people from sneaking around them, like the Prime Minister has. Their Leader has shown them how meaningless—as we have been arguing—such nonsensical legislation is when we have someone like the Prime Minister who is determined to get around it, determined to conceal the significance of a holding in a company involved in a major joint venture, and receiving a benefit from the company.

I have been asked by various people: `Why on earth do you think Mr Keating did this? Why did he go into this pig venture in a major way? After all, he has invested $430,000 out of his family company's total assets of $480,000 in this one venture. Why do it?'. When I look at the dates of all of this, I suppose I get a fair indication of what may have been the answer. Shortly after he ceased being the Treasurer, after he had unsuccessfully challenged Mr Hawke for the prime ministership, Mr Keating wrote a letter on 7 June 1991 to Mr Lyn Barlin, the Registrar of Members Interests. The letter advised that the investment took place—this was just a little investment and the Prime Minister was not a director, although he had a nominee on the board, and so on—

TALK.START.PARA: —He never said that at all. Stop lying.
—I will read out the letter exactly.
—Read it out.
—I will read it out. It supports exactly what I said:

SPEECH.PARA: I advise that on 15 May 1991 my family company—

Senator Ray should notice that this was on 15 May when Mr Keating was still the Treasurer, about to challenge the Prime Minister. He was obviously preparing a way out of this place. Instead of the Paris option, one could almost call it the Danpork option. The scuttlebutt around the corridors was that if Mr Keating did not get the top job, he was going to quit. In fact, he even said so himself.

TALK.START.PARA: —So what?
—I am saying what the motives were for getting involved in this. I will continue reading the letter. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . my family company Pleuron Pty Limited and I made an investment by way of acquisition of shares in Euphron Pty Limited, a company which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business.

TALK.START.PARA: —It doesn't say `little'.
—Would the Minister like to hear the next paragraph? It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The interests acquired by both Pleuron Pty Limited and me in Euphron Pty Limited do not constitute a controlling interest in that company, nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship in that company.
The clear inference is that this is not a matter of substance.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —If the raucous lot opposite would like to listen, the reality is that this is a deceptive, dishonest and dishonourable bit of paper.
—You are a liar.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. I think Senator Faulkner should withdraw his accusation.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—I did not hear what Senator Faulkner said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. We have here the most outrageous succession of outrageous accusations against a member of parliament, probably outside the Standing Orders. He continues to make them, quite inaccurately, but we allow it, and somebody says that he is not telling the truth about it, which is true, and Senator Reid wants it withdrawn. Senator Baume has been unparliamentary for the whole of his contribution. Let us have some common standards about this place.
—On the point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President: you are welcome to ask him to withdraw but he did not suggest that it was untrue; he used another expression altogether.
—I was not saying he said it was untrue. I am saying that it is unparliamentary to make accusations about a member of parliament without a substantive motion, and Senator Baume knows it.
—In this chamber? A member of the Senate?
—No, a member of either House.
—Senator Baume has been reading from a letter that he has in his hand.
—I am trying to finish it.
—He is an unadulterated liar.
—I beg your pardon. Would you please withdraw that, Senator Faulkner. That is not language that you should use in this place.
—If truth is no defence, I withdraw.
—Withdraw unconditionally.
—I am waiting for the unconditional withdrawal.
—Did you withdraw unconditionally, Senator Faulkner?
—I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the front bench please stop interjecting.
—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I take on board Senator Ray's interjection that the letter makes no mention that it is only a little investment.
—But you claimed it did.
—We will have a look at the Hansard to establish that. The clear inference in the statement—
—You are a liar.
—Who said that?
—Senator Faulkner.
—I withdraw.
—Senator Faulkner, you withdrew a few minutes ago. Now you have said it again. I wish you would refrain.
—Madam Acting Deputy President, if Senator Faulkner persists in calling me a liar, I will seek to move a motion in respect of him.
—I raise a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. The whole process of this speech—
—Which point of order is it?
—If Senator Macdonald listens, he will find out. The whole process of this speech is outside the Standing Orders. The Standing Orders, as always interpreted in this Parliament, have said—
—Which standing order is that?

—If Senator Macdonald reads Odgers, he will find it. The interpretation of standing order 193(3) has always been that one cannot make allegations about a member of either House of Parliament other than on substantive motion. We have let this person get away with these outrageous things in the past because I have the view that debate ought be allowed to flow. But, if he wants to start being cute about the Standing Orders, I want to raise a point of order that it is unparliamentary to make accusations about any member of parliament, other than on substantive motion. He has not moved a substantive motion and his contribution is out of order, and it should be interpreted as such.

—Madam Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: the matters I have raised were entirely within the framework of questions asked of and answers given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate today. All these matters in substance were dealt with at Question Time, as the Parliamentary Secretary well knows. He should look at the questions. The points I am making simply emerge directly out of Question Time.

—I rise on a point of order, Madam Acting Deputy President. There is no point of order in that point. I insist that Senator Baume's statements are entirely out of order and that you require him to desist from making accusations about any member of parliament other than by substantive motion, as the Standing Orders require.
—I am sure Senator Baume will take those points of order. I ask him to bear in mind the point of order raised by Senator McMullan.

—Yes, if the Government cannot handle what I was saying. I have read the reality of this letter. This is not imputing a substantive matter from now on. I will take up Senator McMullan's offer to move a substantive motion at the appropriate time. I thank him for the suggestion and I will do so.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Button noted in his response today, the Prime Minister met the requirements in relation to his family company. Is there anything wrong with that? I did not get any interjections by way of response. Mr Keating said in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The interests acquired. . . do not constitute a controlling interest . . .

We have now established that it was a 50 per cent interest; in other words, control and ownership were shared. In view of the special requirements and special tenderness of the Government, I do not make any imputations emerging from that fact. The letter continues:
. . . nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship in that company.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.

—Exactly so, because Mr Keating has a nominee on that company, Mr Christopher Stephen Coudounaris. In fact, Mr Coudounaris is at present in Denmark negotiating the final nature of the Danpork joint agreement. That is a simple fact. Mr Coudounaris is in Denmark finalising the Danpork deal. We are being sufficiently tender for me not to draw any conclusions from this. All I can say is that the timing of this is interesting—it seems to be a lot of jiggery-pokery or, if we want to spoonerise it, `piggery-jokery'.

PARA.TAB: The clear indication is that, had Mr Keating decided that he wanted to withdraw from politics, this piggery would have provided him with an interesting business interest outside parliament. It is very difficult to find another reason why someone who is now Prime Minister would put himself in a position of potential conflict of interest, which the facts indicate he has put himself in. One would have thought that, having entered into this business arrangement, becoming Prime Minister would have encouraged him not to continue with it in view of the specific requirements of his ministerial standing.

I expect that the Government response will be, `Oh, well, you lot did all sorts of funny things'. As I was saying before, the simple, uncomplicated proposition is that the public of Australia now believes, apparently wrongly, that it is protected by this kind of statement, by this kind of declaration, and by these handbooks, from hidden conflicts of interest. This particular set of alleged protections does not protect the public from hidden holdings where there is a potential for conflict of interest. That is a simple and undeniable fact. The fact that it was the Prime Minister who did so adds another dimension to it.

But I repeat for the benefit of the Government: the Cabinet Handbook says that Ministers should adopt a broad interpretation of the requirements, take into account the interests of family members and all interests of their own when considering whether there is a conflict—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senators should take into account—double standards.
—Order!

—Or a potential for conflict or an apparent conflict which should be declared. There has been no declaration of a conflict or an apparent conflict. Now Senator McMullan interjects with `double standards'. I thank him for that interjection because I have been opposing this kind of phoney declaration—
—Any declaration.
—Any sort of declaration.

—Yes, the only declaration I have favoured I have favoured consistently. Therefore, I am not the hypocrite—Senator McMullan should look in the mirror. The proposition I have been maintaining involves no double standards. I have said that, whenever a conflict of interest emerges, the member or senator should declare it—the conflict. Senator McMullan knows that has been my position and that it has consistently been my position.

PARA.TAB: What we have—and this is the issue—is a situation now where the public are deceived into believing they are protected on matters of conflict of interest yet people who have such conflicts do not reveal them by simply meeting the requirements. In relation to Mr Keating's declaration, Senator Button said, `He has done everything he is required to do by the rules'—and yet the rules do not require him to declare a conflict of interest. That is the issue, and it is a simple, uncomplicated one.

As I said, I would have thought that Mr Keating, having become Prime Minister, would have done something to change his business structure—as I said, probably the Danpork option rather than the Paris option. He should have done something to fix this up, particularly to reveal the conflict of interest.

I deal finally with section 2.17 of the Cabinet Handbook in which it is said, `Directorships in private companies must also be resigned'—that is if one becomes a Minister—`unless, for example, such companies operate a family farm, business or investments, and the retention of a directorship is not likely to conflict with the public duty of the Minister'. If one has a nominee as a director, one clearly gets around that requirement. Is that really what should be done? Should we have those sorts of rules?

It further states, `Ministers are to derive no income through personal exertion other than as Ministers or members of the Parliament'—I do not suppose having conversations with the chairman of the company one has a joint venture with could be described as `personal exertion', although some might think it is—`and to divest themselves of shares or similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities; and, should any particular conflict between duty and interest arise during the course of their administration of their departments, to inform the Prime Minister so that he can decide how the particular matter should be handled'. That probably is the last, if you like, bad joke in this absolutely ludicrous set of guidelines. Yet this Government, having seen the way these guidelines can be got around, is now talking about trying to introduce something like that into this chamber.

It is just ludicrous when clear conflicts of interest can escape, unless of course those on the opposite side are now going to get up and tell me, `We're going to close that loophole so people like the Prime Minister can't get around it'. If they are going to do that, I commend them for their energy but not their intelligence because it is not the way to fix the problem. But I fear they have no way to fix the problem; they have no intention of fixing the problem; and schemes like the one the Prime Minister has employed will be available to others of like mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence)

TALK.START.PARA: —From time to time I have heard suggestions that we introduce a breathalyser into this chamber. I have never been in favour of it. But certainly, after listening to Senator Baume's contribution tonight, I think we should introduce a polygraph—
—I've been on the wagon for three years, Robert, and you know that.
—I think we should introduce a polygraph—nothing to do with a breathalyser—and put it on Senator Baume in a regular way.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume is an ex-journalist. I am sure he would like, and would not be offended by, the title of muckraker. It is quite an honourable historical name that has been applied to a lot of people through the ages from Upton Sinclair through to Private Eye. None of those people when they muckraked ever had the protection of privilege; they had to be able to substantiate anything they wrote in court. For instance, Private Eye had to pay a major penalty for putting things on the public record that were untrue and maliciously delivered knowing they were untruths. That is the situation we are in tonight, and have consistently been in for the past few months when Senator Baume has contributed to a number of debates in which the main basis of his contribution has been nothing other than smears.

I will remind him of a few.These days, Senator Baume has the nickname of `backfire Baume' on this side of the chamber. He was the one who wanted to attack Senator Richardson on the basis of Senator Richardson's trying to clear up once and for all whether Mr Joe Meissner had material adverse to Senator Richardson. He was not happy when the rest of the stuff was put on the public record about Mr Gary Sturgess, an employee of the Party of which Senator Baume is a member, running around the State with $100,000 trying to buy this information. There was no knowledge of where the $100,000 came from, and we still do not know where it went. What we do know is that the then shadow Attorney-General, Mr Dowd, who is now out of State politics, was fully aware of it and that Mr Greiner for once admitted some knowledge of it. That is pretty good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hadn't forgotten it.
—As Senator Faulkner says, he had not forgotten it; he had remembered it on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: We had a second attack by Senator Baume in here on 4 May. Most people would have read it. Senator Baume got up and made a whole range of allegations and smears against a member in another place. He got through 60 per cent of his speech and said, `Oops, I'm sorry, I'll have to withdraw all that', with no apology whatsoever. There was no apology from Senator Baume for having said that someone else had not made a declaration when, after shuffling through his papers, he suddenly found it. He had to withdraw his comments before he was forced to withdraw them.

Again, Senator Baume came into this chamber a couple of weeks ago with a great ambush. He had to deliver it that night because, according to his own words, someone in the press was going to knock off the story and Senator Baume would never want be to pre-empted by any of his colleagues in the Fourth Estate. He made the great revelation that the private company of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) was late in putting in its tax return along with 110,000 others.

TALK.START.PARA: —The biggest own goal in history.

—Senator Faulkner is absolutely right: it was the biggest own goal in history because then it was revealed that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) had several companies which put in late returns. The shadow Treasurer had done exactly the same thing; he was 10 months late. Senator Baume chucked the muck, but it went like a boomerang and hit his own Party.

PARA.TAB: That pales into insignificance with the latest smears that this senator has put forward. Today I went back and read all of Senator Baume's speeches. They are all the same. I remember one great paragraph where he posed a rhetorical question and said, `I wonder whether this is the case'. The next sentence said, `This, therefore, is a scandal'. He answered his own rhetorical question by adducing no evidence and no facts.

Let us get to the question of whether the Prime Minister in any way misled anyone about the extent of his investment. Senator Baume came in here tonight and said that the Prime Minister tried to cover up the extent of his investment by describing it as little, and in another speech as modest. He then read the letter, and it makes no reference either way to the size of the investment. That was a lie, and Senator Baume has put it on the public record and hung himself in his own speech on that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the Minister not to use that word.

—I am sorry, Mr Deputy President. Senator Baume put an intended untruth on the record. He contradicted himself two or three sentences later when he put the truthful record in Hansard for others to read when he incorporated the letter.

PARA.TAB: Where do all these claims such as `modest compared with others' come from? Senator Baume said in a previous speech that it was originally revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald to be a $50,000 investment and shock, horror, it is over $400,000. All that reveals to any of us is that the Sydney Morning Herald got it wrong again. It was not quoting the Prime Minister or a source—

TALK.START.PARA: —No, they just checked with his office.

—They did not get that figure from his office, and Senator Baume knows that to be the case. Building on that case, he says that the Prime Minister has tried to be deceptive because the actual amount of his investment does not equate with what the Sydney Morning Herald wrote about it. What absolute nonsense.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume then got to the second issue of controlling. What the Prime Minister put in his letter was right, he does not have a controlling interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —He shares control.

—Senator Baume has changed it now. When he talked in previous debates he changed very quickly from using the words `controlling interest' and slid slimily three paragraphs later to refer to it as a `major investment'. He is trying to confuse two words which have entirely different legal meanings under the Companies Act, under the declaration of pecuniary interest or anything else. Once again, Senator Baume has come into this chamber and grievously misled it, according to the facts, in order to establish a muckraking case which is nothing more than palpable smears.

PARA.TAB: Senator Baume then asked, `Where did the Prime Minister accumulate enough money to make this investment? After all, he's been a member of parliament for 23 years'. The reason he asked this question is that maybe Mr Keating accumulated enough assets over 23 years to make this investment. He did not make $5m in four years, like someone else in another place. No-one has ever explained—and he has never explained—why he made that money in four years. He was a public servant and a university person, and within four years of entering Parliament he has made $5m.

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one ever asks.
—We do not ask; I do not care about it. But that is the reason Senator Baume has raised this issue—in case someone else asks.
—He was a director of a bank amongst other things.
—They must have been paying him a big bank salary.
—Amongst other things.
—We do not know, do we? We do know a few things, though. This is an interesting point. When we actually look at Dr Hewson's—
—He was not a member of parliament at the time.
—Order! I think there have been enough interjections.

—One of the points that Senator Baume made was that Mr Keating should not have just nominated his own company and the one he bought into, but what the consequential downstream effects of that were. When we look at Dr Hewson's declaration of pecuniary interest we find Jaffrey Pty Ltd, which has some small shareholdings in some public companies. How small are they and in which other companies? I do not care. Senator Baume should, if he is asking these questions and if he wants it all to be detailed.

PARA.TAB: Having gone through the pecuniary interests of the Opposition members in the House of Representatives, it is interesting to see the detail that Mr Beale went into. He was quite detailed. Maybe that is something that Senator Baume wants everyone to do; that is a fair point. They are not required to go into all of that detail, but Mr Beale has. The other ones that I have here do not go into any of that sort of detail at all.
I now turn to the great red herring raised by Senator Baume about the Foreign Investment Review Board. On 16 June Senator Baume said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister gave an indication, an impression, in his statement of declaration of interest that he had simply a small investment of little consequence.

We have heard the letter quoted tonight and it does not refer to a small, large, modest, immodest or gargantuan investment at all. It has never been required. Yet Senator Baume comes in here and says that in his actual letter the Prime Minister says that it is a little investment. Once again, the public record shows that Senator Baume has told deliberate untruths here tonight. Senator Baume then goes on to ask this great rhetorical question:

I wonder whether he was acting in his private capacity as a beneficial owner of a large slice of this pig operation when in the One Nation statement he changed the guidelines which exempted this matter from FIRB review or in his position as the Prime Minister of Australia.

Not much research went into that question because when the truth finally came out we found that the Foreign Investment Review Board had looked at these matters—not only in its original decision, but also in its normal amended form—before he became Prime Minister. The impression that the arch smearer over there gives is that this was all done while he was Prime Minister, implying that the fix was put in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't mind. He can call me anything he likes.

—Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I am sure that Senator Baume does not mind, but that does not change the delicacy of the Standing Orders. To describe the senator as an arch smearer is contrary to the Standing Orders and I ask that the comment be withdrawn.

PARA.TAB: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT—I regard that as part of rugged debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Crichton-Browne had been here, he would understand that this whole debate, under standing order 193, should be by way of substantive motion, either here or in the House of Representatives. Senator Crichton-Browne's side has raised matters which are not within the Standing Orders and we are entitled to respond.

PARA.TAB: The point I was making about the FIRB is twofold. For a start, Senator Baume's dates are wrong. I ask those who have some political knowledge of what happened in 1991 to put themselves in the position of saying, `Well, if the fix was put in, the Treasurers must have been involved in it'. I can just imagine John Kerin and later Ralph Willis saying, having had Paul Keating ring them up, `Fine, Paul, we'll help you out'. After all, we did have a rather major conflict last year over the leadership. Everyone knows where John Kerin and Ralph Willis stood on it. Senator Baume has made an absolutely ridiculous imputation. But, of course, when Senator Baume is in full flow trying to smear someone, nothing gets in the way of his particular point. So the FIRB thing has proved to be absolutely ridiculous.

I for one am pleased that the Prime Minister would see fit to invest in a primary industry, which would have either export potential or import replacement potential in this country. At a time that we are in a rural recession, I think that is a good thing. I would much rather that he—because we would not have this controversy—invest in a productive enterprise than put money into property speculation or buy toy farms or Lamborghinis or Mercedes or whatever else. I would much prefer him to put what money he has into something productive.

I do not criticise all those people in the House of Representatives on the other side of politics who have invested in some of the great firms of Australia, such as BHP. I have an example here of a member who invested in the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, Bougainville Copper, BHP Gold Mines, CRA Ltd, CSR Ltd, Pasminco and Macard Co. Those are all good companies that are doing a great job for Australia. If the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) wants to invest in them, good luck to him. If he is not investing in property booms or something else, great for him. He should be absolutely proud of it.

What I find really interesting about all this is that Senator Baume was a member of the House of Representatives, I believe from 1975 until 1983. He was a member of the Fraser Government. In that Fraser Government there was a variety of Ministers and one Prime Minister, a Prime Minister who could not be described as poverty stricken—good luck to him. He owned substantial rural interests, including a major wool production area. During those eight years in the House of Representatives, when did Senator Baume stand up and say, `Prime Minister, have you stepped aside for every discussion on rural adjustment schemes, the setting of the floor price for wool?', or any of these other things? Not once did Senator Baume stand up and get the Speaker's call.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had to resign my directorship of a meat company because of the potential for conflict of interest, and I did.

—Senator Baume is worried, in the public interest, that a Prime Minister may have a conflict of interest, yet he remained silent and mute for eight years while the Prime Minister—quite correctly, in my view—had a substantial investment in the wool industry. When we banned the athletes going to Moscow, Senator Baume's Government made a decision not to ban the wool trade.
—It wasn't hidden behind a sham.

—I am coming to the sham and the hiding in a moment. In the same Government, Mr Doug Anthony was involved in primary industry—guess what—a piggery. Did he step aside during one debate, one vote in the House of Representatives or one Cabinet discussion on any of these issues? The answer is no. Mr Nixon had substantial communications and other interests. Did he step aside? No, he did not.

PARA.TAB: Going through the history, the richest Prime Minister in this country continued to trade shares from 1951 to 1971. Was he ever accused of a conflict of interest? I say for the record that I do not believe he was ever involved in buying or selling a share based on his knowledge of what was happening in government. He used to drive the stockbrokers of this country mad with late night phone calls about his share trading. But it was never based on inside information.

Senator Baume, of course, would be the silent man. In fact, it really would be good tonight if he were like that clown that never spoke, because that is what he was like between 1975 and 1983. He said nothing. I will tell honourable senators something else: if the Liberals ever win government and six or eight of these frontbenchers, with their very vast investments, become Ministers, Senator Baume will say nothing again. He will remain absolutely silent. Why? Because he is doing this as a partisan Liberal; he is trying to ingratiate himself with John Hewson who does not have the guts to take on these issues in the House of Representatives, and never will. That is what he is doing.

We all know the history of Senator Baume on the front bench. He picked the wrong horse. He is not like Senator Bishop; he did not jump stream. I give him credit for that. When the going got tough and the Opposition jumped to Peacock, he got dumped. He got barrelled out as a pro-Howard supporter. Good luck to him. It happens to us all sooner or later, one time or another. The French have a great saying, `Wine drinker one day, grape picker the next'. It can happen to any of us. So what Senator Baume wants to do, to hang onto his preselection in New South Wales, is ingratiate himself with Dr Hewson as a great muck thrower.

When we come to this question of open government and accountability, we should remember that prior to 1983 no figures were ever published on what the travel allowances of Ministers and Opposition office holders were. They are now published. They are also published for staff members, Opposition office holders and Ministers. No car travel costs were ever published. They are now published for Ministers, for staff and for Opposition office holders and their staff. No travel costs for overseas travel were ever published under the Opposition. They have been published under us. There was no requirement for any declaration of pecuniary interest under the Opposition's government. Talk about the great closed shop that used to exist under the Liberals. Opposition members would tell no-one about any information which in fact could be used—they thought or anyone thought—to embarrass the Government.

What we have seen here tonight is a total act of hypocrisy. We have seen someone who said nothing for eight years about potential or actual conflicts of interest in his own Government suddenly getting up and claiming that there is now a conflict when he has never had the courage or the inclination to raise any of these issues before. He is the one who is always inventing motive. We do not have to invent motive on our side of the House. We know why he is doing this particular thing.

If there were an inkling of substance to the issues he was raising, I would be worried, but there is none whatsoever. The Prime Minister when he was the Treasurer made the investment. He notified the appropriate person in the House of Representatives. He has fulfilled his duty to detail it in the House of Representatives, the same as every Liberal frontbencher has. He has done no more and no less than anyone—other than maybe Mr Beale who gives a lot more detail than anyone else. But all the rest of them give the same detail. Senator Baume is not up asking what public companies Jaffrey Industries Ltd has investments in; of course he is not. He would not be sitting there on the front bench if he did. At least we elect our Ministry. The Opposition's Ministry depends totally on Leader of the Opposition patronage. The more obviously that a senator or member crawls and grovels in that particular show, the better he gets promoted. That has always been the major weakness.

Here we have someone who was silent for eight years in government, when Cabinet Ministers and previous Prime Ministers had much more substantial interests than Mr Keating has. He said absolutely nothing, and then he comes in here and cannot really make a case on anything. Let me go through the issues for three or four of the senators that have come into the chamber. Senator Baume says that the Prime Minister has claimed he made a small investment.

TALK.START.PARA: —An incredible investment.

—It may be incredible, but this colleague of Senator Herron's says that the Prime Minister tried to conceal that investment. He says that because the Prime Minister referred to it as either modest or little in his letter to the Clerk of the House of Representatives. He then reads the letter and no reference is made to the investment being large, small or otherwise.
—Where does it say `Danpork'?

—Where is the Jaffrey company that Hewson or his spouse have a share in in this? Absolutely nowhere. That is the first point. Senator Baume makes claims about whether Mr Keating has a controlling interest or not, and he has to drop off that. He then makes claims about the Foreign Investment Review Board. He gets done on those and has to drop off them. In the end he has no case whatsoever other than this classic case of building smear upon smear, of setting up straw men and knocking them over. Generally in this chamber one gets away with it because it is not as combative as the other chamber, but we are sick of Senator Baume coming in and making wrong accusations.

PARA.TAB: He bungled his accusation against Senator Richardson. He bungled his accusation against a member of the House of Representatives not declaring an interest. He bungled his accusation about the late lodgment of returns, which severely embarrassed his Leader and the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party (Mr Reith). He totally embarrassed them and Mr Peacock, who someone sucked in to ask the question. It was probably Senator Baume because he never liked Mr Peacock much. He probably gave him the hospital handpass. That is his style. That would ingratiate him in a crawling, grovelling and obsequious manner with his Leader. That is his modus operandi—grovelling and smearing. He is without doubt the greatest smearer ever to enter this Parliament. If we ran a competition, the winner would be someone sitting over there, and honourable senators all know who I mean.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is in the gutter now?

—Senator Herron gets down into the gutter only by his association and by allowing these sorts of baseless accusations to occur. He does it only by association. I admit that he does not do it himself, but he associates with someone who directly and deliberately misleads this chamber on such matters.

PARA.TAB: I will finish on this point: I believe the Prime Minister—

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not done well enough. You still have another seven minutes to try harder.
—Senator Baume did not go the whole 30 minutes. Not even he had the gall to make more inventions in that particular way. In conclusion, Senator Baume tonight consistently—
—What did you say about Burke?
—It would be typical that we have not raised the cases of a whole range of people in here who have been up on charges.
—Such as?
—Such as Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen. We did not raise his case from the moment he was charged to the moment he was acquitted.
—You sure gave him a bagging beforehand.

—There is a slight distinction here. We gave him a bagging on a whole range of things, but we did not raise issues relating to his case or anyone else's. We did not raise in here the cases of any one of those former Queensland Ministers who went to Boggo Road, from the moment they were charged to the time they were convicted and sent to Boggo Road. But, of course, those opposite cannot help themselves. Sub judice or anything else means nothing to them.

PARA.TAB: In summary, what we have seen Senator Baume do consistently in this chamber over the last few weeks is launch a whole series of unsubstantiated smears, setting up straw men and knocking them over with absolutely no basis on evidence or anything else. But I finish on this point—the ultimate challenge. Senator Baume has given his speech here tonight. He believes it is true, does he not?

TALK.START.PARA: —My word it's true.

—Right. Get a copy, go outside and read it out on the steps of the Parliament. The challenge is here. I hope it is noted that tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock, or five to nine, Senator Baume will take the speech he delivered here and deliver it outside. We all know he will not. He does not have the intestinal fortitude or the moral fibre to do so. He will not do so. He is scared. He is a smearer but he is also gutless. He will not go outside and read out there the same speech he delivered in here. Yet he tells us in here that it is the total truth. It is not the total truth; it is a total untruth.

PARA.TAB: He does not have the guts, the moral fibre or the intestinal fortitude to deliver that speech outside this chamber. I challenge him to turn up at five to nine tomorrow and re-read his speech out there with no protection at all. He will not do it because he is gutless, he is a smearer and he is a disgrace to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, on a point of order: I demand that Senator Ray withdraw the phrase `he is a disgrace to the Senate'.
—Sit down, you silly old bag.
—Again, I would interpret that phrase to be part of rugged debate.
—Mr Deputy President, in the past I was named for making that comment. If you do not uphold it tonight when I was named for making that comment against Senator Grimes, then you are being partisan.
—Mr Deputy President, on the point of order—
—What is your point of order?
—I would ask Senator Schacht to withdraw his statement that Senator Walters was a `silly old bat'.
—I do not mind that from him.
—I did not hear the comment.
—I did not say `silly old bat'; I said, `silly old bag'. But I withdraw it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —My interest in ornithology goes back many years. I do not need to tell honourable senators that Australia has an enormous variety of unique and spectacular birds. These range from the commonly seen and the very well known birds, from our magpies and currawongs to galahs and white cockatoos, to some of the very rarely sighted birds such as our ground parrot, emu wren and many of our spectacular larger parrots that are very rarely seen.

PARA.TAB: In the early 1980s I was one of several thousand Australians who took part in a project to map where and how often all species of birds were seen across Australia and also in coastal waters. Also mapped were nest or breeding sites. The Atlas of Australian Birds was published in 1984 by the Royal Australasian Ornithologists Union. From this we can see—and I have a number of examples here tonight—that a number of our bird species are reaching endangered levels. Their range has been considerably reduced and, where their range has not been reduced, the specific populations in particular areas have certainly gone down markedly. Some species have indeed prospered. I include amongst these the long-billed corellas that now roam in very large flocks and also in some areas the galahs. Some introduced species have also flourished, and these include the sparrow and the common starling.

However, many of our unique and colourful parrots and finches have rapidly declined in numbers and we must ask why. Environmental degradation and loss of habitat is certainly one part of it. This involves the clearing of land; the loss of tree cover—in particular, the loss of trees with nesting sites in them—the loss of wetlands and encroaching suburbia; and all the noise and pollution that goes along with that. Predation and competition from introduced species—in particular, cats—is also a major problem. Starlings will displace our less aggressive native birds from feeding grounds and also, unfortunately, from nest sites.

What seems a major problem and one that really has not been tackled seriously in any sort of collective way is the trapping and then the exporting—although many do not make it that far—of our endangered birds. In particular, I emphasise the larger parrots. These attract enormous sums of money on foreign markets and they are an enormous attraction for those who are looking for a few dollars or, indeed, a few thousand dollars, or maybe a few hundred thousand dollars.

It is an area where rumours abound and from time to time a few people are indeed caught. As recent transcripts will show, in the last two years a considerable number of people have been apprehended. Some of the less common species but the regularly trapped species include the pink cockatoo or the Major Mitchell cockatoo. I will go through a series of parrots, such as the orange-breasted parrot, and refer to the specific notes on those parrots. Again, trapping for commercial purposes and destruction of habitat are two of the problems suffered by the orange-breasted parrot. The turquoise parrot is suffering as a result of the destruction of its habitat and from the menace of trapping for the caged bird market. In relation to the beautiful parakeet, rats have constituted some menace to this ground loving parakeet, but without doubt the main cause of its near extinction has been excessive hunting and trapping.

Bits and pieces of evidence are now coming together as to what exactly is happening to these endangered species. At this point I seek to table three documents, two transcripts of evidence and a file note.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The links in these documents are most interesting and extremely worrying. They bring together the bird trapping, smuggling and exporting trade with meat substitution, several murders and senior officials in the New South Wales National Parks and Wildlife Service. In light of the evidence contained in the transcripts that I have tabled, and other evidence that is freely available on the public record, including several coroners inquests, I call on the governments of New South Wales and Queensland, and the Commonwealth Government, through their appropriate anti-corruption bodies to establish full investigations into the matters raised in these transcripts.

—At the risk of extending the debate which Senator Ray invited tonight, it disturbed me that Senator Ray took what is a good, regular and normal political position—that is, accepting the high moral ground—but it had a stench of hypocrisy about it. I do not say that in an ingenuous way, but I trust I am reflecting the facts as they exist. Senator Ray talked about hypocrisy. Senator Ray has been in this Parliament since 1980. He came in about the same time as I.
—A bit earlier—in 1981. You came in 1983.
—I was elected in 1980 and came in 1981.
—It is the only thing we have in common.
—That is absolutely right. It is the only thing we have in common.
—I would like to be able to branch stack as well as you do. I am getting pretty close.

—If Senator Ray invites me up to his office and buys me a couple of drinks—and I am a pretty cheap drunk—I will give him a few hints as to how to win when I learn how to do it. The golden thread running through Senator Ray's speech was that there was an impertinence about Senator Baume taking a position now which he did not take when we were in government. The truth of the matter is that, whether the Labor Party was in government or in opposition, Senator Ray's position at least in respect of his own colleagues has been thoroughly consistent.

PARA.TAB: I single out one example. More than anybody, Senator Ray got a wonderful belly laugh every time that crude, rude, unattractive colleague of his, Senator Walsh, got to his feet, using whatever means he could to prop himself up, and attacked members of the coalition for whatever reason, justification or perverse purpose came into his mind. Not once did I hear Senator Ray say, `Senator Walsh, I take exception to that. In fact, I will go on the adjournment tonight and dissociate myself from that vulgar, rude, crude and unattractive conduct of yours'.

I well remember that, when Senator Durack was in the Canberra Hospital suffering from a heart attack, Senator Walsh stood up and said that it was the greatest plea for sympathy since Lindy Chamberlain blamed the dingo. That was enormously amusing to Senator Ray. When Senator Carrick, who was suffering from the attrition of being in a prisoner of war camp in Changi, was on his feet, on numerous occasions he had obvious and apparent tremors; Senator Walsh used to mock, mimic and deride him for his affliction. Senator Ray thought that was terribly amusing.

Just five minutes ago, I asked somebody to find the number of articles in the Hansards which contained the two key words `Walsh' and `Crichton-Browne'. There were 2,000 references to me by that sleaze bag drunk. On not one occasion did Senator Robert Ray have the courage, the fortitude or the integrity to stand up and say, `I dissociate myself from this man and his vulgar conduct'. But now there is great indignation. The only person on the Government side that had any courage and decency was Senator Tate, who came to me privately and said, `I dissociate myself from that man and, if it comes up in our party room and if it comes up for the vote, I will consider my position'.

Senator Walsh was the man that tabled fraudulent cheque butts and was censured by the Senate, with the support of the vote of the Democrats. Where did Senator Ray vote? For that crook. Where did Senator Ray vote? For that person who told lies to the Parliament. Senator Ray was right behind him. He did not abstain; he did not take a holiday; he did not come across to our side; he did not register his indignation at Senator Walsh's dishonesty. Senator Ray voted to endorse and condone, but not condemn, his dishonesty. Now Senator Ray pulls out an old, worn-out speech which is 10 years old to rattle out because somebody dares question the integrity of this delicate petal who is now 28 per cent in the poll, and Senator Ray is terrified that he is going to fall further.

Where was Senator Ray when a female member of Senator Walsh's staff was ringing up in the early morning hours making obscene phone calls to Senator Harradine, who had the President's permission to sleep in his room because his wife was dying of cancer and he was waiting for a phone call to hear about it? She was nailed for her conduct. Did Senator Ray stand up in the Senate and register his indignation and his protestation about that or did he think that was pretty damn clever? I did not hear a word from Senator Ray—not a squeak, not a murmur.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why should you?
—I am not talking about me.
—Are you sure there's water in that glass?

—Did Senator Ray hear that crude, rude and unattractive comment from poor old Lurch, whose claim to fame is that he practises interjections for three days and then still bungles them, and they are only 10-second throwaways? What contribution does Senator Ray make to integrity and honesty? Where was he when Senator Schacht bugged a private committee meeting and then came in with the documents, put them on the table and read them out? Where was Senator Ray? Talk about Watergate! That was a whole new level of dishonesty. Where was Senator Ray? He was silent. He was sitting back in his office, sucking on his cigar, very amused. I am not saying that Senator Ray is a hypocrite, but all the indications point in that direction. The moment his fragile petal on 28 per cent in the polls gets attacked in the course of a robust debate in this chamber—
—Order on my right and on my left! Order on both sides of the chamber!

—At the risk of interrupting the interjections, if the measure of Senator Ray's qualification for standing in his place to register his protestation is whether something is true or untrue, all I can say is that he is very clumsy in getting to his feet. I have never seen him, never heard him, rise to question the integrity of his own colleagues when he knows where they stand.

PARA.TAB: When we had the whole sordid debate about the bottom of the harbour scheme which finally brought down Bill Hayden and had him elevated to the position of Governor-General, not once did Senator Ray get up and say, `This is over the top. This is improper. This is unreasonable. This is unfair'. Not once! Senator Ray was very amused by it all, as he has been this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a pack of lies.
—Not once.
—Were you at the bottom of the harbour?

—We can be sure about one thing in relation to Senator Schacht: he would not have been at the bottom of the harbour; he has never earned a dollar in his life that did not come out of somebody else's pocket.
—That is true of most people.

—When Senator Faulkner says that it is true of most people, it tells us with whom he mixes. It is interesting who he holds hands with—the poor old workers. Senator Faulkner's wife and kids have lived off the sweat of the brow of the workers. What comes out of their pay packets keeps Senator Faulkner afloat. When they are on strike and without a salary, here is the old union official, still making a good fat living.I do not want to prosecute this argument past this point except to say that, if I have not heard gross hypocrisy tonight, I have never heard it. Senator Ray's indignation tonight is fragile. He is simply interested in defending his Prime Minister and not interested in defending integrity, honesty or a reasonable argument.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —We all heard with interest Senator Lees's substantial contribution to the debate on the adjournment, for which we were all duly grateful. I think it was edifying and uplifting.
—What did she talk about?

—Birds. It was a significant ornithological contribution for which the Senate is duly grateful. Beyond that, I doubt that the Senate's reputation has been substantially enhanced by tonight's contributions. However, I do think that had we sold tickets, we would have made a lot more money. Senator Ray's contribution was one which we all enjoyed and for which, as I say, we should have sold tickets.
—It was the same old one.
—No, it was not, it was significantly better. At least he told the truth, which is more than Senator Walters did this evening.
—It was the same old one that we heard about Burke and Richo.

—I will come to that. The problem we have here is that Senator Crichton-Browne followed with these comments about consistency, after Senator Ray had outlined the situation so adequately. The most grievous allegation about the Prime Minister is that the disclosure he made did not indicate all of the secondary investments that his family company has made, when it is absolutely clear—
—Don't you enter into it.
—Senator Walters knows that is what he said—she probably does not, but that is what Senator Ray said when he outlined accurately that Dr Hewson has exactly the same disclosure.

PARA.TAB: Senator Ray, in his usual modest form, did not wish to raise the fact that, while he was shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson was making trips overseas and receiving fees from Baring Brothers and continuing to act as a consultant for Baring Securities. Senator Ray was much too mild-mannered to raise these sorts of matters, which might have been raised in the debate. He did not say that perhaps a shadow Treasurer, advocating alternative financial policies for the nation, should not be working as a consultant to Baring Securities. That is a question worth asking, but Senator Ray is much too modest and mild-mannered to say that perhaps there was a conflict of interest.

Nobody would have known about these consultancies and these conflicts of interest but for the disclosure requirements introduced by this Government. Had the Opposition been in government, those consultancies could have continued undisclosed, as undoubtedly they had for 83 years with different members until this Government came in and cleaned this area up. That is exactly why those necessary disclosure provisions are there—so that such consultancies are exposed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The present Treasurer sat in on BHP when he was a shareholder and didn't tell a soul—and the bottom of the harbour too.
—Senator Crichton-Browne, you have made your contribution.

—We remember the attempts of Senator Crichton-Browne's graceful colleague the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) to elevate the standard of debate in the House of Representatives to that which Senator Baume has achieved in the Senate, and he failed as abysmally. I remember it, and I am grateful to Senator Crichton-Browne for reminding us.

PARA.TAB: We do not want to get into the circumstance where these documents are scoured for potential conflict of interest because, as Senator Ray said, there is nothing wrong with a member of parliament having investments. There is nothing wrong with the shadow Minister for industry having investments in a large number of companies whose fortunes will be affected by the policies he advocated. I do not accuse him of conflict of interest because he and the other person who disclosed that he has investments on the stock market—the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson)—indicate that they want to reduce taxes on business by $20 billion and transfer them to the consumers. They are entitled to do that.

I think it is appropriate that now that we have disclosure we know that those investments are there and that potential conflict is available for the public to judge. Were it not for the disclosure provisions, that would not be the case. All the previous conflicts which have gone on, which have been articulated by my colleague in his learned and patient contribution, would never have been exposed, as with these other conflicts, were it not for the disclosure provisions.

The saddest thing about today's exercise is that all these attacks are launched in the Senate on a member of the House of Representatives because members of the Opposition do not have the courage to launch them in the House of Representatives. They know exactly what would happen if somebody fronted up and started to make these accusations in the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —They're not sitting this week.

—The House of Representatives sat recently and it is sitting next week, and Senator Macdonald knows that. Actually, he probably does not know that, but all the people in control of theirfaculties in this place do know that the House

SPEECH.PARA: of House of Representatives is sitting next week.

PARA.TAB: I simply say that the debate and the contribution that has been made will be analysed by the media. I assume it will be ignored, as was Senator Baume's last attempt to smear and muckrake, as it deserved. If it is not, I hope it is assessed on its merits, to say that this is three strikes. He had two backfires, two bungles, in the past. This is the third strike. It makes it apparent that Dr Hewson in his disclosure of interests follows exactly the same procedure as that which Mr Keating has applied, to which they are both entitled. Three strikes and Senator Baume is out. I am delighted that the Senate will adjourn now, because that might enhance its reputation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Fisheries Act—Plan of Management—No. 32—Southern Bluefin Tuna Management Plan (Amendment), 15 May 1992.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: North Australia Development Unit: Discussion Paper

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer upon notice, on 26 February 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the department considered the discussion paper on Remote Area Allowance by the North Australia Development Unit (Social Security).
(2) Has the department drafted a response to this report; if so, can it be made available to the Senate.
(3) What measures have been undertaken by the department to address the concerns identified that there is no uniform criterion by which eligibility for Remote Area Allowance can be determined.

(4) What is the department's response to the following recommendations: (a) amend the existing policy and legislation to make physical presence of Tax Zone A as the only criterion for receipt of Remote Area Allowance; (b) extend the payment of Remote Area Allowance to clients physically present in Tax Special Zone B. Introduce a discretionary test similar to taxation legislation for people resident near Zone boundaries; and (c) Social Security apply pressure to review and re-establish the basis for Tax Zones, district and remote allowances and Remote Area Allowance. Ensure that Social Security is represented on any working party, task force or inquiry involved in reviews.

(5) What initiatives has the department taken to review the present Tax Zone system, through investigation of costs in each zone, expenditure patterns of people within those zones and regional variations.
(6) What is the role of the Department of Social Security in any review that the department is undertaking of the present Tax Zone system.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Treasury has not commented on this discussion paper. However, Treasury undertook, with assistance from the Department of Social Security and in consultation with the Prime Minister's Country Task Force, a departmental review of income tax and social security arrangements in remote areas that was carried out in the early part of 1990.

(3) and (4) The senator has addressed the same questions to the Minister for Social Security whose department administers the Remote Area Allowance. Senator Richardson provided an answer on 31 March 1992 (Senate Question No. 1705) which indicates the Government's approach to the matters raised.
(5) In response to the departmental review carried out in the early part of 1990, the Government decided to:
include Lord Howe Island and Nhulunbuy (NT) in special Zone A and King Island and the Furneaux Group of islands in income tax Zone B;
remove the distinction between special areas of Zones A and B by increasing the dependants' component in the special Zone B tax rebate to a level equal to that applying in special Zone A; and
extend payment of the Remote Area Allowance to residents of special Zone B.
The taxation measures took effect from 1 July 1990 and the Remote Area Allowance extension took effect from 1 January 1991.
(6) See (1) and (2) above.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 7 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Foreign Investment Funds, is July 1992 still to be the commencement date given the problems identified by major bodies, for example the Tax Institute and Institute of Chartered Accountants, for the new taxation regime affecting foreign investment funds.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Government intends to proceed with the commencement date of 1 July 1992 for the Foreign Investment Fund (FIF) taxation measures. The broad design features of the FIF measures were originally announced in the 1991-92 Budget, and were detailed in the April 1992 Information Paper, Taxation of Interests in Foreign Investment Funds.

The FIF measures will bring to tax on a current basis the income of Australian investments in foreign companies and trusts that are generally not controlled by Australians. In designing the FIF measures, the Government has carefully targeted those non-controlling interests in foreign entities that provide the greatest scope for tax avoidance.
The Government considered all submissions received in response to its 1991-92 Budget announce

ANSWER.PARA: ment and consulted extensively with interested parties. As a result, the arrangements outlined in the Information Paper incorporate a number of modifications, all of which are favourable to taxpayers and will substantially improve the operation of the measures. Following the release of the Information Paper, the Government has continued to consult with industry representatives, and is confident that the legislation that will be introduced into Parliament will address any legitimate concerns raised by those representatives about the FIF measures.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 19 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What was the total area of cereal crops grown in Australia in 1990-91.
(2) What are the main methods of disposing of cereal straw available to growers and proportionally what are the main methods actually used.
(3) What Commonwealth funds, if any, have been allocated to research into methods of disposal and recycling that are more environmentally friendly than burning.
(4) What methods of disposal are recommended to achieve the goal of returning organic matter to the soil.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The latest estimate by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics (ABARE) of the total area of cereal crops planted in Australia in 1990-91 is 13,356 thousand hectares.

However, it is worth noting that because of the dry conditions which persisted through Queensland and northern New South Wales during winter last season, some of this area which was planted to grain was eventually abandoned or was grazed or cut for hay.

(2) There are a range of methods for disposing of cereal straw currently practised by Australian growers including grazing, natural decay, partial incorporation by offset tandem discs and one-way disc ploughs, burning, rolling, slashing, flail mowing and mulching, and breaking down stubble by other mechanical means. Many of these methods involve costs associated with the destruction of the straw in preparation for planting.

Because of the variation of the types of methods used to dispose of cereal straw, depending upon such factors as the growers' cropping programs and rotations, tillage and sowing methods and soil types, an accurate indication of the proportional distribution of cereal straw destruction methods is not available.

(3) The Commonwealth matches the research expenditure of the Grains Research and Development Corporation (GRDC), up to a limit of 0.5 percent of the gross value of production of grains in any year. In 1990-91, industry contributions through levies amounted to $12.6 million, while the Commonwealth matching contribution for expenditure in that year was $8.9 million.

I am advised by the GRDC that much of the research effort it has funded in the past has involved straw disposal as an integral or incidental part of projects with other agronomic purposes, for example, stubble retention and minimum tillage systems. The GRDC has also informed me that it would not be a practicable proposition to seek to identify the amount of money attached to the straw disposal aspects of such projects.

(4) The achievement of agricultural practices which are both environmentally and economically sustainable does not necessarily incorporate a goal of returning organic matter to the soil in every case. This would depend upon, for example, factors such as cereal and grass borne disease control, soil structures, intended land use, or the environmental effects of alternative disposal practices.

In the end the farm management practices and the operation of the farm as a business will together determine the method of cereal straw disposal which, for the long term success of the farming enterprise, should seek to achieve a balance between environmentally and economically sustainable cropping enterprises.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 27 May 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the speech given by the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services (Mr Howe) at the Disability Employment Action Centre conference on 21 May 1992 during which, on page 10, of his speech, he referred to the census of service providers for people with disabilities, please provide: (a) details of the aims and objectives of the survey; (b) a copy of the questionnaires and other forms; (c)details of the census sample; (d) details of the cost of the census; (e) details of the time period over which the survey was conducted; and (f) a copy of the detailed results from the census.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (a) The Department of Health, Housing and Community Services has the responsibility to collect basic information from funded service providers in order to discharge its administrative obligations, to assess its budgetary requirements and to evaluate services and to plan for the future. Consequently, it undertook a census of disability services in March 1991.
The main objectives of the census were:—

ANSWER.PARA: (1) to provide basic administrative information for the Disability Services Program (DSP);
(2) to establish initial benchmarks from which Program targets can be set and measured;
(3) to clarify and quantify the inputs to the Program in terms of finance and staffing;
(4) to provide a foundation for establishing greater accountability for actual outcomes achieved;
(5) to facilitate subsequent assessment of Program performance, eg against previous census data and/or Program goals; and
(6) in brief, to provide a comprehensive and effective instrument for the planning, management and evaluation of the Program.

PARA.TAB: (b) A copy of the questionnaire has been provided to the Senator. There were no other forms either supplied to, or by, service providers.

(c) A pilot census of 35 services was conducted on 25 January 1991 following which feedback from each participating service provider was utilised in the development of the final questionnaire and procedures.

The final questionnaire was sent to all services funded by the DSP (approximately 1,700) and was to be completed for Census day (18 March 1991). The total response rate was 94% (1,587 services). (d) The total cost of the census was $290,322, consisting of $287,504 paid to the consultants—AGB Australia and $2,818 for independent support.
(e) The DSP Census was conducted by AGB Australia during the period January to June 1991.

Three reference periods—Census day (18 March 1991), the last funding year (1 July 1989 to 30 June 1990) and the month of February 1991—were used in the questionnaire. This was aimed at obtaining data on the flexibility of the service delivery system by using through-put measures over the last funding year and giving a picture of service provision at a particular point in time.
(f) A copy of the 1991 Census of Disability Services Final Report with a covering letter and explanatory notes has been provided to the Senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 4 May 1992 (Hansard page 2034) Senator Reid asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning:

PARA.TAB: "In view of the fact that the annual inflation rate was 1.7 per cent for the year to the end of the March quarter 1992, that the average weekly earnings increased by only 2 per cent in the year to the end of the December quarter 1991, and that interest rates on savings investment accounts have almost halved, will the Government introduce legislation to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act to calculate the increase in provisional taxpayers' income at a more just and realistic level than the current 10 per cent?"
The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

The provisional tax uplift factor was set at the rate of 10 per cent to reflect broadly the expected long term growth in incomes subject to provisional tax. While inflation and interest rates are components of the growth in incomes subject to provisional tax, they are not the only components. Incomes subject to provisional tax may be expected to exhibit quite a sharp proportional rise during the emergence from an economic downturn.

If a taxpayer considers that the amount of provisional tax assessed in any year is more than his or her expected tax liability for the year, the taxpayer is able to vary the provisional tax liability to the amount of the expected lesser tax liability. This self-assessment option is available to those who believe their incomes for the year will not rise by 10 per cent.

The 10 per cent uplift factor was set in legislation with a view to making the provisional tax system more simple and certain by avoiding the need to adjust the rate annually. Nevertheless, the Government is monitoring the experience with the current uplift factor, and would introduce amending legislation, if it believed that alteration of the uplift factor was warranted in future years.
